videos.description: Consider others and avoid creating bad joint karma so we can have a better future.

videos.title: Guidelines for and levels of benevolence (GDD-830, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We must compassionate and wise at the same time or it's not real compassion, but foolish compassion.

videos.title: How do we care for others without hurting them even more (GDD-832, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should act to express our care and concern and do it in all sincerity.

videos.title: While we care for others, how should we protect ourselves from hurt (GDD-833, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should care for others according to our ability only, so we can avoid burdening ourselves instead.

videos.title: How are caring and acceptance related to each other (GDD-834, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The true meaning of acceptance is to open your mind and embrace all things.

videos.title: Won't acceptance become indulgence in the end (GDD-835, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should use our wisdom to solve all misunderstandings and conflicts.

videos.title: How do we use wisdom to accept others and resolve problems (GDD-836, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Acceptance can increase our wisdom and reduce our vexations and enemies.

videos.title: Guidelines and limits to accepting others (GDD-837, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Discard the self and accept according to our ability.

videos.title: How do we remain tender in accepting others (GDD-838, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Letting go of the self, treating others with softness are the manifestations of strength.

videos.title: The real meaning of overcoming harshness with tenderness (GDD-839, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: True perseverance lies in being kind to people and learning to be soft.

videos.title: What it takes to care for people an open and clear mind (GDD-840, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should keep an open and clear mind or else we're just as ignorant as animals and muddle through our lives.

videos.title: How can one transform depression into an open and clear mind (GDD-841, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Depression is becoming increasingly common in our complex and fast-changing world. But we should strive to adapt to conditions and do our best to keep up with the times.

videos.title: What can we do to foster a cheerful mind (GDD-842, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: When depressed or entangled, just look at things in a positive light and a whole new vista will appear you. The environment changes with your mind and you'll be cheerful and at ease.

videos.title: Contentment through reduced desire and its effect on purifying the spirit (GDD-843, Master Sheng-Yen
videos.description: Contentment through fewer desires entails pursuing less what we don't actually need and wise use of our fortune.

videos.title: Living a simple life and being content with few desires (GDD-844, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Living a simple life, being content with few desires, can actually be a life of refinement and taste, and is the key to protecting and preserving the Earth.

videos.title: How do we remain content with few desires in our daily life (GDD-845, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: To reduce, reuse, and recycle things in our daily life is to practice being content with few desires.

videos.title: What does the Dharma tell us about choosing an occupation (GDD-847, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Through our jobs, we should try to create benefit not just for ourselves, but also for others, and to dedicate ourselves to society, humanity, and all sentient beings.

videos.title: Dealing with adversity in the workplace by applying the Dharma (GDD-848, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should not be arrogant in favorable circumstances, nor become disheartened when facing adversity.

videos.title: Helping students with learning difficulties by applying the Dharma (GDD-849, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Mutual respect and paying attention to speaking respectfully will help us achieve "verbal harmony without dispute".

videos.title: The kind of EQ modern people require in the workplace and ... (GDD-850, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Dharma can help us achieve a calmer state of mind, reducing negative emotions and bringing out positive emotions in us, which are invaluable in all walks of life.

videos.title: How can we care for others in proper measure (GDD-831, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Care for your family and friends in good time, this will warm the hearts of everyone everywhere.

videos.title: The difference between a positive and negative attitude (GDD-816, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Positive attitude to life is about knowing your direction. But the journey is more important than the destination, for only then can you bring happiness to yourself and others.

videos.title: How can we remain positive (GDD-817, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should have a positive attitude to our work, concentrating on the present without worrying about outcomes. In this way, we will not be as tired and will be able to work more efficiently.

videos.title: How do we establish a positive view of life (GDD-818, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The best way to be positive is to have an interest in your work. Even if you can't have exactly what you want, you should still strive to achieve the best for your family and society.

videos.title: Is Buddhism passive (GDD-819, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: A real positive attitude is to create infinite merit and virtue with our limited life.

videos.title: How do we cultivate blessings (GDD-820, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Benefiting others is the best way of benefiting yourself. Cultivate your blessings by cherishing your blessings, giving to others, and sharing the benefits between yourself and others.

videos.title: The importance of benefiting others (GDD-821, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: You can only begin to purify your own mind by first thinking of benefiting others. Only by dissolving your sense of self can you achieve wisdom and liberation from vexation.

videos.title: How do we turn sacrifice into giving (GDD-824, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Treating everyone as a bodhisattva is the right attitude to create the mind of giving.

videos.title: The meaning of repentance and its difference to shame (GDD-801, Master Sheng-yen)
videos.description: Repentance is about resolving to take responsibility for our misdeeds, improving ourselves and making redress. It enables us to accept our difficulties with inner peace rather than blame others.

videos.title: What are the effects of being unrepentant (GDD-802, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If we don't repent but keep walking the path of darkness, we get caught in a vicious cycle of our actions and their bitter consequences. Once we repent, we can break out of darkness into the light.

videos.title: How can we give rise to a repentant mind (GDD-803, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If e regularly examine ourselves, we'll illuminate all our faults, past and present, and recognize ourselves as ordinary people. We'll then constantly give rise to a repentant mind and truly reform.

videos.title: Other ideas that fall under wrong views  (GDD-810, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: W e should replace our wrong views with right knowledge and views, the view of emptiness, which teaches us not to cling to the two extreme wrong views of eternalism and nihilism.

videos.title: Spiritual consciousness and karmic force (GDD-809, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Past, present and future are constantly exerting their influence on us. However, we focus on every single present moment to develop our infinite merit and virtue for the future.

videos.title: How can we eradicate nihilistic views (GDD-808, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We must cultivate a belief in karma and the infinite transformation through which it carries our spiritual consciousness from one life to another to eliminate the influence of the eternalistic view.

videos.title: The impact of the nihilistic view on society and people's minds (GDD-807, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: To eradicate nihilistic views, we should contemplate the purpose of our existence in the world and do good deeds to build up merit for our future lives.

videos.title: The cause of the nihilistic view and its range (GDD-806, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Denying cause and effect removes an important basis for moral behavior and damages both individuals and society.

videos.title: The cause of eternalistic views and their range (GDD-805, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: An eternalistic view makes one tend to become overly optimistic. One can have optimism and faith, but should not fall into eternalism.

videos.title: What are wrong views (GDD-804, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhist doctrine of karma is a law of responsibility: you reap what you've sown. People who don't believe in this may act wrongly based on wrong views.

videos.title: Will knowledge itself become an obstacle to learning (GDD-813, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: There is no ultimate  truth in the world. Do not let what you've known become to obstacle to learning, nor stop learning because you're afraid of the obstacle of knowledge.

videos.title: The cause of obstacle of knowledge and views and its effect on us  (GDD-812, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Only when we let go of our pertinacity can we realize what the view of emptiness is.

videos.title: The view of emptiness and the middle way (GDD-811, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Emptiness is existence, and vice versa. We should not have attachment to either emptiness or existence.

videos.title: The relationship between knowledge and practice (GDD-814, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Action speaks louder than words.

videos.title: Compassion as an essential element in purifying the mind (GDD-815, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Compassion is the best prescription to purify our minds.

videos.title: Where does one go after death (I) (GDD-776, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: People accomplished in spiritual practice may foresee their hour of death, and die in a free and easy manner. With the help of the science of death, we can at least live and die with dignity.

videos.title: Where does one go after death(II)--the Buddhist view (GDD-777, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
Which of ten realms we go to after death depends on our bodily, verbal, and mental 
actions in this life. We should fear causes rather than consequences, and turn away from darkness towards brightness.

videos.title: How to deliver the dead effectively (GDD-778, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We can more effectively help the dead attain a better rebirth while they're still in the intermediate existence. This can be achieved by doing good works on their behalf, or helping them with the Dharma.

videos.title: Who can best deliver our loved one who passed away (GDD-779, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Deliverance of the dead is most effective if their loved ones recite sutras and perform meritorious acts for them. To gain a better rebirth, the most reliable way is to practice Buddhism while we're alive.

videos.title: The law of karma and people's destinies (GDD-780, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
The law of karma offers a reasonable explanation for people's different destines. Believing this allows us to maintain equilibrium in our lives, as we know we always reap 
what we sow.

videos.title: Can wicked people be reborn in the Western Pure Land (GDD-781, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
Our last thoughts before death affect where we go thereafter. So rather than upsetting the 



dying by crying, we should recite the Buddha's name and guide them with the Dharma.

With virtuous thoughts right before death, it is possible for a wicked person to be reborn 
in the Western Pure Land. After achieving the state of liberation there, he comes back 
to this world again to repay his debts, which is called fulfilling vows, by helping deliver 
others.

videos.title: Samsara--Is it possible to revisit one's past lives (GDD-782, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
We ordinary people are subject to the cycle of life and death. But the dreamscapes 
obtained by hypnotism aren't necessarily from your past lives. It is more important to 
understand that where we'll be reborn depends mainly on the karma we've created, and 
we can also determine where we'll take rebirth by making vows.

videos.title: Low self-esteem versus modesty (GDD-783, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
Knowing everyone has potential and limits, we should be self-confident and modest, 
rather than feel inferior or proud. To help children develop self-confidence, we should 
praise and encourage them more.

videos.title: The effect of low self-esteem on us and how to eliminate it (GDD-784, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Appropriate encouragement and praise make children confident and willing to try hard, while scolding, insults, and disdain usually result in their low self-esteem.

videos.title: How to help those with low self-esteem overcome it (GDD-785, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In dealing with people with low self-esteem, encouraging and praising them through compassion is the best way to eliminate their feelings of inferiority.

videos.title: What is the Buddhist perspective on vanity (GDD-786, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: To put up a front, vain people chase things they have no use for or can't afford, affecting themselves and harming others. It's more practical and beneficial to develop wisdom and character.

videos.title: How to overcome vanity (GDD-787, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: All at sea and without goals, lazy people just want to get by day to day, idling away their lives. They miss the chance of uplifting themselves, and tend to sink spiritually.

videos.title: The vexations and problems caused by laziness (GDD-788, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: All at sea and without goals, lazy people just want to get by day to day, idling away their lives. They miss the chance of uplifting themselves, and tend to sink spiritually.

videos.title: How can we root out laziness (GDD-789, Master Shsegn-Yen)
videos.description: While having a wide vision, we should put our hand to the plow, solidly going about daily tasks. Cherishing the fleeting human life and making vows will spur us to take action quickly.

videos.title: Sloppiness and its effect on us (GDD-790, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Sloppy people spend their lives aimlessly, without ideas of their own or a regular lifestyle. They contrast pitifully with people who strive toward their goals with adaptability.

videos.title: How to overcome sloppiness (GDD-792, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We can overcome sloppiness by setting a goal in life and cultivating interests. A regular group life will also help.

videos.title: What is self-indulgence (GDD-793, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: By respecting ourselves, reflecting often on our actions, and living a regular life, we can avoid becoming self-indulgent.

videos.title: Are occasional minor transgressions harmless (GDD-794, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should deport ourselves with dignity rather than laxity so other people won't find us a nuisance. But acting occasionally in a lax but humorous way is fine as it will draw people closer to us.

videos.title: Slyness and its effect on us (GDD-795, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If we often use slyness for the purpose of self-protection, we'll end up losing out because people will discover we are untrustworthy and therefore keep us at arm's length.

videos.title: How does slyness relate to lies and falsehoods (GDD-796, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Try to handle things with savvy and sincerity, rather than resorting to slyness. That is the best policy in interacting with people.

videos.title: Pretence and its effect on us (GDD-797, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The frequent experience of shame keeps us on the path of progress, and prevents us from failing behind even further.

videos.title: The effect of shame on society and individuals (GDD-800, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Real shame requires both recognition and action or else it's false and useless.

videos.title: What is false speech (GDD-758, MasterSheng-Yen)
How can we be free from fear (GDD-757, MasterSheng-Yen) (2)
The effect of fear on us (GDD-756, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Fear makes your mind tense; it makes your body tense, it makes your nerves tense and blocks up your brain. Suspicions create imaginary fears. The fear is all in the mind. Only when the mind is afraid do you see things as scary. Once you let go of the fear, and just do it, going with the flow and adjusting to the course it takes, then there's no problem.

videos.title: What is fear and how is it caused (GDD-755, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Everyone of us more or less feels fear. First of all, everybody is afraid of dying, while some fear loneliness. Fear has something to do with a feeling of insecurity about our life. Whatever it is you are afraid of it will probably happen. So instead of having fear we should learn to deal with problems more calmly. If we can free ourselves from fear, things will improve greatly.

videos.title: How to eliminate the ingrained habit of doubt (GDD-752, Master Sheng-Yen)
Is it human nature to be skeptical (GDD-751, Master Sheng-Yen)
Does promoting oneself or boasting count as false speech  (GDD-759, Master Sheng-Yen)
Is it okay to tell white lies (GDD-761, Master Sheng-Yen)
How divisive speech come about (GDD-762, Master Sheng-Yen)
Avoid using slander, flattery, or other inappropriate speech (GDD-763, Master Sheng-Yen)
What is abusive speech (GDD-764, Master Sheng-Yen)
How are bad speech habits related to our minds (GDD-765, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Bad speech habits hurt others and cause many interpersonal problems. To improve, we should examine ourselves and repent regularly, make spiritual friends, and use speech that brings warmth and harmony.

videos.title: What are the causes of jealousy (GDD-766, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Jealously is of no avail, bring us only pain and makes us unpopular. Instead, it does us good to commend your betters with a breath of mind, and develop yourself to catch up with them.

videos.title: How to get rid of jealousy (GDD-767,Master Sheng-Yen)
The causes of resentment and its effects on us (GDD-768, Master Sheng-Yen)
How to overcome the resentment against loved ones (GDD-769, Master Sheng-Yen)
Attachment versus will power  (GDD-770, Master Sheng-Yen)
Is it adhering to our principles or just being attached (GDD-771, Master Sheng-Yen)
Don't be attached to anything, even to the Dharma (GDD-772, Master Sheng-Yen)
How to let go of our attachment (GDD-773, Master Sheng-Yen)
How to break our attachment to life and death (GDD-774, Master Sheng-Yen)
How to be free of the fear of death (GDD-775, Master Sheng-Yen)
What is the Buddha's wisdom (II) (GDD-728, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Everyone has the inherent capacity for wisdom that is the same as the Buddha's, but when we have affliction, wisdom disappears. The Buddha's wisdom transcends objectivity and subjectivity. By regarding every sentient being as equal, the Buddha's wisdom, the wisdom of no-self, completely lets go of self and other—no you, no me, no him, no her—and sees all things in a detached, un-involved way.

videos.title: Teachings in the sutras for cultivating the mind  (GDD-726, Master Sheng-Yen)
How to eliminate our afflictions (GDD-729, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If we want to reduce our afflictions, then we should reduce our attachments and entanglements, which are our worries about gain or loss, or ideas about self or other, right or wrong, benefit or harm. Also, by changing our way we look at our life and the world, our afflictions will naturally be reduced. By having right mindfulness at all times, wandering thoughts will have no place to step in

videos.title: How to overcome the craving for power (GDD-736, Master Sheng-Yen)
Wandering thoughts and fundamental vexations (GDD-730, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The 6 fundamental vexations - craving, aversion, delusion, arrogance, doubt, and wrong views-obstruct our wisdom, and hurt ourselves and others. Greedy people always crave more, as a result, are afflicted.

videos.title: Craving--Needs and Wants (GDD-731, Master Sheng-Yen)
Craving--Needs and Wants (GDD-732, Master Sheng-Yen)
Practice giving to overcome the craving for material gains (GDD-734, Master Sheng-Yen)
How to overcome the craving for fame and status (GDD-735, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: To accumulate more and more wealth just to satisfy our own desire to become rich someday is a sign of greed. But if we're saving up money for an appropriate purpose, then that's very good. With the same action, if you act out of a different attitude, you may get different results. We may get rich and famous as a result of causes and conditions, but we shouldn't identify ourselves with them, for they are illusory and unsubstantial.

videos.title: What harm does stinginess do to us (GDD-737, Master Sheng-Yen)
Share generously, without being stingy or wasteful (GDD-738, Master Sheng-Yen)
Is simple living a form of stinginess (GDD-739, Master Sheng-Yen)
What is aversion and and how does it impact us (GDD-740, Master Sheng-Yen)
How do we overcome aversion (GDD-741, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Aversion and compassion are opposites. If we can develop a mind of love then aversion will naturally wane. Emotions are not to be controlled; they are to be channeled. When aversion rises and it's impossible to produce compassion or to transform it into compassion, by reciting the Buddha's name or a mantra we can redirect our emotion or divert our aversion to the recitation, thereby reducing our hatred. As a more active way we should develop a mind of love and compassion in interacting with people and things, by reviewing and reflecting our bodily, verbal, and mental actions at all time.

videos.title: The mental and physical problems caused by aversion (EQ)(GDD-742, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We need to elevate our moods, transforming them into sentiments by seeking to improve our low grade, unruly moods, transforming them into something better—from negative to positive and from positive to ever better states. We should develop a compassionate mind instead of a mind of opposition, enmity, and competition, thereby eliminating our hatred. Without hatred there are no irreconcilable foes. Since there are no enemies, there is no object for our hatred, then your mind will be peaceful, tranquil, and happy.

videos.title: What is ignorance  (GDD-743, Master Sheng-Yen)
The mental and physical problems caused by ignorance (GDD-744 Master  Sheng-Yen)
How to transcend the vexations caused by ignorance (GDD-745, Master Sheng-Yen)
Arrogance and its many forms (GDD-746, Master Sheng-Yen)
Overcome arrogance with humility and respect (GDD-748, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should apply humility, modesty, and respect as the antidotes to arrogance. Humility and respect are the keys to good interpersonal relationships. When we interact with people we should think that our success is the result of the coming together of causes and conditions, instead of focusing only on ourselves. We should take the task we do seriously and show respect or even appreciation to everyone involved. By doing so we won't be proud of ourselves.

videos.title: More ways to overcome our arrogance (GDD-749, Master Sheng-Yen)
Doubt and its many forms (GDD-750, Master Sheng-Yen)
Sutras and theories that emphasize the mind (GDD-725, Master Sheng-yen)
Finding a balance between the spiritual and the material  (GDD-724, Master Sheng-Yen)
Why are books about spirituality so popular today  (GDD-723, Master Sheng-Yen)
Causes and conditions are not mere coincidence  (GDD-722, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Many people confuse causes and conditions with coincidence, or waiting passively. Some even use the lack of causes and conditions as an excuse to justify their laziness. Don't wait passively for causes and conditions; instead, try to bring them about. Nevertheless, once you've tried all you can but the plans you thought to be failure-proof just won't materialize, it's also the work of causes and conditions.

videos.title: Making a vow differs from swearing an oath  (GDD-721, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The pledges that ordinary people make can be bitter, malicious, or well-intentioned. If you are a practitioner of Mahayana Buddhism and aspire to emulate the spirit of the Buddha and bodhisattvas, you should take the Four Great Vows: vowing to deliver all sentient beings; vowing to cut off all afflictions; vowing to learn all Dharma methods; and vowing to attain supreme Buddhahood. The Four Great Vows are the basics for Buddhists, and all of them aim at delivering sentient beings. In order to save them, we should first eliminate our own afflictions.

videos.title: What is the best way to keep healthy and vigorous (GDD-720, Master Sheng-Yen)
Purifying society by helping people purify their minds (GDD-719, Master Sheng-Yen)
Using the Dharma to cease suffering and attain happiness (GDD-718, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The purpose of practicing Buddhism is to help people free self from suffering and attain happiness. The pursuit of material happiness inevitably traps us in the cycle of suffering. A moderate lifestyle, non-attached spiritual practice, and helping others will bring us peace and spiritual bliss.

videos.title: The young novice who saved the ants prolonged his life (GDD-717, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Working to help sentient beings with a compassionate heart makes us feel joyful and fulfilled, and this brings with it a healthy body and mind. Good works also serve to improve our karma.

videos.title: The Buddhist view on leadership (GDD-716, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: A natural leader is respected, supported, and followed. People obey him not because he has power, but because he helps others, leads the group well, brings people together for a common cause, and inspires a divided group to join hands and work towards it. He has good communication and interpersonal skills, is able to move and influence others, identifies with and respects others, and is able to convince and lead others to work towards the same goal. This kind of leader is a democratic leader.

videos.title: What can we do to be speedy but not hurried (GDD-715, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Whatever we do, we must prioritize according to its importance and urgency. Between immediate and long-term projects, work on the immediate one first. Tackle the pressing, manageable, and more important issues first, and then move on to others. Our goal can be grand and ambitious, but when we set off to work on it we should start with the immediate and the manageable. Never attempt to do everything at the same time. We must go step by step, finishing tasks one by one. Things should be arranged, prioritized, and planned. By following these guidelines, we won't feel impatient or anxious, and can also speed up the completion of our work.

videos.title: What is the study of life and death about (GDD-714, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism was created to deal with the issue of life and death. It teaches us to shoulder responsibilities while alive, and be prepared to face death at any moment, so we can die with peace, joy, and dignity and free of all cares and attachments.

videos.title: How does international Buddhist conferences influence Buddhism (GDD-713, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Many Taiwanese see Buddhism as folk belief. We hold international conferences to broaden their perspective, showing them that it is an international religion with a rich cultural heritage for all humanity.

videos.title: What does the Sutra Opening verse mean (GDD-712, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Dharma is so wonderful, yet few know about it. By reciting the Sutra Opening verse, we cherish the rare opportunity to encounter the Dharma, without which true wisdom and liberation is impossible.

videos.title: How to eliminate anxiety and fear (GDD-711, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We often suffer from fear and anxiety due to lack of confidence. If we can strive to understand ourselves and our surroundings, and be prepared in advance, there is no need to fear. Fear won't help at all.

videos.title: The meaning of Dharma drum, Dharma rain, and Dharma conch (GDD-710, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Using analogies like Dharma drum or rain makes it easier to strike a chord in people's hearts, creating in their minds vivid images of how the Dharma is inspiring, soothing, etc., and thus conveying difficult ideas.

videos.title: Imbuing the students with the Dharma is a way of education  (GDD-709, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We'll have faith in Buddhism if we look up to it as something useful. Then come understanding, practice and realization. For children, fables and stories are the best means to establish the foundations of faith.

videos.title: How to put out the mental fire when in anger  (GDD-708, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Anger, expressed or repressed, harms yourself and others. It can be resolved through an understanding of the law of karma or through practices like breath counting and reciting the Buddha's name.

videos.title: Letting go differs from giving up and abandoning hope  (GDD-707, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: By "letting go", we mean casting off our attachments, not "giving up". We should face up to our problems, do our best to deal with them, then irrespective of success or failure, just let them go.

videos.title: How does spiritual practice help improve our EQ (GDD-706, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Meditation is a wonderful way to raise our EQ. It harmonizes our body, breath, and mind so we can be physically relaxed and at ease and emotionally stable and happy.

videos.title: What can we do to be a good leader  (GDD-705, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The best leadership is to lead by being led-respect your subordinates and their opinions, trust their ability, and be accommodating. This will make you a popular leader, and get things done harmoniously.

videos.title: The straightforward mind differs from speaking straightforwardly  (GDD-704, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Speaking with the "Straightforward mind" doesn't refer to speak honesty and it is not any kind of generalized, blunt, or ignorant straightforwardness. It means that you speak without guile, trickery, cajoling, or beating around the bush. If you have few vexations and distorted views, you have a straightforward mind. Like a mirror, empty but reflecting all, you'll be wise and free of self-centeredness, and give others guidance which would benefit them fundamentally and lastingly.

videos.title: The four inducements intermingling (GDD-703, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Unaware of the benefit of the Dharma, people keep distant from it. To win them over to the Dharma, we should join their activities, tactfully intermingling with them, and then we slowly transform them into disciples of the Three Jewels.

videos.title: The four inducements acting beneficially (GDD-702, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Everybody can, more or less, reach out to help others with the Dharma or anything beneficial. People whom we benefit will follow in our footsteps. That's how we act beneficially to induce people to the Dharma.

videos.title: The four inducements speaking lovingly (GDD-701, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If we practice speaking lovingly with true compassion and concern, our words, gestures, and expressions will all be affable and kind, warming people's hearts and naturally inducing them to follow the Dharma.

videos.title: The four inducements giving (GDD-700, Master Sheng-yen)
videos.description: When giving, we can comfort and encourage the recipients with the Dharma, so that they will understand its true benefits and be ready to help others in turn. This is a good way of forming karmic affinities and to win people over to Buddhism.

videos.title: The bodhisattvas and doctors won't take on sentient beings' karma (GDD-696, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: When seriously ill, leave your illness to the doctors and your fate to the Buddha. Single-minded faith will bring you peace and infinite hope, and free you from fear and worry, giving you a better chance to improve.

videos.title: Will the doctors take on the patients' karmic retributions  (GDD-697, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Always seek medical treatment for your illnesses. For unidentified diseases, probably causes by karmic hindrances, magical or spiritual therapy may help, but cause more problems. It's better to recite the Buddha's name.

videos.title: The difference between vexations and ingrained habits  (GDD-698, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Ingrained habit is not the same as vexation, though it arises from vexation. The ingrained habits we show in our behavior can disgust people without our knowing it. While not all habits are bad, we should remind ourselves not to allow them to cause annoyance to others. However, those who have vexations hurt themselves and can hurt others.

videos.title: How to cultivate an expansive mind (GDD-699, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Life is difficult for small-minded people as they're full of suspicion, fear, and grudges. We can cultivate an expansive mind if we take things with equanimity, think positively, and be tolerance, considerate and compassionate.

videos.title: The Buddhist view on human cloning (GDD-695, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: For Buddhists, cloning can be regarded as just another type of birth, through which a spiritual entity can take rebirth. It is therefore acceptable as long as the related ethical problems are well taken care of.

videos.title: The true meaning of confidence and the ways to build it (GDD-694, Master Sheng-Yen)
Show warm-hearted concern appropriately instead of meddling (GDD-693, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Truly concerned about others, warm-hearted people selflessly do their best to help without thought for consequences. Meddlesome people simply want to show off, and usually create trouble rather than solve problems.

videos.title: The positive side of knowing contentment  (GDD-692, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "Knowing contentment" is not about passively waiting for things to happen, but applying yourself diligently. It means that after trying your best, you feel fulfilled and accept the outcome with equanimity.

videos.title: What to do when big love and small love come into conflict (GDD-691, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Small, selfish love can bring us afflictions and vexations. Bigger but conditional love is not good enough. Truly big, unconditional lover covers all creatures and treats friend and foe equally, thus benefiting our loved ones as well. We should deal with conflicts and contradictions between big love and small love with wisdom, rather than always respond in the same way.

videos.title: Where exactly is the Western Pure Land (GDD-690, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In Buddhist cosmology, there are countless Buddha worlds, or galaxies, either pure or full of afflictions. People reborn in pure lands can be free of afflictions, but to attain Buddhahood, they must come back to the Saha world to deliver sentient beings.

videos.title: What is the proper attitude when taking up Buddhism (GDD-688, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: It is normal for people to take up Buddhism for worldly needs and expectations. But it would be better if they can gradually uplift their faith to the level of cultivating the mind and emulating the bodhisattva spirit.

videos.title: The difference between a sense of inferiority and shame (GDD-687, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Shame is totally different from feelings of inferiority. People with a sense of shame are ready to admit mistakes and improve themselves. Those with feelings of inferiority have no confidence and cover up their weaknesses, so they lose the chance to develop themselves and have no chance to contribute to and serve others.

videos.title: How to remain calm and unaffected in adversities (GDD-686, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Dharma teaches that all things are impermanent, emptiness and devoid of self because they are dependently originated. Understanding this will help us strive for improvement, and remain calm and happy in all situations.

videos.title: The moral of the story of the poor son (GDD-684, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: A chapter in the Lotus Sutra tells the parable of a poor beggar. The story implies that sentient beings, unaware that they have the precious Buddha-nature within, refuse to follow the Dharma and don't believe they can achieve Buddhahood. They must be guided slowly and brought around, just like the beggar son who turned into the heir of a rich man.

videos.title: The Buddhist view on the non-decaying bodies of practitioners (GDD-683, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In the Buddhist tradition, burial is not common and many eminent masters were cremated after they passed away. There are monks who are known while alive to be highly accomplished and left non-decaying bodies, which did raise faith in the general public. However, we should respect and admire all those practitioners who serve as living examples by exemplary behavior, no matter they have left non-decaying bodies or not.

videos.title: What are the "four reliances" (GDD-682, Master sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The four reliances are 1) relying on the teaching, not on any person; 2)relying on intuitive wisdom, not on intellectual understanding; 3)relying on the true meaning, not on the words; 4) relying on the ultimate teaching, not expedient teaching. They are the four principles for Buddhists to follow to determine whether a given teaching is the genuine Buddhadharma, or your belief is correct.

videos.title: How should educators deal with disobedient students  (GDD-681, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Only after spending more time with difficult students and gaining an understanding of their dispositions can a teacher decide how best to deal with them. Neither encouragement nor harsh words will work every time.

videos.title: Why do people forget everything in past lives (GDD-680, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We don't need to remember past lives, as it has no benefits in the present life and may simply stir up trouble. It's enough to believe in the law of karma, and then use the Dharma to improve yourself.

videos.title: Why is the Three Jewels the true refuge (GDD-679, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In Buddhism, taking refuge in the Three Jewels is an eternal vow to improve oneself and deliver all beings through the Dharma, which is different from finding shelter under the power of a supreme deity in other religions.

videos.title: First catch them on the hook of desire, then help them attain wisdom (GDD-678, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should first use the hook of desire to motivate people who are unaware of the significance and benefits of Buddhism, and then skillfully guide them onto the path of wisdom and liberation.

videos.title: How to make good use of our empathy for others (GDD-677, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: With empathy, we put ourselves in others' shoes instead of caring only about ourselves. Compassion goes one step further, putting others before ourselves, and trying to fulfill needs they might not even know exist.

videos.title: What is the pure land on earth like (GDD-689, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The original spirit of Buddhism centered on solving human problems and helping people generate compassion and wisdom from within, and thus bring harmony, happiness, peace, and the spirit of mutual assistance to the world.  Promoting a pure land on earth is a way to revive this ideal by helping humanity purify the mind and improve life in the real world.

videos.title: What do the titles such as"exalted master"mean (GDD-675, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "Exalted master" is the same as a "vajra master" in Tantric Buddhism, who is an enlightened Mahayana practitioner having attained indestructible, unshakable and non-regressing realization, and is able to transmit the Dharma. Many practitioners declare themselves to be "exalted masters", but such titles have no validity and are not accepted by the traditional lineages of esoteric Buddhism. True titles can only be acquired through transmission from a master in the orthodox lineages.

videos.title: What is the Buddhist view on Euthanasia (GDD-672, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Human life, a precious tool for spiritual practice, should be cherished. But if the patient and doctor agree, we should allow nature to take its course in the face of death rather than seek to prolong life artificially.

videos.title: Seek the Dharma in the dusty world (GDD-671, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism is not either pessimistic or renunciatory. The Mahayana spirit is to be actively engaged in the world but remain undefiled by it. A true practitioner shows compassion for others rather than sees their faults, and helps them improve through the Dharma.

videos.title: How to apply the wisdom of adapting to conditions (GDD-670, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Adapting to conditions is not an absence of principles, or being hypocritical. Adapting to conditions is about grasping and fostering causes and conditions to win people over to the Dharma and help them grow spiritually, while letting it be when the circumstances are simply not right.

videos.title: The great variety of Dharma approaches (GDD-669, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Dharma is offered to everyone equally so we may draw on it according to our capacity and inclination. While there are many different approaches for bodhisattvas and sentient beings adopt different methods of practice, all lead to Buddhahood.

videos.title: Ward off covetousness with self-discipline to build a pure society (GDD-668, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The more we have, the more we want. But the more we want the more vexations we will have. A spirit of giving and compassion may not only influence others to do good, but also bring us inner peace. As a Buddhist or a practitioner who emulates the bodhisattva spirit, we shall always have hope for this world.

videos.title: The causes and conditions that exist between twins (GDD-667, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: From a Buddhist perspective, the formation of twins reflects close relationships and similar karma in former lives, and is easily explained in terms of the doctrine of causes and conditions.

videos.title: How to treat other religions and avoid conflicts (GDD-666, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism is a religion of tolerance. While advocating that we change from within instead of relying on external gods, it believes all religions that encourage ethical conduct have a role to play in society.

videos.title: What is the function of the literary forms in the sutras (GDD-664, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Literary and artistic expressions in the sutras have a wide appeal and are an expedient means of teaching and spreading the Dharma.

videos.title: Prayer beads and Buddha images aren't decorations or accessories  (GDD-665, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We should not use Buddha images and prayer beads as decorations or accessories, for these are tools of spiritual practice and should be treated with respect.

videos.title: What is hindrance by the known (GDD-663, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "The known" refers to one's preconceived ideas. "Hindrance by the known" is basically acquired through experience or learned from books. However, our subjective ideas, discriminations, and experiences don't reveal the truth. They give rise to attachment, which makes us despise different opinions, and hinders us from attaining true insight.

videos.title: Is an animal's spiritual capacity the same as Buddha-nature (GDD-662, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
An animal's spiritual capacity means that it is like human beings in having judgment and memory. Buddhists treat all creatures compassionately, whether they're clever or not.
We believe that all sentient beings have Buddha-nature, and will understand the Dharma at certain time and eventually achieve Buddhahood.

videos.title: How does Buddhism view the cautionary phrases (GDD-661, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: There are cautionary phrases in Chinese that "deities are just three feet above us" or "deities watch our every action." Such belief in supervisory deities is good, as it encourages moral behavior and acts as a kind of ethical safeguard. Buddhists take a more self-reliant attitude, believing our minds keep track of all our deeds, and we must bear the consequences of our actions.

videos.title: How to cultivate compassion to become wisely compassionate (GDD-660, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Compassion is both nature and nurture. We are all born with some degree of compassion, which should be tempered with reason, and nurtured like a seedling so it won't wither. And it will grow if we practice by looking inward, and reducing our vexations.

videos.title: What does convergence of many conditions mean (GDD-659, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: When many conditions join a certain cause, something will be accomplished. So knowing that nothing happens independently of various conditions, we will be modest about our achievements and attribute them to everyone's help. This breadth of mind is an essential part of spiritual cultivation.

videos.title: The pride of arhats differs from that of ordinary people (GDD-658, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The pride of ordinary people is self-importance, conceit and arrogance, while the pride of arhats is superior spiritual attainment. It is the unshakable confidence in what they've realized from spiritual practice, that they have achieved the ultimate goal of practice. Such pride is a form of attachment and prevents them from taking the further step toward attaining Buddhahood.

videos.title: How to be the companions of non-regressive bodhisattvas (GDD-657, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The three levels of non-regression are non-regression of faith, position, and practice. Renew your vows daily and stay with a group of good practitioners who can encourage you wisely. This way you won't falter or regress on the Buddhist path when your karma makes your life too difficult or too easy.

videos.title: How did the nine-grade lotus in the pure land come about (GDD-656, Master sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The 9-grade lotus in the Western Pure Land is formed by different level of merit. Once reborn there, we can practice, without cares and disruption, until we become non-regression sages.

videos.title: How to transcend the three realms of samsara, a burning house  (GDD-655, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: We seek the happiness of the three realms unaware that it's a burning house where the calamities of samsara can descend any time. But it's a cool, pure land for bodhisattvas who are free from vexations.

videos.title: Practice honestly, without an opportunistic attitude (GDD-654, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Haste makes waste. Craving for quick spiritual attainment will only do you harm. We'll truly benefit only when we practice honestly to reduce our vexations and enhance our compassion.

videos.title: How does Buddhism view prophecy and divination (GDD-653, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In spite of his spiritual powers, the Buddha rarely makes prophecies. Unlike varieties of divination, his prophecies are just a roadmap showing the natural course of one's spiritual development.

videos.title: Can vegetarians eat royal jelly, cod-liver oil, and the like (GDD-652, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhists promote vegetarianism not for health reasons but out of compassion for sentient beings. If you have health concerns, a balanced vegetarian diet can still provide essential nutrients.

videos.title: Do we practice Buddhism to seek self liberation or to deliver ... (GDD-651, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: A person who takes up Buddhism with selfish motives will become compassionate and less self-centered after experiencing the Dharma. Only with an altruistic spirit can one attain arhatship and achieve liberation.

videos.title: Getting prepared beforehand by practicing in daily life  (GDD-650, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If one gets prepared beforehand by becoming well established in faith, vows, and practice, one can be reborn in the pure land no matter when one dies. Don't just count on recitation at the hour of death.

videos.title: How can a cancer patient and his family adapt mentally (GDD-649, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Cancer patients have enough time to turn to religion to get ready mentally. With the positive attitude that death is just a transition to a new stage of life, they'll feel that to live or to die is all fine.

videos.title: Why do monastics take on many duties to help people (GDD-648, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Contrary to the stereotyped view of monastics as idle escapists, most of them are very active and vigorous in their efforts to benefit society, where so many people are in need of the help of Buddhism.

videos.title: How to eliminate the three hindrances (GDD-647, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Dharma is beneficial and important to our life, but many are unable to accept it or practice well due to the hindrances of afflictions, work, or karmic retributions. We should strive to overcome them. Only after removing these obstacles can one practice smoothly.

videos.title: Can those who follow false teachers attain spiritual realization  (GDD-646, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Many spiritual seekers fall prey to false teacher. A true teacher is an ethical person who keeps the precepts and can teach the views and methods for you to improve spiritually through your own practice and good works. Those who make offerings to eminent teachers but do not engage in spiritual practice themselves will only get karmic rewards, but won't attain liberation.

videos.title: The causality spanning past, present and future lives is not fatalism (GDD-645, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhists believe that all beings continuously undergo death and rebirth and this present life is just one step in the course of our limitless lives. The doctrine of karma is neither determinism nor fatalism, as causes must be joined by conditions to lead to effects. Know this helps us accept sufferings peacefully, and full of hope, work hard for a better present and future.

videos.title: One's true mind and inherent nature--How to take refuge in oneself  (GDD-644, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description:
Our true mind is the pure mind of wisdom free of defilements. Our inherent nature refers to the nature of our being something common, which is also called the Buddha-nature.
By taking refuge in our inner Buddha-nature and letting go of our guest mind, which is subject to vexations, we can see our true mind, which is beyond defilement but functions as wisdom. To take refuge in oneself, one must first be able to realize the nature of his mind by the guidance of the Three Jewels.

videos.title: Pithy words are profound--Chan is not established on words (GDD-643, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: That "Chan is not established on words or letters" simply means that people should not rely on words for their understanding of the Dharma. Though Chan is beyond words, Chan masters can use a simple remark as a powerful tool to turn a disciple's mind inwards, or even help him break through the final barriers to enlightenment.

videos.title: The koan of  polishing a brick can't turn it into a mirror (GDD-642, MasterSheng-Yen)
videos.description: Chan Master Huairang once said, "If polishing a brick can't turn it into a mirror, how can one achieve enlightenment by sitting?" Meditation may lead to concentration, but one must know that wisdom doesn't come from sitting. It can only be brought forth from within. Peace of mind, right views, and freedom from vexation is true enlightenment.

videos.title: The blank state during Chan practice and its cause  (GDD-641, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: There are different stages of Chan practice. Being able to cultivate meditative concentration and reach the blank state is pretty good. It is a clear and concentrated state in which one feels free and at ease, having rid oneself of all wandering thoughts.

videos.title: The koan of carrying a beauty across the stream  (GDD-640, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In scriptures there is the story of Chan Master Tanshan carry a beautiful lady across a stream. Buddhism stresses proper behavior between men and women. In keeping the precepts, the central concern of Mahayana followers is whether their mind is free of impurities. Still, they interact cautiously with the other sex because emotional entanglement is easy and ruinous.

videos.title: The origin of the phrase Thus have I heard  (GDD-639, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The phrase "Thus have I heard" at the beginning of all the sutras is a way of indicating their authenticity. Spurious scriptures with the same phrase can always be identified by their discrepant contents.

videos.title: The Buddhist view on education via environmental influence  (GDD-638, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Both good and bad environments can help our growth. First let weak people improve in a good one. When they've sufficiently mastered themselves, they can be honed in a bad one and change it for the better.

videos.title: What is merit Is it defiled or undefiled (GDD-636, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Merit means that when you do a good deed, it has a positive effect on your mind. Good deeds done for the sake of rewards result in defiled merit, which will leak away. Try to have less attachment when doing good deeds, and you will gradually be able to attain undefiled merit and awakening.

videos.title: The relationship between oneself and one's shadow (GDD-634, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Chan Master Dongshan perceived that "the reflection on the water is me, but I am not the reflection". It is the state of no-self and signlessness. The shadow or reflection is just a provisional phenomenon created by causes and conditions, but without real substance. Knowing this, one can become less attached and have fewer vexations.

videos.title: Emigration versus the treasure in one's own backyard (GDD-633, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Without sound reasons, don't emigrate to run away from difficulties, which are a fact of life wherever you go. Live intently, and you can always beat a path by tapping the "treasure in your own backyard".

videos.title: The Buddhist perspective on EQ and emotional management (GDD-632, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist teachings focus on deeply understanding the mind and regulating it with spiritual practice to keep it calm and free. They are effective ways of emotional management and EQ improvement.

videos.title: The Buddhist perspective on the doctrine of evolution (GDD-631, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Even beings in the natural world accept and support one another. So, characterized by our humanity, we help, forgive and accept each other in the midst of competition, using patience and compassion.

videos.title: How to be free from attachment, but principled  (GDD-630, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Adhering to one's principles is not the same as attachment. Adhering to our principles amidst temptations and difficulties is a positive force for improvement. Attachment is self-centered concern about fame and gain, which keeps us bogged in delusion.

videos.title: What is the true Dharma and how can we learn it (GDD-629, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: To distinguish the true Dharma from sham ones, just follow three rules: they must not depart from the precepts, and they must comply with the law of karma and explain the Dharma only with the Dharma.

videos.title: Is it proper for monastics to attend entertainment activities (GDD-628,Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Monastics should avoid places of entertainment. This not only helps them maintain their determination to seek the Path, but also prevents the laity from creating the karma of evil speech.

videos.title: The meaning and states of samadhi  (GDD-627, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In Chinese Samadhi is transliterated as "sanmei". Samadhi originally means meditative concentration, a state where that the mind and body, or the mind and the environment are one, and you no longer have scattered thoughts. But later in Mahayana and Chan, it denotes the combination of concentration and wisdom: undefiled and wise, one remains in concentration in all activities.

videos.title: What are the prerequisites for becoming a monastic (GDD-626, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Though parental consent is not imperative for a grown-up to become a monastic, it's important to talk it over with your parents so that, with their understanding, you can have peace as a monastic.

videos.title: Why should we repent? How should we repent?(GDD-63 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To repent, either to our own conscience, to the person we have done a disservice, or in public, is to express responsibilities for ourselves. By repenting on a daily basis we can gradually purify our body and mind, and therefore eliminate our karmic obstacles.

videos.title: What is the Buddhist view on art (GDD-617, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Many treasures of Buddhist art in China were created during the periods when Buddhism flourished. Only when Buddhism is highly valued by the people will Buddhist art continue to blossom.

videos.title: How does the Western Pure Land differ from the heavens  (GDD-625, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Heavenly existence is temporary and not free from samsara. Buddhists are advised to go to the eternal pure land, where they practice until they achieve liberation and return to ordinary worlds to help other beings find liberation.

videos.title: The usefulness of the regulations in Buddhist monasteries (GDD-624, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Whether monastic or secular, rules help prevent disorder and promote harmony and efficiency in a group. Proper deportment, like many monastic rules, is conducive to individual and group practice.

videos.title: Why are emiment Buddhists referred to as dragon-elephants  (GDD-623, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The qualities of a great teacher of the Dharma are represented by the lion for its awakening roar, the elephant for its perseverance, and the dragon for its ability to respond to any call for help.

videos.title: Does Buddhism talk about truth (GDD-622, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "Truth" in Buddhism refers to the absolute true principle or essence underlying all things. The laws of causality and of conditional arising are expressible mundane truths that govern our phenomenal world. Transcendental truth, the all-pervading Buddha-nature, is one with the mundane but defies words.

videos.title: Does practicing Buddhism help ensure a happy marriage  (GDD-621, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Practicing Buddhism helps ensure a happy marriage. Following the guidelines of a common faith and mutual respect, acceptance and support, couples will weather all problems and remain committed.

videos.title: Propagating the Dharma overseas (GDD-620, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Region knows no borders. In an open society with increasing international interchange Chinese Buddhism needs to be open-minded and learn from other forms of Buddhism to succeed internationally.

videos.title: Why was Buddhism accepted by Chinese (GDD-619, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Through adaptation and assimilation, Buddhism gradually became a major part of Chinese culture. Having had its ups and downs in Chinese history, it is now reviving by drawing on Western civilization.

videos.title: When did Buddhism reach its greatest glory (GDD-618, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Subtle doctrine, inner practice and a new perspective attracted many talented people who created the golden age of Buddhism during the Tang dynasty. All these are needed to revitalize Buddhism today.

videos.title: Why do some monastics practice martial arts? (GDD-0616, Master Sheng Yen)
Why is Maitreya Buddha portrayed so differently? (GDD-615, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The paunchy, smiling figure of Maitreya with his "all-embracing bag" reminds us to emulate the bodhisattva spirit: being big-hearted and compassionate, one cheerfully accepts all and gives all.

videos.title: The significance of translating Buddhist scriptures (GDD-614, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The translation of Buddhist Scriptures has over 2,000 years of history and is now more important than ever as a means of promoting the beneficial teachings of Buddhism around the world.

videos.title: What does the Dharma Drum University wish to achieve? (GDD-613, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The establishment of a liberal arts university is necessary if DDM is to foster people with the qualifications to contribute to society by helping to promote our vision of a pure land on earth.

videos.title: Is Buddhism polytheistic? (GDD-612, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhas and bodhisattvas aren't deities, but those who have attained enlightenment through cultivation and are our models. Although they take many forms, they're linked to each other in substance.

videos.title: Why does Buddhism compare our mind to an ox? (GDD-611, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The ox is an important symbol in Buddhist texts, representing both a wayward mind that needs to be disciplined and also the Buddha Vehicle, which carries all sentient beings toward supreme Buddhahood.

videos.title: What is the significance of offering pure meals? (GDD-610, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we offer pure meals for practitioners engaged in pure practice to eat at prescribed pure times, we acquire merit and create affinities in the Dharma. Many people do this to fulfill or redeem a vow.

videos.title: What is the significance of the ritual of deliverance (GDD-609, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Deliverance is primarily aimed at the living rather than the dead. But rituals for the dead can bring them merit, and on hearing the Dharma they may even be able to let go and achieve deliverance.

videos.title: What is the significance of reciting the the Buddha's name? (GDD-608, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We'll be free from fear in danger or in difficulties if we're mindful of one of the six meritorious things. Reciting the Buddha's name leads to a peaceful, virtuous life and rebirth in the pure land.

videos.title: What do the Sanskrit terms in the sutras mean  (GDD-607, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Transliteration of Sanskrit terms is sometimes used in the sutras because they can't be translated appropriately. The sutras are not hard to understand if you consult dictionaries for these terms.

videos.title: Reciting the Buddha's name verbally or mindfully (GDD-606, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To derive true benefit from reciting the Buddha's name, we should do it mindfully rather than just pronouncing it absent-mindedly. Our concentration will increase with practice until we achieve samadhi.

videos.title: Who should Buddhists today look to as their teacher (GGD-605, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhists take refuge in the Three Jewels, regarding this as their teacher. Though the Buddha has long passed away, if we take the Dharma and the precepts he taught as our teacher, then it is as if the Buddha were still with us, guiding us in leading a grounded, peaceful life.

videos.title: How does western society view orthodox Buddhism  (GGD-604, Master Sheng Yen)
Buddhist view on world records (GDD-603, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: While competition can help a few people become outstanding, Buddhism reaches out to everyone, urging them to walk an ordinary path, steadily and continuously, to enlightenment, each at their own pace.

videos.title: How should parents lay the foundation for their children's education (GDD-601, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Even animals educate their young. Parents should spend time with their children, guide them with loving care, and set a good example for them, so that they grow up to be wise, compassionate, and worthy.

videos.title: How does the nobility of our character relate to the quality of our social customs? (GDD-576,)
videos.description: Especially in the new century and new era, new ideas are difficult for us to adapt to. Everyone only cares about their own interest, expansion, development, protection, and security; everyone thinks very little of others. So on the one hand, society seems prosperous with everyone striving to invent, create, and work hard. On the other hand, quite a number of people also try to find the loopholes in the law, and take advantage of the gray area between legal and illegal. To restore peace and safety to society, everyone should rely on their own efforts to make a living, which is the best

videos.title: How, with the pressure of intense competition, we can properly protect our conscience  (GDD-577)
videos.description: Packaging may be able to make something look valuable, stylish and elegant, but most of the time it is mere vanity and deception; we not only deceive ourselves but also allow ourselves to be deceived. The packaged image is always short-lived; it is better to be honest and true. We don't need too much grooming, but must keep our appearance simple, tidy, and neat. We must also be well grounded and honest.

videos.title: Putting "Protecting the Spiritual Environment" into practice (GDD-578, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Environmental protection means the sanitation of the environment, that is, keeping our living conditions healthy, clean, and hygienic, and protecting nature from being destroyed. The Protection of the Spiritual Environment movement promoted by Dharma Drum Mountain is closely related to the protection of our living and natural environments; its essence lies in being aware of our mind, knowing if our mind is pure or contaminated, knowing if there are afflicted, impure thoughts in our mind.

videos.title: Why does Ch'an have such a huge body of collected sayings (GDD-579, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Not depending on words and letters" does not conflict with the use of language. It teaches us not to be attached to words, not to take a remark out of context, and not to cling to unilateral statements, or the words of one single person. At a deeper level, it means that the real truth cannot be expressed in words; whatever is described and explained in words and symbols is not the real truth. The purpose of "not depending on words and letters" is to encourage people to use their own mind and their own efforts to experience and practice Chan themselves.

videos.title: What does "nonconceptual wisdom" mean? (GDD-580, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Sixth Patriarch Huineng once said, "The lowest class have supreme wisdom, and the highest class have non-conceptual wisdom." It means that all living beings have the Buddha-nature, the potential to attain Buddhahood, and the inborn capacity to develop the supreme wisdom of a Buddha. As long as we strive to develop it, we will be able to manifest this kind of wisdom. People of great wisdom are already rid of self-centeredness and not attached to their own wisdom, and so have non-conceptual wisdom.

videos.title: The meaning of the alms-begging practice(GDD-581, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Begging for alms forms an affinity. At first you had no affinity with the monks. If they beg alms from you and you give them food, medicines, or other essential items, then you are related to each other. On the other hand, by receiving alms and giving the Dharma in return, a monk forms an affinity with lay people. By sincerely giving alms, donors feel joy and thus amass spiritual merit in upholding the Three Jewels.

videos.title: (GDD-582, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Lotus Sutra teaches about the supreme, thorough, and ultimate Buddhadharma; though it won't make us a Buddha immediately, at least it teaches us to take on the first step on the path to Buddhahood. The Shurangama Sutra shows us how different methods lead to the same enlightenment, though it doesn't mean that one will attain enlightenment instantaneously after hearing it. Nevertheless, they certainly help us alleviate our attachment and affliction.

videos.title: Compassion vs. "women's kindness"(GDD-584, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A wise person handles situations with compassion rather than hatred, hostility or a desire to give someone a hard time or to punish them; he just wants to help others. Punishing when necessary is also compassion; we punish people to save them, to help them and make them better. This is compassion.

videos.title: Is swearing an oath useful? How can one's repentance be effective?(GDD-586, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: An oath is a promise that you will do something without fail, while a vow is an aspiration to do something. A vow is a driving force that helps us work toward our goal. In contrast, a malicious oath is a foolish and sinful act that harms oneself and others, but it can be remedied if we repent and reform. We should emulate the Buddha or the bodhisattvas in making vows to deliver all sentient beings, cut off all afflictions, learn all the Buddhist teachings, and ultimately attain Buddhahood.

videos.title: What's the significance of a Dharma name?(GDD-588, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: "Dharma name" serves as a way to remind oneself that one has started practicing Buddhism; it's a sign that one is a Buddhist now and has taken refuge under a certain master. Just getting a Dharma name won't make you a more advanced practitioner or make you become a Buddha sooner. As a Dharma name is related to the Buddhadharma, it is actually a reminder for us to continually practice Buddhism.

videos.title: What is the significance and benefit of pilgrimage?(GDD-590, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhists go to monumental Buddhist sites to pay homage and offer worship in order to commemorate the Buddha and show their respect and gratitude. The meaning of a pilgrimage is to experience the inner world of the Buddha, bodhisattvas, and great patriarchs, emulating their spirit of compassion and the operation of wisdom.

videos.title: (GDD-591, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The original idea of Ullambana, based on the story of "Mahamaudgalyayana saving his Mother" and meaning "rescuing those who are hanging upside-down", was to deliver the dead through the merit of making offerings to the monks who completed a three-month summer retreat. Over time, this practice has evolved into the Hungry Ghost Festival, an occasion celebrated in many countries in Asia.

videos.title: Cohabitation and its impact on society(GDD-592, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The relationship of a couple living together is actually the same as that of husband and wife. Their responsibilities and obligations to each other should also be matrimonial. They must take care of and be considerate of each other, and fulfill their mutual duties. If you and your partner live together in this way, you two will feel more secure and stable. But if a married man has several mistresses or a married woman has several lovers, then there will be grave problems. These complex emotional entanglements will bring great pain.

videos.title: "Mild illness is conducive to one's spiritual practice"(GDD-593, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As Buddhists, we must face reality, accept it, deal with it, and then let go of it. If the disease is curable, receive the treatment; if it's not, what more can we do? As long as we consult a doctor, there's always hope. If we don't do it, there's no hope. If we know we're sick and we face it calmly, then we'll feel at ease. After all, not every disease is fatal.

videos.title: Child abuse and its impact on society(GDD-594, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Facing abusive parents, children should never harbor hatred, but must try their best to stop their parents from immoral, irresponsible, and abusive behavior by seeking outside help. If the harm has been done, then accept it with a forgiving heart. In general, parents may sometimes hurt their children one way or another. This may have to do with their personality, ways of thinking, habits, or educational background. These factors give rise to the different ways and attitudes in raising and educating children.

videos.title: A healthy work ethic for today's people(GDD-596, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: It's not healthy to treat your job just as a source of income, a means to support yourself, or as a status symbol. If we just work for these reasons, we'll feel frustrated with many things. Work is work; it's our duty in this life. If we live for another day, we work for another day. We fulfill our meaning and value of our life through work, serving society, making a contribution, and keeping our body and mind healthy. With this attitude, we'll put all our best effort into it, enjoy whatever we do, and do it well.

videos.title: When our help has been taken for granted or seen as intrusive, what ... (GDD-597, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Charity and good works should not be done in the expectation of gratitude. A good deed is its own reward and will bring you joy. Ingratitude should not stop you from doing good deeds.

videos.title: Will living in the present lead to trouble because of our failure ...(GDD-598, MasterSheng-Yen)
videos.description: To live in the present is not to disregard the future or the past. To live in the present every moment means that whatever you have to do right now, you focus all your attention on that task. Living in the present, we are firmly grounded and renewed each moment.

videos.title: How do we use wisdom when choosing a partner?(GDD-599, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Monastic life is not an alternative escape for not being able to find a marriage partner. One should only become a monastic if one has had some inspirational experiences of life that make one want to take this path. When it comes to finding a suitable partner for marriage, character, instead of appearance, should be the first consideration. Look for qualities like virtue, kindness, honesty, and simplicity. Secondly, your spouse must be clearheaded. Thirdly, your spouse must be an understanding person who cares not only about you but about others as well.

videos.title: Buddhist view on prenatal influences(GDD-600, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A fetus is affected by the mother's mood and interaction with the outside world. If she can engage in Buddhist practices and listen to classical music to keep a clam and serene mind, the baby will be born smart and sweet-tempered. The father also has an indirect role to play for prenatal influences by remaining calm, speaking and behaving softly and gently, being always compassionate, and by creating and maintaining a pleasant household environment.

videos.title: Does the "Prison of Unjust Death" exist in Buddhism? (GDD-551, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Accidental death is not a good thing. But since the person is already dead, through the Buddhist rituals of deliverance this spirit can still be saved, and delivered to a better rebirth. Therefore, we need to recite sutras, perform repentance prostrations, chant the Buddha's name, give and make offerings on his behalf. Then, through the power of the Dharma, he can come and listen to the teachings, let go of his attachment, and as a result can get a better rebirth either in a heaven or the Western Pure Land or as a human being again.

videos.title: What does a "spiritual friend" mean? (GDD-552, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Spiritual friends are both teachers and companions; they advise us, encourage us, and help us through their suggestions, through their association with us, and through their conceptual guidance. So, keeping a good friend, a spiritual friend near can develop character, increase wisdom, and facilitate peace of mind and body, a happy and harmonious family, and a smooth career.

videos.title: Why is the Western Pure Land divided into nine different grades? (GDD-553, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The power of Amitabha's vow to accept all kinds of sentient beings wishing to be reborn in his Pure Land and the fact that there are nine grades of rebirth in the Western Pure Land  show equality in Buddhism: every sentient being has the opportunity for the rebirth and that everyone is reborn according to the effort they've made.

videos.title: Is there any harm in entering meditative concentration? (GDD-554, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: It is not easy to enter concentration, and one who can attain concentration can certainly leave it, so there is no need to worry about not being able to come out of the state of meditative concentration. Extended concentration is an indication of good health, not a cause of physical problems. To avoid harmful hallucinatory states or so-called demonic states, practice under an experienced Buddhist teacher.

videos.title: Why can't Buddhist monks and nuns wear regular clothes? (GDD-555, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Monastic attire helps monastics keep a dignified image and helps both monastics and laity remain mindful of their conduct. So it's absolutely not a good idea for monastics to wear lay clothes when they are not reciting sutras or performing rituals at the monasteries.

videos.title: Do the Buddhist precepts forbid us to cut down or hurt plants? (GDD-556, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The precept of non-killing in Buddhism refers to animals. Using plants to sustain ourselves creates no karma because they're insentient. But we should still have compassion and respect for them as they are living beings and can be dwellings for ghosts and spirits.

videos.title: Can we address experienced lay practitioners as Dharma masters? (GDD-557, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In the early days lay people who were versed in the Dharma could be called Dharma teachers. Today, however, the title is customarily reserved for monastics.
