In Buddhism, only those who practice, receive, and spread the Buddhadharma can be addressed as Dharma teachers. They refer to the Dharma for guidance and use the Dharma to guide people; they take the Dharma as their teacher and make it others' teacher, too. Such people are called Dharma teachers.

videos.title: Tripitaka master (GDD-558, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Those who have studied and mastered the Tripitaka and gained thorough understanding of the Sanskrit originals can be called "Tripitaka masters". In China, there is another requirement: only those who were responsible for a monastery or assembly engaged in the undertaking of the translation of Buddhist scriptures could be called "Tripitaka masters".

videos.title: What's the meaning of saying "Amituofo"? (GDD-559, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "Amituofo", the name of Amitabha Buddha in Chinese, is also a greeting word of Chinese Buddhists. The practice is attributable to Chan master Yongming Yanshou (904-975), who recited Amitabha Buddha's name all the time—even when talking to people, he still mentally recited the Buddha's name. "Amituofo" is a very useful Buddhist expression, good for all occasions. Constant recitation brings us inner peace and joy, keeps us mindful of our conduct, and benefits others in the same way.

videos.title: Is the Diamond Sutra more conducive to enlightenment than other sutras? (GDD-560, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Any sutra can lead us to enlightenment if it corresponds with our mind and level. The key is not to cling to a subjective "I" and an objective "other", namely the notion of self, and to abide nowhere while keeping our mind very clear, which is the function of wisdom.

videos.title: What exactly does "sharp-witted and clever" mean? (GDD-561, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Sharp-witted and clever people may be knowledgeable, but they like to argue with others and tend to resort to sophistry or be too literal-minded. Whether what they say makes sense or not, they like to show others how knowledgeable they are and how smart their opinions and viewpoints are. If someone stubbornly insists on his opinions, talks incessantly and doesn't respect others' opinions, then he is "sharp-witted and clever in the worldly way".

videos.title: How does upholding a practice differ from practicing? (GDD-562, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Although sitting in meditation, doing prostrations to the Buddha image, being a vegetarian, and chanting the Buddha's name are all part of Buddhist practice, the real meaning of practice means to correct and mend our bodily, verbal, and mental actions, as well as to break bad habits. Also, it means to learn by doing something again and again. So spiritual cultivation lies in our constant practice.

videos.title: What does it mean to leave home and become a monastic? (GDD-563, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The work, or undertaking, of the Tathagata family means to emulate the Buddha in thought, word and deed, practicing according to the Buddha's wisdom and compassion, and the principles and rules of the Buddhadharma. Also, it means to deliver sentient beings with the wisdom and compassion of a Buddha.

videos.title: Should we leave people's remains untouched for eight hours after death? (GDD-565, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Making the deceased angry or inflicting pain by moving or touching their body hinders a good rebirth. We should treat the body in the proper way while urging them to let go of worldly attachment and seek rebirth in the Buddha's Pure Land by chanting the Buddha's name for them and dedicating the merit to them.

videos.title: Dharma body, rard body, response body and transformation body(GDD-564, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhas have three bodies: the Dharma body, which is omnipresent and all pervading; the reward body, which results from their merit and virtue; and the transformation body, which manifests in the world appearing to us in a human form with a body and life like our own to save all beings.

videos.title: Bodhi (GDD-566, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Bodhi is to see through worldly phenomena and to be free from attachment. For a bodhisattva who is thus awakened and saves others in the sea of suffering without feeling suffering, "affliction is bodhi, and samsara is the same as nirvana," as taught in the Platform Sutra.

videos.title: The three stages Chan practitioners undergo (GDD-567, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Spiritual cultivation is a process that may go through three stages: seeing the mountain just as a mountain; seeing the mountain not as a mountain; and seeing the mountain just as a mountain again. The first stage represents the state of mind of average people. The second stage is when practitioners are working hard and so absorbed in their practice that they look but do not see, listen but do not hear. The third stage is when they have settled the self, or even let go of it or dissolved it. Only in the last stage does the self no longer exist.

videos.title: What virtues does each of the four great bodhisattvas in Buddhism? (GDD-568, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Various names of bodhisattvas, while representing their specific virtues and vows in delivering sentient beings, actually embody the qualities of the Buddha—compassion, wisdom, vows and practice. Guanyin Bodhisattva (Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara) and Earth Treasury Bodhisattva (Bodhisattva Ksitigarbha) are popular among Chinese Buddhists mainly because they meet their needs, respectively providing help in this life and helping them to avoid hell in the next.

videos.title: Why is it that enlightened Chan masters from the ancient times weren't called Buddhas?  (GDD-569)
videos.description: All sentient beings have the potential to become a buddha. "Seeing the nature and becoming a buddha" indicates when one is enlightened to the reality that one is absolutely capable of attaining Buddhahood through continual practice and meritorious deeds, rather than meaning that one can instantly become someone like Shakyamuni Buddha.

videos.title: Which is more important, compassion or wisdom?  (GDD-570, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Compassion is very important; wisdom is also very important. Being compassionate means caring for others, embracing them, loving them, helping them grow, and forgiving them. Wisdom means that we are capable of clearly observing our minds and recognizing our inner state. Wise people are not emotional, so they are able to influence their families to be less emotional. Because you are not emotional, no matter how people treat you, you won't react with emotion. Thus, people around you will gradually become less and less emotional. If we can cultivate and employ both compassion and wisdom, eventually we'll attain Buddhahood in a peaceful manner.

videos.title: Why is it that many long-term practitioners  even monastics suffer great pain before death?(GDD-571)
videos.description: Everyone has his karmic rewards and retributions. Even if one has attained Buddhahood in his last lifetime, he must reap what he has sown. Causes and effects span many lifetimes, life after life, from the limitless past to the endless future. The causes and effects involved are extremely complicated, so we shouldn't just look at the immediate result of this life to conclude that someone has done good or evil in this life.

videos.title: Why are the Buddhist programs in the form of dynamic retreats so popular?(GDD-572, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism in Taiwan was once a conservative religion that caters to the dead, delivering the deceased to a better rebirth. Now it has become a humanistic Buddhism for the living that serves society and deeply engages it. This, along with other causes and conditions, has contributed to the increasing popularity of various kinds of Buddhist programs for people of all ages and from all walks of life.

videos.title: Universal deliverance (GDD-573, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "Universal deliverance" means that Buddhism delivers sentient beings with the Dharma, to help all sentient beings to eliminate their afflictions and eventually attain enlightenment, to be freed from suffering and obtain the bliss. "Universal deliverance" means whether you want the Dharma or not, believe in Buddhism or not, practice it or not, the gate of the Dharma is always open to you, and you are always welcome to come in. "Universal deliverance" also means to give, to educate, and to offer to all equally, wishing for the deliverance of all sentient beings.

videos.title: What's the right age to take up a religion?  (GDD-574, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Spiritual practice helps us develop ourselves, transform our afflictions into bliss, and helps us eliminate our suffering, and thus attain joy and a sense of belonging. Anyone who feels the need is welcome to follow Buddhism. Even if one is still a child, as long as he's old enough to understand, he can follow and practice Buddhism. For the elderly, even if one is dying he still has time to learn the Dharma. So, there is no age limit. Especially, religion plays an important role in forming a child's sense of direction. If they have firm religious faith, their future journey will be very smooth and steady.

videos.title: What is the significance and purpose of a treasure vault?  (GDD-575, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In ancient times, when laying the foundation of a monastery or a pagoda, the monastics would bury some Buddhist contemporary artifacts such as ritual implements, Buddha images, images of bodhisattvas, relics of the Buddha, and hand-written manuscripts of sutras, under the ground, in a subterranean chamber. Based on the similar idea, Dharma Drum Mountain's treasure vault was built with a wish that people in the future will be able to witness today's Buddhist culture in Taiwan.

videos.title: Buddhist perspective on "trips to the netherworld" (GDD-526, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Visiting the dead by making a trip to the netherworld does them no good and puts your own health, and even your life, at risk. The best way to help them is to do meritorious things like giving and making offerings on their behalf, dedicating the merit to their rebirth in a better realm.

videos.title: How should people today cultivate proper deportment?(GDD-527, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Deportment is a matter of appearance, but also the expression of character. Good deportment allows you to become friends with good people, and makes others feel you're safe and reliable. In terms of Buddhist practice, we can also influence others in a positive way through our deportment and manners.

videos.title: How should we express ourselves properly without hurting others?(GDD-528, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: When we want to say something, we must choose an appropriate time, choose our words, and take a fitting tone. Attitude is also very important. We should be warm and sincere instead of pushing, forcing others or taking a suspicious, hostile attitude. Then our communication will be free from obstacles.

videos.title: What is the purpose of the "Releasing Burning Mouths" ritual? (GDD-529, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: "Burning mouth" refers to a major type of hungry ghosts, who are greedy and miserly while on human path. The rite of releasing burning mouths is to bring hungry ghosts relief through the power of the Dharma and mantras, so that their burning mouth will become a normal mouth that can eat and swallow food. After meal, they may be able to leave the hungry ghost path and ascend to a heaven, or even better, be reborn in the Western Pure Land, or become humans to learn and practice the Dharma.

videos.title: What is the significance of holding different types of Dharma assemblies?(GDD-531, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In the Buddha's time, Dharma assemblies were occasions for explaining, practicing, and listening to the Dharma. But now among Chinese Buddhists, few people expound the Dharma, so rituals were created with guides or manuals for people to follow. People gather in Dharma assemblies to chant or recite, prostrate or kneel down, and do visualizations, so these assemblies combine different forms of practice. Based on different scriptures, bodhisattvas' names or Buddhas' names, and the practices for different Buddhas or bodhisattvas, various practice gatherings have been created, to help people practice Buddhism and spread the Dharma at the same time.

videos.title: How do we help our children make a habit of cherishing ?(GDD-532, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Cherishing and nurturing blessings are fundamental to Buddhism. Each of us only brings limited karmic blessings from previous lives, so if we do not cherish our blessings in this life, we will end up using them up. Once we use them up, trouble will come. Parents should teach their children from an early age to follow and believe in Buddhism, instill in them the concept of karmic causality, and teach them to cherish blessings by making the best of our limited resources and sharing them with others.

videos.title: How to dissolve conflicts(GDD-533, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Communication must be two-way. It's very foolish to try to isolate ourselves from the world, to lock ourselves up in seclusion, to cut off contact with people, to seek no help from anyone. When we just can't communicate with someone, let it go without animosity; reflect on the attitude and the language we use to approach them and try to find a good way to adapt ourselves to give them the chance to come around.

videos.title: How to fill the void in our hearts(GDD-534, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: People feel empty because they do not know why they exist in this world and why their lives pass like this. Another reason for feeling empty is when we cannot get what we seek or have what we want. So the reason for feeling empty is a feeling of pointlessness and futility. If we believe in Buddhism we'll never feel empty, because we know where we are going, what we are doing, and why we are dealing with certain situations. By having Buddhist faith in mind, we know our future can lead in two main directions: to the Buddha's Pure Land or to thorough enlightenment. If we cannot attain enlightenment, we believe we can still be reborn in the Pure Land.

videos.title: How to relieve stress and anxiety brought by the explosion of information(GDD-535, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In a world of exploding information, there is no need to make our life stressful by trying to learn it all, for it is impossible for one to master every trade and know it inside and out. Just try to master our own field and be familiar with other general and practical matters.

videos.title: Must people have faith in order to enter the Western Pure Land or Heaven?(GDD-536, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In general, folk beliefs and all theistic religions believe that gods exist externally—there must be a god external to the believer that is always protecting and helping people. While Buddhism is "theistic", in that although Buddhists believe in the existence of gods, who may be helping us as the Dharma-protecting deities, basically one's inner cultivation does not depend on the gods. Our success or failure, our fortune or misfortune, depends on our hard work and our karma. So in terms of Buddhism, the religion within is the real one and the religion without is a supplement.

videos.title: Can the Dharma help develop the infinite potential in all of us?(GDD-537, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism helps us reduce our affliction, calm our minds, stabilize our emotions, improve our character and expand our compassion, making us become a person of wisdom. As for whether someone can develop the brain indefinitely, becoming someone of great learning, knowledge, and creativity, someone capable of breaking new ground, this is not the main purpose for practicing Buddhism.

videos.title: (How can we judge when we should forbear and when we should concede?(GDD-538, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In our life, only through the experience of rise and fall, advance and retreat, up and down, high and low can we learn and become stronger, wiser, more mature, patient and accommodating. To ensure our hard work achieves its goal, we can retreat for now, give way for a while, and forbear for the moment. But we have to consider why we do so: we give way in order to make progress; we retreat in order to move forward; we forbear in order to be compassionate; and we are accommodating in order to allow ourselves and others to get past a problem.

videos.title: What's the best way to repay kindness?(GDD-539, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If we are able to survive, live in peace and free from disturbance, and follow and practice the Dharma well, we should be thankful to the many people who help and support us. That is why Buddhism teaches us to repay four types of kindnesses: the kindness of parents, the kindness of the Three Jewels, the kindness of one's country, and the kindness of other sentient beings. Some people also count the kindness of teachers.

videos.title: How does Buddhism define "discriminating mind"?(GDD-540, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Discrimination, or the discriminating mind, in Buddhism refers to self-centeredness and petty calculation, not the intellectual recognition of objective facts and reality. Buddhism teaches us to, while being aware of gain and loss, advantage and disadvantage in our daily lives, we should often practice reducing our petty mind and our gasping at gains and advantages. Discrimination is our afflicted, differentiating mind, while recognition of difference, on the other hand, is related to wisdom and knowledge. We should be clear about their difference.

videos.title: How can the Buddhadharma help people who are out of a job?(GDD-541, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In face of unemployment at middle-age, it's much harder to deal with one's feelings than take care of the family livelihood. It's no use to feel upset; all you can do is face the facts, accept the situation, and try to adjust your attitude. You should feel grateful that you are still alive and are able to get by. When we are retired, if situations allow, find a volunteer work. By being a volunteer, life won't lose meaning or value. Just because we are retired doesn't mean we have to become useless, worthless, or idle.

videos.title: How to broaden our mind(GDD-542, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: What's worth learning from broadminded individuals is that we don't make a big deal of everything. Rather, we should just do what should be done, work hard where we need to, avoid what should be avoided, and deal with what needs to be dealt with. Whenever something comes up, we should face it, accept it, deal with it, and then let go of it.

videos.title: Is it  true that as long as one has faith, one can be reborn in the pure land?(GDD-543,)
videos.description: Rebirth in the Buddha's Pure Land mainly relies on two powers. One is the power of Amitabha Buddha's vows, which is the major power. Another is the power of our own vows to be reborn in the western Pure Land. The meaning of rebirth in the Pure Land is that when we get there we won't commit bad karma again, where we focus on the practice of mindfulness of the Three Jewels, and continue to cultivate ourselves until we are transformed from ordinary people into sages. After that we vow to return to this Saha world and follow the example of Buddhas and bodhisattvas to save the world and deliver other sentient beings.

videos.title: How do we know if we're suitable for practicing Buddhism?(GDD-544, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Upon hearing the Buddhadharma some people feel so refreshed and inspired that they are moved to tears. People reacting that way all have good roots and are inclined to accept Buddhism. The majority of people, however, lead an uneventful life and so it's not easy for them to come to a sudden understanding—because there seems nothing to disturb them. It's rare for such people to feel moved immediately after they listen to the Buddhist teachings.

videos.title: Buddhism focuses on compassion, Confucianism. How do these views differ from one another?(GDD-545,)
videos.description: Benevolence and universal love can bring our world peace although they still involve the opposition of subject and object, while people with unconditioned compassion, which is the ultimate, supreme state of mind, transcend this and save the world spontaneously without being attached to the idea of compassion.

videos.title: How do we open up and try to accept and be tolerant of others?(GDD-546, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Some people think that they need a lot more and want to possess and own more; the less they own, the more insecure they get. But the more they own, the more they feel they lack something. Actually, there are only two things we can own forever: wisdom and blessing. The more wisdom we gain, the less afflictions we have. As for blessing, having blessings doesn't mean that you enjoy a rich life. Instead, the greater our contribution and the more we benefit people, the more blessings we will obtain.

videos.title: What's the meaning of practicing Buddhism?(GDD-547, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Action speaks louder than words. It's best that people actually apply what they learn about the Buddhadharma in their daily life, though they don't spend much time studying or researching Buddhism. Nonetheless, if we have both a deep understanding of the teachings and a solid foundation in practice, then that's even better.

videos.title: How do we implement humanistic Buddhism?(GDD-548, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Humanistic Buddhism is an idea advocated by modern Buddhists. Although the term didn't exist in the past during Shakyamuni Buddha's time, the Buddha's teachings were originally meant for helping human beings cross the sea of sufferings to the other shore of liberation, not just about delivering ghosts to assist them to get a better rebirth.

videos.title: Is it possible for people to believe in two religions? (GDD-549, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: It's better not to believe in two religions simultaneously, although some people may sincerely believe in each religion and think that they both help bring them peace of mind. We should tolerate others' religions, respect their religions, and stop discriminating against other religions, but it's also important to stick to our own religion.

videos.title: Can we develop wisdom by delving into the Buddhist canons? (GDD-550, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Various sutras come from discourses delivered by the Buddha on different occasions, to various groups of disciples and at different times. There are Mahayana sutras and Theravada sutras representing different Dharma methods, but they all impart the same principles. People can read the sutras in volume or in depth and both ways can be referred to as penetrating the canon, which is to help us increase our wisdom. Even though you are only studying one sutra in depth, actually you are becoming familiar with the whole of the Buddhadharma.

videos.title: offerings(GDD-520, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Cultivating the path means using the Buddhadharma to help us correct our bodily, verbal, and mental actions. Lay people with little time can still perfect themselves by cultivating the path. The practice of giving is not exclusive to lay practitioners. While lay Buddhists can practice giving or making offerings by giving material things and money, monastics can do so by giving compassion, the Dharma, wisdom, methods of practice, concepts, guidance, and care.

videos.title: What's the meaning of praying before meals?(GDD-519, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As Buddhists, we should not forget the afflictions of sentient beings, and should always bear in mind that this world is a sea of suffering and the pure land does not exist in this world. We hope to emulate the Buddha's attitude and the spirit of bodhisattva—wisdom and compassion. So in Buddhist terms praying means we should at all times remind ourselves to let go of our afflictions and have other sentient beings in mind.

videos.title: Will being nice result in getting taken advantage of?(GDD-518, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People who can't take advice only gain temporary feeling of dignity. They may get self-respect, but it only serves to satisfy their vanity and so is not a true warranted self-respect. While a humble, tolerant person who is willing to accept warnings, advice or even reproach, and feels grateful for criticism is a great bodhisattva and can truly benefit.

videos.title: Compassion is the supreme guideline for protecting our spiritual environment(GDD-517)
videos.description: Environmental protection starts with our mind, our spiritual environment. In protecting the spiritual environment, however, the primary thing is compassion. When we have compassion, we will protect the environment and all the beings that depend on it, coexisting with them in harmony.

videos.title: Master Hongyi: "Fame and profit are much loved by fools, (GDD-516, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Pursuing fame or profit for one's own sake will only compromise one's virtue, merit, and wisdom. If a person craves for fame and profit, he will be affected adversely and can't escape his own conscience and the law of karma. We should instead emulate Shakyamuni Buddha to care for and deliver sentient beings without thinking of becoming famous in the future.

videos.title: "Putting down the cleaver, one may become a Buddha on the spot"(GDD-515, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhist story of "putting down the cleaver and becoming a Buddha" tells us that once we realize that harming others or doing evil is wrong and resolve to stop and change our minds, we've turned around and sown the seed of Buddhahood, namely the cause for attaining Buddhahood, and therefore we will certainly become a Buddha in the future.

videos.title: True Dharma, Semblance Dharma and Decline of the Dharma(GDD-514, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although we are in the Dharma Ending Age in terms of Buddhism—a stage or period to time when people's experience, acceptance, application and practice of the Dharma are not that strong and are on constant decline—as long as the Dharma exists and we have very strong faith and practice very diligently, we can always benefit from applying it to our daily life and so there is no need to lose hope.

videos.title: The merits of reciting sutras(GDD-513, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist sutras are religious texts; they offer a way of life and a way to cultivate a peaceful mind. By reciting sutras and making it our regular practice, we will have a more peaceful body and mind. When people believe in religion, read the scriptures, and practice accordingly, they will naturally create works of literature, works of art, and develop the ability to appreciate art. Religion is a guideline for living, while art adds color to our life, which has a cultivating effect and makes our lives more refined. There's no contradiction between the two.

videos.title: How should Buddhists balance work and volunteer work?(GDD-512, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Volunteering means willing to spare some time to help others without reward, which reflects the spirit of Mahayana Buddhism—to serve others first without asking for reward. Volunteering is its own reward; it helps us grow and gain happiness and a sense of satisfaction. By using our time efficiently, we can actually take care of family, career, volunteer work, and practice well.

videos.title: Paranormal phenomena(GDD-511, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The phenomenon of haunting does exist, but only certain kinds of people are likely to see ghosts. If we run into such situation, we can recite the Earth Treasury Sutra, the Amitabha Sutra, the Buddha's name or the Diamond Sutra for them. When ghosts hear these sutras, they are hearing the Dharma and so they will be able to realize the truth and let go of their anger, resentment or grudges and therefore can take another rebirth.

videos.title: Putting emphasis on contentment, shame, and repentance in our daily life(GDD-509, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Chan practice is not merely about sitting in meditation. Buddhist practitioners should also seek conceptual guidance and establish the correct mindset. Otherwise, practicing meditation only benefits one's body as qigong does and cannot really change one's character, mentality, and view of life. A true Buddhist constantly reminds himself to know contentment, shame, and repentance. Only when we repent can we feel joy, because we have a clear conscience and feel at ease.

videos.title: Does death solve all problems? Is it equivalent to "liberation" in Buddhist terms(GDD-508)
videos.description: Liberation is not the same as evasion, escapism, and world-weariness. Liberation is using wisdom to observe and eliminate our contradiction and conflicts within by realizing that that all phenomena merely give the illusion of arising and perishing, and that all things are temporary existence and eternal emptiness. You are aware of phenomena but aren't attached to them and not disturbed by them. People with such wisdom won't be bothered by anything. This is true liberation, liberation attained through wisdom.

videos.title: Goals and clinging(GDD-507, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: It's important to have direction in our life, to know where we are going by setting up a guiding principle for ourselves. Instead of setting unrealistic goals that are subject to changes of the environment, we should make great and long-lasting vows that have nothing to do with our discriminating and clinging mind, aspiring to use the Buddhadharma to help ourselves and others, serving society, humanity, and all sentient beings.

videos.title: Are Buddhists allowed to keep pets?(GDD-506, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: It is permissible for Buddhists to keep pets, but not recommended. If you do keep pets, be sure to love and take care of them properly, as they do feel pain like us and no sentient being wants pain. Having compassion toward animals doesn't mean we have to take home all stray animals we see just because we pity them, for there are simply so many stray animals. Instead we can recite Amitabha Buddha's name and transfer the merit to them, praying for them to gain a better, higher rebirth.

videos.title: People coming back to life and ghosts possessing dead bodies(GDD-505, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism only mentions that when a person dies, his spiritual consciousness will take rebirth according to his karma. Whether it can come back to life on its own or by possessing a dead body is not discussed. Buddhism advises us not to bury or cremate a person too soon after he dies, and that we shouldn't even touch his body right away, because he may still be alive.

videos.title: Does Buddhism believe in calling back the soul of the dead?(GDD-504, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Only sentient beings on the ghost path, or those who have died less than 49 days ago can be called for deliverance rituals. Buddhism refers to this 49-day process as an intermediate stage between death and rebirth. This intermediate existence comes between two lives and only sentient beings in this state can be called. Through the strength of the Buddhadharma and of the Buddhas' and bodhisattvas' compassionate vows, simply reciting the sutras, performing repentance prostrations, and chanting the Buddha's name may produce a response in the deceased, thereby helping them attain a better rebirth.

videos.title: Are there designated methods or occasions to perform rites of honoring one's ancestors?(GDD-503)
videos.description: Buddhism does not reject holding rites for one's ancestors, but they benefit more from the merit of the Buddhist practice and good deeds you undertake on their behalf. We can honor or remember our ancestors by reciting sutras, prostrating to the Buddha, or reciting the Buddha's name, either at a group practice or at home.

videos.title: How to establish the correct mindset for job-hunting(GDD-502, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Don't be picky when it comes to finding a job after graduation. If you find a job where you're wanted, then just accept it. After getting the job, work at it for a while and decide if you should look for a better one. You can keep looking and plan your next step. From the Buddhist point of view, al things arise through the working together of causes and conditions. When the cause is there and conditions are ripe, you'll find everything goes your way, and you will get what you want readily.

videos.title: How can people find a balance between destruction and construction?(GDD-501, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although the cycle of formation, continuation, destruction, and emptiness is a natural phenomenon, which reflects the Buddhist principle of independent co-arising, the process is actually gradual rather than sudden. Similarly, in the process of change there has to be a connection between the new and the old, so that there is no dangerous gap in between.

videos.title: How to tell if a religion is wholesome or not (GDD-521, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhist perspective on religion is that firstly, wholesome religions don't have cults of personality. Secondly, though religion seeks to transcend the natural or physical world, it should by no means defy wholesome customs, habits, ethics, or moral standards and systems. If local society regards something as a wholesome custom or habit, conforming to legal and moral standards, then religion must abide by it. Thirdly, a good and proper religion treats all people equally and tolerates all other religions; if it rejects other religions and permits only itself, it is a problem.

videos.title: Distinctions between wholesome and unwholesome religions (GDD-522, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Some things in religions are truly beyond human comprehension and can be both divine and demonic. It's better not to have dealings with the spiritual beings that may hurt you mentally and physically once you turn your faith away from or rebel against them, because worshiping them will make you subject to their control in the end.

videos.title: Must one recite Amitabha's name for end-of-life chanting?(GDD-523, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: As far as Buddhists are concerned, whether or not the person at the deathbed believed in Buddhism while alive or no matter what Dharma method he practiced, we can chant Amitabha Buddha's name for him. We can introduce the Dharma to encourage him to seek rebirth in the Western Pure Land, explaining that his destination should be the pure land of Amitabha Buddha.

videos.title: Benefit others and in turn you benefit yourself(GDD-524, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Giving and receiving must be mutual, which are what hold society together and what make the society and the world we live in have warmth and hope. Although we may not be able to repay kindness to the person who has helped us, as long as we harbor gratitude and thankfulness, and pray for the happiness of our benefactors, or in turn try our best to use what we have, our knowledge and abilities, to help others and contribute to society, that is also repaying kindness.

videos.title: What role do parents play when their son is romantically involved with someone?(GDD-525, )
videos.description: Talk with your kids about their reasons for their choice of spouse. Share your views and concerns without being attached to them. From a Buddhist point of view, it's best that children accept parents' well-intentioned advice and suggestions, and parents should respect their children's thoughts and choices. Thus, they will come together on some points. This way, unnecessary conflicts and tragedies can be avoided.

videos.title: Selfishness vs self-interest(GDD-471, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Selfishness and working for one's self-interest is normal and reasonable, as long as it doesn't harm society and hurt other people. But Buddhism teaches us to learn the spirit of the bodhisattva and practice no-self by sharing our personal gains with all sentient beings, without asking for return and being attached to our good deeds.

videos.title: What does the term "consensus" mean? How to reach consensus with others? (GDD-476, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A consensus must be based on the common understanding and needs of a community or group, as a common cause or goal everybody can identify with and believe in. A consensus helps the members of a society, environment, or family live a life with more peace of mind, serving as a basis on which they can continue to make progress.

videos.title: Upholding honesty in a business (GDD-477, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Honesty and credibility are two qualities that facilitate sustainable development, which not only benefit us now but will also help us win everyone's trust in the long run. On the contrary, a company that is not concerned about credibility or reputation will lose out sooner or later. This reflects the Buddhist idea that goodness results in karmic reward and evil results in karmic retribution.

videos.title: Healthy competition(GDD-478, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism is not opposed to wholesome competition, which is fair, open, normal and reasonable. The purpose of competition is not to bring someone else down so we can rise to the top; the point is to act as a model ourselves by doing better where others have failed to do better, and by contributing more where others have not contributed so much. This kind of competition is to bring more benefit to society and everyone in it. In Buddhism it is not called "competition", but "diligence", meaning working hard ceaselessly to improve ourselves and benefit others in the spirit of bodhisattva.

videos.title: Discriminating mind(GDD-479, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhist idea of non-discrimination does not mean making no distinctions. The Buddhadharma makes a very clear distinction between good and evil, more and less, large and small, as well as existence and non-existence, as a starting point or focal point for our effort in spiritual practice. For example, although sentient beings intrinsically have the characteristics of a Buddha, they are not Buddhas now and are still sentient beings because they are disturbed by afflictions. They still need the help of the Dharma to free themselves from their afflictions. With spiritual practice they rise level by level and progress by stages until ultimately they are liberated and become a Buddha, and then there is non-discrimination.

videos.title: How does Buddhadharma help those...? (GDD-480, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To help elder people have a sense of security, family members should make sure their aged relatives get proper medical help to calm their nerves so they won't be so upset and nervous. Secondly, they need to be treated with more love and compassion. The method is using the Buddhadharma as a guide to let them know that human life is by nature not secure and nowhere is actually secure, and encouraging them to let go of worldly affairs and recite Amitabha Buddha's name to seek rebirth in the Pure Land.

videos.title: What significance does Buddhism give to modernization?(GDD-481, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Keeping up with the trends is not the same as modernity. The true meaning of modernity is new knowledge, new learning, new skills, new ideas, and the most important philosophy of life of the time. Also, as the distance between people is shrinking and we need to use many different languages to communicate with different people and cultures, it's good to know more foreign languages.

videos.title: The significance of offering food(GDD-482, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhists make offerings in a symbolic manner to the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Sangha, to show their respect to them. Buddhists also make offerings to deities and ghosts, in the sincere hope of using the Buddhadharma to deliver and liberate them, using the Buddhist teachings to influence them and move them so they have fewer suffering because of their attachment and gain some peace with the help of the Dharma.

videos.title: Can unusual bodily signs really serve as omens?(GDD-483, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Strange physical reactions are not omens of the future, but signs that we should pay attention to the state of our body and mind. By keeping a healthy body and mind we will be able to deal with things smoothly and avoid possible problems, thereby inviting blessings

videos.title: Can we commit minor offenses?(GDD-484, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We should take the birth of a baby in our household as the arrival of a bodhisattva that will help us grow spiritually by cultivating wisdom and karmic blessings in learning to guild them and bringing them up. By raising a child with appropriate guidance and admonition rather than spoiling them, we can help cultivate them to become of use to society, become a family member that everyone can be proud of.

videos.title: Intentional/unintentional taking of lives of family members(GDD-485, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When faced with the loss of a loved one in our family, which is always a most stressful moment, we should try to see life as a play directed by the force of karma and familiarize ourselves with the idea of letting go, in order to allow the pain to fade and regain our mental balance.

videos.title: How the generation can pass on their experience to the new generation(GDD-486, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There is actually no guarantee in any ages or any society, so we must teach children to count their blessings and feel content for all that they have. If we remind ourselves to count our blessings and to be frugal at all times, then when a problem or some difficult situation occurs, we won't find it unbearable because we're already used to a simple lifestyle.

videos.title: How can modern people establish a correct view of religion?(GDD-487, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: True religious belief is based on several conditions. First, the religion must have a theoretical basis. It must have a historical background. It must have communal activities. The beliefs of a religion must promote a peaceful and healthy body and mind. Following a religion should not result in physical and mental abnormalities, familial trouble or disturbances to society. A true Buddhist cultivates this peace through taking refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and implementing the Buddha's teachings in their daily lives.

videos.title: Can eating a vegetarian diet help us fend off disasters?(GDD-488, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism talks of reaping what one sows; one must seek one's own blessings, develop one's own wisdom, and use one's own power to help oneself. Nevertheless, we can always benefit the sick or dying by dedicating the merit of our good deeds to them and thus affect their state of mind.

videos.title: Will we inevitably receive spiritual responses from our practices??(GDD-489, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Unusual physical and mental reactions are the natural result of serious practice. If we marvel at them, become attached, and crave them, we may very likely fall into a demonic state. Instead of paying over attention to them or worrying about them, the best way is to keep an even mind, a mind of equanimity, and keep practicing as usual.

videos.title: Inter-ethnic marriages(GDD-490, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Dealing with differences in a marriage, especially in intermarriage, a couple should accept, adapt to, and learn about each other's cultural backgrounds, religious backgrounds, and habits. If they can identify with, respect, and tolerate each other, then the marriage will be a happy one.

videos.title: What's the karma for eating animal meat?(GDD-499, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Some people eat exotic wild animals, especially endangered species, out of vanity, arrogance, and curiosity. It not only damages the environment but actually also sows the seeds of karmic retribution. Buddhist sutras say that all disaster -- whether flood, drought, war or epidemic -- is the result of collective karma, in which the action of killing is the major contributor.

videos.title: Buddhism's view on mass killing of animals(GDD-498, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Mass slaughter of diseased animals is upsetting, but they were already destined for slaughter by the consumption of meat, which actually contributes to the action of killing in Buddhist terms. In fact, if people didn't eat meat, then people's cruel behavior toward one another and the phenomenon of mutual enmity would be reduced. Only by eating less meat or none at all can human beings truly address the problem of hatred and killing.

videos.title: What is the significance of a pilgrimage?(GDD-497, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: One may make a pilgrimage to any sacred spot, ancient or modern, near or far. A pilgrimage helps people develop their faith, renew their devotion, and clear their mind, thereby creating spiritual benefit and merit.

videos.title: How to attain rebirth in the Pure Land(GDD-496, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A pure land means there is no evil, no suffering, no worry, sorrow, or affliction. From a Buddha's perspective, no matter where he goes he is in a pure land because a Buddha's karmic blessings and wisdom is the same wherever he goes. If we can eliminate our anger, hatred, greed, discontent, and jealousy, and cultivate a state of mind that is pure, serene, content, and carefree, then we will see a pure land everywhere.

videos.title: How to establish harmonious relations with people(GDD-495, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Our interpersonal relationships reflect the karmic affinity we formed with others in our past lives. But to transform our karma we should develop good affinity with others by being nice to them and treating them well, no matter how they treat us.

videos.title: What kind of adjustments should a practitioner make between group and individual practice?(GDD-494)
videos.description: Individuals cannot be separated from the group, but they also need time to face and confront themselves. In Buddhist practice, both group and individual practices are required in that group practice provides confidence and encouragement for one's diligence while individual practice helps one face, understand themselves, focus on their own mind, and be their own master.

videos.title: What does it mean to worship the six directions?(GDD-491, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Worshipping the six directions, in Buddhist terms, means to fulfill our responsibilities as a lay follower towards those they represent: the Three Jewels or our superiors, our spouses, parents, children, friends or siblings, and subordinates. This is the true way to pray for merit and blessings.

videos.title: How does the karmic law of cause and effect apply to monastics?(GDD-492, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To claim that one does not fall under or is not subject to cause and effect represents a type of nihilistic view. Nihilism is an outer path. Instead, we should not be ignorant of cause and effect, and should practice what is required of us as the cause, to attain liberation and achieve Buddhahood as the effect, which is a process that cannot be skipped.

videos.title: How to cultivate peace of mind(GDD-493, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There is no guarantee of security in this world because material conditions and our worldly possessions are unreliable. Therefore, Buddhism teaches us to cultivate peace of mind, for as long as we can calm and stabilize our own mind, our environment will not matter. Peace of mind doesn't lie in any outside person, situation or thing for protection. Instead, we should face reality and maintain a balanced body and mind. As long as we do our part then our mind will be at ease and at peace.

videos.title: How to implement the way of "simple living"(GDD-451, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The decadence and extravagance of our lives is bad for our bodies, health, way of thinking, family life, society, and natural environment. Instead, we should live a simple life, trying our best to do things ourselves and live a frugal, simple, modest, and industrious life.

videos.title: Spiritual practice and leisure activities(GDD-452, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Modern people need recreation because their work is too stressful and the environment is too complicated. After working a few days, people are extremely tired and exhausted, and so they need to rest and recuperate. Buddhist practice is even better than recreation in that it improves our state of mind when we learn to relax our body and mind and let go of worldly worries, instead of a change of scenery or a different way to feel stressed.

videos.title: Helping crime (rape) victims(GDD-453, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Encouraging religious faith is the best way to prevent sexual violence, because such a behavior shows a lack of wisdom and compassion and will lead to karmic retribution. When it has already occurred, we should have compassionate concern for the victims and help them overcome their trauma and regain their mental health.

videos.title: The virtue of forgiving others(GDD-454, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If we don't choose our words carefully, small slips can turn people into enemies, or hurt our friends, relatives, or those close to us. Seek forgiveness and show repentance for the wrong we have done. But if it is not enough then let time ease the grudge while we try to mend our ways. Instead, we should use admiring, encouraging, comforting, sympathetic, and praising language, and then we will be able to reform ourselves and take on a new attitude and state of mind, and therefore will get along well with everyone.

videos.title: The karmic effect of charitable giving(GDD-455, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Society is a cooperative structure. Endeavors in culture, education, religion, charity, and relief work can transform those in our society who have lesser ability into high quality talent. By working for the good of society, showing loving care, and practicing giving, we can make our society better, as well as sow the seeds of blessings and nurture blessings for ourselves.

videos.title: Balancing needs and wants(GDD-456, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: "People today are well-supplied with material things or enjoyment and the result is that our desires become greater and greater. Being led by our pursuit of material desires is miserable and can cause damage and destruction to the natural environment. Instead, we should economize and live more simply, which is extremely beneficial for our body and mind. Being at peace and living an ordinary, stable life is in itself a type of health, enjoyment, and happiness.

videos.title: Teen troubles (GDD-457, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Dealing with troublesome teens requires love, patience, care, and sympathy. Parents should take that as an opportunity to grow spiritually and increase their compassion. When deviant behavior in teenagers occurs in society, it actually helps us to ponder the problems of society and the problems of children's educational environment.

videos.title: International perspective of Buddhists (GDD-458, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Having an international perspective means that we do not box ourselves in staying only within the narrow circles of our own life and the confines of our own country. It means that we know about major international events in the areas of thought, culture, art, religion, politics and economics. Buddhists also need an international perspective; they need to know about the Buddhist world, about what the Buddhists of the world are doing, what they are thinking about, and what direction they are going.

videos.title: Compassion vs. mood swings(GDD-460, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist practice includes two aspects: understanding of the concepts and daily practice of the methods. The point of learning Buddhism is to use the Buddhist ideas we understand to solve the problem we encounter in daily life. It is most important to constantly practice, so as to gain effectiveness and proficiency in applying the Buddhadharma to our daily activities, keeping our body and mind in a state of balance, calmness, stability, and peace.

videos.title: How should we face other people's complaints and deal with them?(GDD-465, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If there is a problem, we can report it, have it discussed, ask how to handle it, or make a suggestion. There are lots of channels for expressing what we have to say. Whether as a Buddhist or an average person, don't complain about anyone, and don't feel bad if someone complains about you. By practicing listening to complaints and criticism patiently and magnanimously, we can grow spiritually and become a healthier and better person.

videos.title: Chinese Ouija boards(GDD-464, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As Buddhists, we should follow the law of cause and effect as well as that of causes and conditions to help ourselves live a more positive life and expand our minds, and should use spiritual practice to help ourselves become more peaceful in mind, and more upright, serene, and dignified in behavior, rather than playing Ouija board for some spirit's message, which is actually useless in improving our character and will only change our mood and spirit in a negative way, making us become extremely dependent and lose our own judgment.

videos.title: How do parents instill a sense of morality and values in children?(GDD-463, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Parents and teachers should be concerned about or pay attention to children's spiritual education, religious beliefs and moral life while they are growing and developing, because they are curious about everything and are more easily subject to the influence of their friends, the stimulation of society, and the temptations of their environment.

videos.title: Transcending taboos—it's all a matter of perception(GDD-462, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Taboos are simply customs that have been handed down. According to Buddhism, any bad luck that results from breaking a taboo is actually due to your own state of mind

videos.title: How to deal with people who are bossy(GDD-461, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Religious followers may believe that their own religion is the best and their ideas and ways of thinking or that their religious precepts are the most important. They may believe they can criticize, and say what is good and bad because it is their belief. But religious followers should never impose or force their standards and beliefs on others, and use them to scare them or threaten them. Instead, they should have a friendly, easy-going and open attitude when interacting with people.

videos.title: How to find a balance between self-reproach and responsibility(GDD-470, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People who always blame themselves lack confidence and don't understand themselves. On the other hand, people who always shift all the blame onto others are usually arrogant and conceited. Instead we should be ashamed, repent our errors, and try to find out our strong points and shortcomings, while working harder and seeking to improve ourselves. That's called repenting and knowing shame and taking responsibility.

videos.title: Time management(GDD-469, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Using our time efficiently means knowing how to spend our free time in a fulfilling way, or how to be relaxed and at ease even when we're very busy. Those who make full use of their time are people with a very clear mind, for they know how to arrange their time in an orderly and logical manner, and so will in turn have a lot of time at their disposal.

videos.title: The meaning of "In poverty, people see fortune-tellers"(GDD-468, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Fortune-telling, drawing oracle sticks, palmistry, and physiognomy may be able to bring temporary comfort or peace of mind, but they don't actually help people improve their future. It is our reverent attitude in upholding the Dharma, practicing giving, and helping to spread the Dharma that will gain us merit.

videos.title: How to build a pure land on earth(GDD-467, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: At any moment our mind is in accord with the Buddha's mind, the world is a Buddha land. Although it is impossible to enable everybody to see our world as a pure land, if we can practice care and respect for all sentient beings and try to free our minds of conflicts, contradictions, and struggles, then at least we can have a brief experience of pure land.

videos.title: Understanding impermanence and living life to the fullest(GDD-466, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Impermanence means that life is finite and the time that we can really use is very limited. While we have to spend most of our life make a living, working for our family, we should make good use of our life and enhance the value of our life by having good intentions, speaking good words, and doing good deeds. If we can't do good deeds, at least we should make sure that people interacting with us don't suffer because of us.

videos.title: Selfishness vs self-interest(GDD-471, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Selfishness and working for one's self-interest is normal and reasonable, as long as it doesn't harm society and hurt other people. But Buddhism teaches us to learn the spirit of the bodhisattva and practice no-self by sharing our personal gains with all sentient beings, without asking for return and being attached to our good deeds.

videos.title: How to intrigue people to practice Buddhism (GDD-472, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As Buddhists, when we live among and interact with other people we shouldn't give them reason to dislike us or cause to feel an aversion to us. We can use the spirit of Buddhism to interact with them, help them, and embrace them. Over time, if causes and conditions are ripe, people will naturally accept Buddhism in a way they're comfortable with and benefit from it.

videos.title: Can householders wear monastic robes? (GDD-475, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Since Buddhist monks wear distinctive clothes to show their identity, it's not advisable for lay people to wear them. When householders wear monastic robes or clothing, they look neither monastic nor lay, which can cause confusion and is not a good thing.

videos.title: Selfishness vs self-interest(GDD-471, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Selfishness and working for one's self-interest is normal and reasonable, as long as it doesn't harm society and hurt other people. But Buddhism teaches us to learn the spirit of the bodhisattva and practice no-self by sharing our personal gains with all sentient beings, without asking for return and being attached to our good deeds.

videos.title: How to intrigue people to practice Buddhism (GDD-472, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As Buddhists, when we live among and interact with other people we shouldn't give them reason to dislike us or cause to feel an aversion to us. We can use the spirit of Buddhism to interact with them, help them, and embrace them. Over time, if causes and conditions are ripe, people will naturally accept Buddhism in a way they're comfortable with and benefit from it.

videos.title: What does it really mean to be "always ashamed"? (GDD-473, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Conscience and the sense of shame represent a method and mindset of practice. Conscience means the self-awareness that one has let oneself down or to be ashamed for one's own faults, while the sense of shame means that we're ashamed because we let others down. By having a conscience and a sense of shame we are able to mend our ways and seek self-development in a proactive and positive attitude.

videos.title: Why do monasteries suspend a wooden fish outside the dining hall? (GDD-474, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The wooden fish is used by monks to alert themselves to have a spiritual sense of shame, practice diligently, and not to be lazy. The wooden-fish clapper serves to remind Buddhist practitioners to have the path of the bodhisattva in mind and remain diligent when entering the dining hall to eat.

videos.title: Can householders wear monastic robes? (GDD-475, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Since Buddhist monks wear distinctive clothes to show their identity, it's not advisable for lay people to wear them. When householders wear monastic robes or clothing, they look neither monastic nor lay, which can cause confusion and is not a good thing.

videos.title: Developing proper democratic views(GDD-450, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Democracy requires us to consider collective thinking and perspective, as well as the public good. In terms of long-term benefit, however, the majority opinion is not necessarily correct, so we must rely on expert knowledge and keen wisdom to observe and make judgments. In the perspective of bodhisattva spirit, democracy also means using our true wisdom to explain things patiently, kindly, and earnestly to convince everyone to accept our view so they can improve things accordingly. The principle is to make a contribution to the people and not the other way around.

videos.title: Promoting Buddhism by producing soap operas(GDD-447, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Whether dramatized works about Buddhist stories will have a positive or negative impact on the viewers depends on the attitude of the company that makes the movie or series. They can either help people know about Buddhism or undermine Buddhism as a whole. Buddhist followers or groups have the right and the duty to follow its progress and make positive suggestions.

videos.title: Promoting Buddhism by using illustrations(GDD-446, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The use of pictures to tell the stories of Buddhism, the story of the Buddha and the events which occurred during Shakyamuni's past lives on the bodhisattva path began very early in the history of Buddhism, as can be seen in the Buddhist caves in China. They spread the Buddhist ideas in a way that is easily accessible and can leave a deep impression on the viewers. So using pictorial images to spread Buddhism is very practical, especially when you use images that are serial or narrative, as in comics.

videos.title: Benefits of cremation(GDD-445, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Cremation is the best way to deal with remains because it takes up little space and leaves no pollution and after-effects. That's why cremation was adopted in Buddhism. The ashes can either be scattered or a symbolic amount of them can be kept for remembrance.

videos.title: Gambling(GDD-441, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The love of gambling must have existed since primitive times; it reflects the love of contests, contests of strength, of wit, of luck, and also of wealth. Gambling violates the Buddhist precepts for it may involve stealing and false speech, and it often leads to grave financial ruin for one's family. If there is a gambler in your family you should separate your assets for your own security to safeguard your own life.

videos.title: Burgeoning of technology and human relationships(GDD-438, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As information technology is advancing rapidly and computer networks are getting overwhelmingly popular, we can access information, all knowledge and learning any time we need to. If we can make more use of information technology, then, with so much to learn, we can strengthen ourselves and won't be lonely. But no matter how much information technology develops, the need for contact between people, for service and care will stay the same.

videos.title: Good manners in the family(GDD-437, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To develop good manners in family, parents themselves must first form the habit of saying polite greeting to each other before they can teach it to their children. Good manners are a sign of civilization and modesty to show great respect toward the other person. Manners make our home harmonious and our society peaceful; it is one of the best ways for us to be happy.

videos.title: Child molestation(GDD-436, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We need to teach children from a young age to be vigilant and observe people carefully, how to recognize when they are in danger of sexual abuse, and to run away and tell a parent or teacher to help them deal with it. Also, we should reform the social environment and public opinion to help prevent such criminal behavior.

videos.title: How to de-stress in a stressful environment(GDD-434, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In today's social environment where there is too little space, too many people, and information spreads too fast and the sense of space is too small, we need to constantly relax the mind and body. Relax the brain, relax the mind, and don't be stressed or nervous all the time. Then consider our actions. Don't be coarse or rude. Also don't be too direct when speaking. Always be aware of these things, be aware of ourselves, check ourselves, and urge ourselves to relax. This way when we're facing a difficult task we won't suffer so much but can instead live a very happy, free, and relaxed life.

videos.title: Is there really such a thing as "being blocked by ghosts"?(GDD-433, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If we encounter the situation when our way or passageway is blocked by the ghost, we can recite the Buddha's name to arouse its compassion, then it will let us go and won't block the way any longer. Sometimes "being blocked by ghosts" also means when we are lost and don't know what to do with our lives. When that happens, the Dharma can help us transform our mood and mind and therefore we can find our way again.

videos.title: Media's impact on society(GDD-432, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Writers and the mass media should not lead people astray with the stories they write and report, but should consider what their work's cost to society is. Although their point of departure might not be bad, the way they describe a story can influence some people into committing crimes.

videos.title: Finders keepers?(GDD-431, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Finding and turning in lost property reflects one's sympathy and feeling for someone else, as well as one's concept and idea of karmic causality. This meritorious act is a result of one's sense of honor, faith, and religious belief. We need to strengthen these two things in our society --honor and religious belief—so as to establish a more ideal society.

videos.title: Is it okay to cheat on a test?(GDD-430, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Students cheating in exam are cheating themselves while assessing their studying levels or real abilities. It upsets the natural balance and it's unfair to those who are intelligent and work hard. Since it's unfair, there will naturally be karmic retribution. By playing by the rules, being a good person, and working solidly at school and at work, we are proving that we are reliable and have solid ability and sound character. In this way, people will think we are trustworthy, dependable, and honest, which will be very advantageous for us and will bring us great honor.

videos.title: Establishing a world-class city(GDD-429, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People should always take care of their own environment. In order to maintain a place so that it is clean, orderly, neat, and quiet, more comfortable for people to live in, it requires that our government's law is enforced, and that the people's education and our individual habits are improved.

videos.title: (GDD-428, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People go to the temple during the Lunar New Year to seek good luck and merit. This custom is a very good one in that at the beginning of the year we begin again as a person and start afresh with a new way of life by repenting our misdeeds and bad karma of the last year.

videos.title: How to reduce garbage(GDD-427, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To reduce garbage, we can try not to buy so much, cook so much, or order so much food in a restaurant if we can't finish it. If we can't finish the food we've cooked, save it for the next meal. If we can't finish our food in a restaurant, take it home and finish it later. For the things we use, we should reuse them as much as we can. Keep using them again and again and don't just use something once and then throw it away. Try not to use disposable things; otherwise we are generating more and more garbage.

videos.title: How to face water shortage problems(GDD-426, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To solve the water shortage problem, we need to use water sparingly. We should try to conserve water and encourage people to use less water. We must also figure out how to clean up polluted water sources and prevent pollution in the first place, to ensure that we can continue to use water in a sustainable way.

videos.title: The development of Buddhism in China and Taiwan(GDD-401, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: After the Cultural Revolution, China's policy on religion was gradually liberalized and Buddhism in China has been slowly recovering and reviving. In Taiwan, Buddhism is now growing stronger day by day, and our human resources are increasing. The Buddhist circles are putting in more efforts in fostering Buddhist talent and spreading Buddhism.

videos.title: The five precepts and the bodhisattva precepts (GDD-403, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The precepts are meant to safeguard our mental and physical peace and well-being, and to create a harmonious society, instead of intimidating or restricting us. After receiving the precepts, we'll be on our guard and be alert for our actions, and thereby becoming more stable and healthy in mind and body. There's no need to fear taking the precepts; if we break a precept, simply repent and resolve not to make the same mistake again.

videos.title: How can we establish a clear sense of direction and a clear goal in life?(GDD-404, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People, whether young or old, all need a sense of direction. The average person needs to have a long-term life plan, without which they'll feel lost. In Buddhist perspective, the direction or long-term goal of life is to achieve Buddhahood. In setting a goal in our life, we need to consider our own abilities, our current environment, the historical backdrop, and the global environment. But the most important thing is to perfect our character and develop a peaceful body and mind.

videos.title: Are natural disasters a form of divine punishment?(GDD-405, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There have always been natural and man-made disasters, but most catastrophes today are actually man-made due to the destruction of our planet and environment. Based on the Buddhist view of karmic causality, disasters reflect a group of people's collective karma. The best way to avoid disasters is first by taking precautions beforehand, such as doing more good deeds and not causing troubles for the environment, and secondly, by making amends afterwards, such as changing our character and our way of thinking toward life.

videos.title: What kind of karmic retribution results from gossiping about others?(GDD-406, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
There is a Buddhist precept to refrain from false speech—jealous speech, destructive speech, speech that sows discord, abusive speech, lying speech, and mocking speech.
We should consider whether our words will help others and ourselves, and think about how our words will affect others who hear them. Will they have a positive effect or a negative effect? If we consider these things first, then we'll refrain from careless speech in the future.

videos.title: Should we abolish capital punishment?(GDD-408, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: All sentient beings can become Buddhas. There are only people who have done bad things; there are no eternally, unchangingly bad people. Abolishing capital punishment should take two paths: One is to consider how to legally decrease the number of death sentences, and the other is to promote religious education so as to prevent crime from the bottom. If people all reached a high level of Buddhist or religious cultivation, no one would commit capital crimes.

videos.title: Do those who carry out executions suffer karmic retribution?(GDD-409, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: One who carries out executions is just the enforcer of the law. It is the person who is being killed that is behind the killing, because he committed a certain kind of crime and must receive karmic retribution. Nevertheless, the attitude of the judicial executioner makes all the difference. If he enforces the law with compassion, and recites the Buddha's name praying for the condemned so he will from that moment have a change of heart and be reborn in the Western Pure Land, then not only is the executioner not committing the sin of killing, but his act is meritorious.

videos.title: How are sharira created and how does Buddhism view sharira?(GDD-410, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Sharira, or relics, are produced by the power of spiritual response through one's own practice and faith. They may serve as reminders and religious objects to be worshiped, but it is the Buddha's teachings, the true relics of the Dharma-body, that can really inspire us spiritually and transform us.

videos.title: How does Buddhism view traditional funeral customs?(GDD-411, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The purpose of funeral ceremonies is to remember the dead and comfort ourselves, relatives, and friends. From the Buddhist perspective, it is to help the deceased secure a better rebirth or gain rebirth in the Buddha's pure land by transferring the merit from reciting the sutras and the Buddha's name.

videos.title: How to create a literate society(GDD-412, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The purpose of reading is to develop our character, expand our knowledge or our skills. Read books that are really informative and illuminating rather than reading for excitement or distraction. Parents should read with children, and help them choose and read children's books that are informative and benefit their mental and physical health.

videos.title: How does Buddhadharma help people with terminal illnesses?(GDD-414, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If a person doesn't believe in religion, doesn't believe in Buddhism, then even if their physical body does not suffer, mentally they have no sense of security. When death is inevitable, accept it peacefully and lead a normal life with calm, while reciting Amitabha Buddha's name all the time entrusting our mind to the Western Pure Land.

videos.title: How to effectively deal with complaints(GDD-416, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Complaints are the result of discontentment and everybody feels some dissatisfaction. We are only human and so we can't be without mental affliction, and he who has mental affliction is likely to complain. In the face of criticism and complaint, we should place ourselves in the other's position and think what's best for ourselves and others. Firstly, we shouldn't complain about others. Secondly, we should accept others' complaints. And thirdly, when we hear others complaining about us, we shouldn't get upset. Instead, we should be glad, because it means that he has a high opinion of us.

videos.title: How ex-convicts can start a new life(GDD-418, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Breaking the law and doing evil are not things people are destined for from the day of birth. Dealing with people serving time, we must give them warmth, counsel and guidance to help them realize that what they did was wrong. Our society should give ex-convicts a fair chance, help them and facilitate their reintegration into society so that they may be of service to our community.

videos.title: How do special camps help school drop-outs?(GDD-419, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Dharma Drum Mountain organized a camp for truants to help them grow mentally and improve their outlook and attitude. We treat them with warmth and care and give them a chance to bring their individual talents into play, to say what is on their minds, to learn things in a hands-on manner, and to do the things they want to do. This way we treat them with respect, instead of trying to discipline them. If our society and schools can treat these children differently and give them a special kind of environment, give them guidance and a chance to grow, then these children will get on the right track.

videos.title: Effective communication(GDD-420, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Effective communication requires us to treat others equally and make them feel respected by being courteous and lowering ourselves. This way we can make others well disposed towards us, otherwise they will not accept us. This principle can be used to successfully communicate and negotiate. To communicate and negotiate, put ourselves in the other person's shoes. Let him say what he thinks, and decide how we can help him according to what he requires.

videos.title: Flea markets—How to establish correct views as consumers(GDD-421, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The purpose of the flea market we organize is to treasure the resources we have now. Things that we have used and do not need any more are not necessarily trash; they can still be used. Even if we can't use them ourselves, we can let others use them. We should treasure resources by using things as long as they can be used, and recycling things we can't use any longer.

videos.title: How does karma account for murders and suicides?(GDD-423, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: According to the Buddhadharma, the bonds of enmity should be loosened, not tied. By committing suicide or murder, one will only create bad karma, a vicious circle in which the problems will never be resolved. If during our lives we are treated unfairly or wronged, it would be best for us to think of ways to improve things. Also, if we can receive some measure of justice by resorting to the law, that's enough.

videos.title: Why does Buddhism use the lotus flower as a symbol? (GDD-376, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The lotus flower is described in Buddhism as pure and undefiled, and as being of great benefit. It teaches us to become a person of pure wisdom, who cultivates the bodhisattva path among ordinary people, learns to be free of greed, hatred, and delusion, and only gives and contributes to our world without seeking to gain anything of this world.

videos.title: What does this swastika 卍stand for?(GDD-377, Master Sheng-Yen)
