videos.description: he swastika in Buddhism symbolizes infinity, perfect harmony, and totality, in terms of both time and space. It is also one of the Buddha's 32 marks of greatness, the signs of perfect merit and blessings, representing the Buddha's perfect wisdom and complete compassion.

videos.title: Buddhism's view on "running into something evil"(GDD-379, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Some people blindly fear the evil influence of the deceased spirit when they are near a corpse. If we have a healthy mentality, treat the deceased as a bodhisattva going to the Western Pure Land, and recite the name of Amitabha Buddha for him with good will, we will feel comfortable, peaceful, and safe.

videos.title: Should one eat a vegetarian diet when doing the end-of-life chanting?(GDD-380, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Many Mahayana sutras, such as the Nirvana Sutra, the Shurangama Sutra, and the Sutra of Brahma's Net, all encourage people to be vegetarian, especially for those who aspire to practice the bodhisattva path. Nevertheless, people who haven't completely given up eating meat are still encouraged to practice chanting or reciting the Buddha's name, as what really counts is our mind. If our mind is pure, then the recitation is useful.

videos.title: What's the proper way to dispose of Buddha images?(GDD-381, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Buddha's spiritual responses, power, wisdom, and compassion are everywhere. As we read the sutras, practice the Buddhadharma, and benefit from the Dharma, we then have seen the Buddha. The Buddha exists everywhere; it's not as if the Buddha is only in Buddha images or statues. The image or statue is not the Buddha; we worship Buddha images or statues so as to invoke our faith and develope our aspiration to emulate the Buddha.

videos.title: Why do monks and nuns have to shave their heads?(GDD-382, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In ancient India it was a custom for practitioners to shave their heads to show they'd renounced the five desires, for our hair adorns our body and so it can be said to stand for sensual desire. Hair also symbolizes our mental affliction as well as our attachment to worldly affairs and emotions and so shaving our heads symbolizes that we want to eradicate our afflictions and suffering.

videos.title: Chain letters(GDD-383, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Chain letters are baseless superstition; whether in terms of religious faith or philosophical theory or folk belief there is no way you can find a foundation. By contributing more to others we'll enjoy karmic blessings, and by caring more for others we'll have good luck. If we contribute more to society and have more compassion toward sentient beings, then we'll have good fortune. Only in this way is our good fortune true and reliable.

videos.title: What are the "eight winds"?(GDD-384, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Ordinary people are subject to and often affected by the "eight winds"—praise, ridicule, fame, disgrace, gain, loss, happiness and suffering. Through spiritual practice we train our minds not to be disturbed and shaken by these eight types of external influence.

videos.title: The "Matthew Effect"(GDD-385, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The Christian Bible says: "To all those who have more will be given; but from those who have nothing even what they have will be taken away." In terms of Buddhist spiritual practice, this "Matthew Effect", a term used by some sociologists to describe a social phenomenon, reminds us to have foresight and make good use of what we have spiritually to develop and nourish more merit and blessings.

videos.title: Should Buddhists participate in political activities?(GDD-386, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Politics is the management of the affairs of the people. Since we Buddhists live in this society and are citizens of this country, we should fulfill our obligations as taxpayers, and thus have the right and obligation to vote, and the right to run in an election. This is an obligation as well as a right, and is universal. We should vote for one who we think would benefit our society and country, bring people peace of mind, make significant contributions, and even benefit the entire world.

videos.title: Teenage counseling(GDD-387, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: It's best to introduce children to religion at an early age, to Buddhism or any other of the great, established religions. Children who believe in God or Buddha and bodhisattvas will naturally find psychological relief and spiritual solace. They'll behave properly towards their parents at home and towards their teachers at school, and therefore will be better equipped when facing teenage pressure and problems.

videos.title: How to change people's behavior of indulgent spending(GDD-388, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: When people are not satisfied they feel that they haven't got enough; they are greedy and insatiable. This often leads to all kinds of terrible social phenomena, such as worship of money or worship of material wealth. It's best that people believe in karmic causality, for someone who believes in karma will know that one's fortune all depends on one's own effort, rather than using illegal methods or evil means to gain things.

videos.title: How can parents help their children develop healthy values toward money?(GDD-389, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If today's teenagers have muddled moral values, then in the future they'll create much misfortune and trouble. Parents should have frequent heart-to-hearts with teenagers, spend more quality time together with them, and listen to what they have to say. Parents need to keep their child's needs and psychological health in mind, and show care about their problems and troubles. If this kind of relationship can be developed, children will be understanding towards their parents.

videos.title: What it really means to make offerings(GDD-390, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Making offerings is a very important part of Buddhist practice. To make offerings is to practice giving, one of the six perfections. It benefits both ourselves and others in that through giving we are actually repaying the kindness of others and showing gratitude, as well as learning and growing spiritually. Also, by making offerings to the sangha we are contributing to spreading the Buddhadharma and helping others engage in spiritual practice, thereby gaining great merit.

videos.title: What kind of attitude should a business leader have(GDD-392, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The relationship between labor and management is interdependent, in which they interact with, help, need, and make demands of each other. Business owners, management and executives contribute a lot by investing capital, offering their wisdom and their time, and taking on risks, while employees put in their contributions through their hard work, cooperation, and support. This reflects the Buddhist teaching that every phenomenon, every achievement or success is the working together of many causes and conditions.

videos.title: How do business leaders identify, use and retain talent?(GDD-393, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To recruit talent, business leaders can check whether the job candidate is sincere, which is the most important factor. Once you hire them, treat them like family; take care of them at work; and take care of their physical and mental well-being, as well as their family. By training and nurturing talent from within a company at entry level positions, a business or company will be able to retain the most loyal, reliable, and capable employees and leaders.

videos.title: The employer-employee relationship(GDD-394, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The employer-employee relationship is mutual; it is not just a financial or economic relationship but also an ethical relationship. The boss and the employees work as one living entity. They work together and spend their lives together, sharing the well-being or otherwise of their company. It's best for a company to develop a common vision to be held by both the employees and the employer as a shared goal.

videos.title: Significance of the copying of sutras(GDD-395, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In ancient times when there was no printing, copying the sutras by hand was to help spread the Buddhadharma and therefore was a meritorious act. Nowadays, unless it is for personal practice purpose, there is greater merit in having popular or accessible sutras modern Buddhist books printed for free distribution to the public.

videos.title: How do we care for our neighbors and our community?(GDD-396, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When there's nothing we can do to help, it's best to keep clear of a messy situation and not linger in a dangerous spot. But we shouldn't run away if the situation allows and requires us to take action to help someone in need, prevent someone from being hurt, or save someone's life.

videos.title: How can we foster the breadth of mind that allows us to give unsparingly?(GDD-397, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Just like the well will be replenished when we use it, giving our wealth away to benefit others will be rewarded with karmic blessings. When we give without any conditions or selfish motives, we are developing our character, our virtue, and our wisdom, which are actually our most reliable source of safety and security.

videos.title: What's the purpose of reciting the gatha:"Warning to the Assembly"?(GDD-398, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Human life is short and limited, and our lives are very precious because we are born as human beings, as the Buddha taught us that "It's hard to be born human". Life may be hard and painful, but life's hardships are an experience, a process to train ourselves, to grow and mature, and therefore to gradually perfect our character and morality so that we can become peaceful and calm and also help others to become peaceful and calm.

videos.title: Cultivating peaceful minds, bodies, families, and activity(GDD-399, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The purpose of the Four Fields for Cultivating Peace movement we launched in 1995 is to help people live and work in peace and contentment. The effectiveness of the movement lies in developing a peaceful mind by living in contentment with few desires. With a peaceful mind we are more able to have a peaceful body, a peaceful family, and a peaceful job.

videos.title: Where is Buddhism flourishing the most (GDD-351, Master Sheng Yen)
How can a Buddhist judge which sutra is the best (GDD-352, Master Sheng Yen)
How does one establish and maintain a family (GDD-353, Master Sheng Yen)
What circumstances are most suitable to becoming a monastic (GDD-354, Master Sheng Yen)
How we can maintain a modest attitude GDD 355, Master Sheng Yen
videos.description: From a Buddhist perspective, we know that people are basically ordinary, unenlightened, and so of course have faults. We should think of our own faults first and then see if others have good points that we can learn from. We should criticize others less and examine ourselves more. We should also make a compassionate vow for the future, finding ways to help and benefit sentient beings, and then we will feel that there is too much to learn and work for. If we can do this, then we can be very modest.

videos.title: Is it really possible for a person who vows to be reborn in .... (GDD-356, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: As long as there is attachment to the self, differentiation of the self and self-centeredness, as long as there is a self, a notion of the self, then one is not liberated and there must be karmic effects one has to receive. By reciting Amitabha's name and thus being reborn in his pure land, we can eliminate our afflictions completely and become liberated. Then we can vow to return to this world to deliver sentient beings, which is in itself accepting karmic retribution actively and therefore amounts to no longer suffering karmic retribution.

videos.title: Buddhist perspective on sexual discrimination (GDD-357, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Shakyamuni Buddha never discriminated against women because he believed that bhikshunis and bhikshus were the same and could both attain arhatship. There are great bodhisattvas who are women, like Queen Shrimala, which is very clearly stated in the sutras. The Buddha has compassion and regarded all sentient beings as equal, so how could men and women not be equal?

videos.title: Buddhist perspective on organ donation (GDD-361, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism does believe that if a person clings to his body, then he cannot be moved before the last breath to avoid adding to their suffering or affecting their ascension to the pure land or rebirth in a good realm of existence. If a person made a vow to donate his organs or was very compassionate, once death is properly determined, removing his organs to save another won't cause him any harm or vexation and anger.

videos.title: What does sharing others' joy actually mean (GDD-362, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Rejoice in others' merit, one of the ten great vows of Samantabhadra, is rejoicing in other people's good deeds and good qualities or taking part in someone else's meritorious deeds. No matter what situation we are in and what position and status we have, we can help people at any opportunity, by using our mental and physical effort, financial resources, influence, and social status.

videos.title: What actions are in the deceased's best interest (GDD-364, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: When a hospital pronounces someone dead, that's when a person's heartbeat stops, the pulse is gone and the breath stops. In Buddhism, it's after a person's spiritual consciousness has left the body that we speak of "death". The deceased's spiritual consciousness is free of the body and unaffected by its cremation. We can benefit the dead best by chanting "Amitabha Buddha" to help him gain rebirth in the Western Pure Land.

videos.title: How do we help those on their deathbed who wish to.. ..(GDD-365, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: It's best to let the dying person pass away in a comfortable manner and without physical burden. In general, let him die peacefully in a lying position. Then ask him to recite the Buddha's name, and everyone present can chant the Buddha's name gently and softly to help him. That's the best way to pass away.

videos.title: How to prepare psychologically and adjust one's attitude .....(GDD-366, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Taking refuge in the Three Jewels means that we identify with and accept the Buddha, Dharma and Sangha, and are willing to live by the Buddha's teachings cultivating compassion and wisdom. It's not true that after taking refuge there will be many frightening, scary things awaiting us or that there will be lots of restraints and restrictions; instead it will help us live a more wholesome, peaceful, and down-to-earth life, to be a better human being.

videos.title: Buddhism's view on the unlucky number 9 (GDD-367, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Chinese people have Chinese superstitions and foreigners have foreign superstitions. Superstitions have to do with people's customs, history and cultural background. Instead of keeping telling ourselves, thinking to ourselves that we will have bad luck in a certain year or that things won't go smoothly, we should become mentally strong and recite the Buddha's or bodhisattva's name more often, do more good deeds, and help people more, then there will be less problems.

videos.title: Seeing a bright future in one's advancing years (GDD-368,  Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Toward the last several years or last period of our life, we should get mentally prepared for the future. We need to be confident and hopeful about the future, and have vows for the future, vowing that everlastingly we want to deliver sentient beings and give of ourselves by following the Buddha's path, learning the compassion and wisdom of the Buddha.

videos.title: Rules for visiting a monastery (GDD-369,  Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Regular monasteries actually don't have so many elaborate rules of etiquette; there is a lot of flexibility in the monastery. As long as one behaves politely one needs not worry and doesn't have to feel intimidating when visiting a monastery. If we do not understand the etiquette, we will understand once we go.

videos.title: Why are there more female Buddhist followers (GDD-370,  Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: In Taiwan, there are more female than male Buddhist followers because of our social structure and because the work patterns and lifestyles of men and women are not quite the same. In general, women are gentler and more mild-tempered, so under most circumstances they are more likely to accept religious faith. This is not just true in Buddhism.

videos.title: Eating natural foods (GDD-371, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: The current fad of natural, health food happens to coincide with the Buddhist position. While some people promote natural food for health reasons, Buddhism advocates vegetarian food to show compassion toward animals. Even if we cannot stick to vegetarianism, just trying to eat more natural food and cut back on meat can help ourselves become kinder and gentler and develop more compassion.

videos.title: Should Buddhists completely avoid using leather?(GDD-372, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: There are no rules in Buddhism that forbid the use of leather, but it's best to try to avoid it unless it's something we need. For example, in the bhikshu and bhikshuni precepts, there is a rule that monastics are allowed to wear straw sandals with leather soles for walking on mountain paths or long distances. Hopefully we can use less leather, but if we use leather when we need to we shouldn't feel guilty.

videos.title: How to develop our inner wisdom and compassion (GDD-373, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: If there is something in our mind, then it has obstructions; it cannot be broad and vast, open and clear, and therefore it cannot really have wisdom and compassion. A mind free of obstructions is a mind without distracted thoughts and vexations. When we are not affected or afflicted by our environment, that's wisdom; with such wisdom, we will have compassion.

videos.title: Why do good people still suffer retribution?(GDD-374, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: From the perspective of the Buddhadharma, human life and death aren't limited to one lifetime. We have actually gone through countless rebirths, so sometimes it's difficult to look at the causes and effects solely at a single lifetime. The best way is to let bygones be bygones while paying attention to our present actions; things that can be dealt with should be dealt with properly. This is more conducive to our physical and mental well-being, and to our own future.

videos.title: The emotional life of monastics (GDD-375, Master Sheng-Yen)
videos.description: Sentient beings are sentient because they have feelings, and monastics are no exception. However, the Buddha's teachings require that we become an awakened or enlightened sentient being, so as to dissolve our own vexations and help relieve others of affliction and suffering.

videos.title: How to harmonize emotion and reason(GDD-0327)
videos.description: Emotion and reason should complement each other and be in balance. Buddhism teaches that we purify our emotion and transform it into compassion, showing concern and sympathy towards others without attachment, as well as use our wisdom to be flexible, accommodating others and adapting to their needs. Applying compassion with wisdom is harmonizing emotion and reason.

videos.title: Flying saucers and the Buddhist view of the universe(GDD-0328)
videos.description: Our planet is only a very tiny world among immeasurable, countless worlds in the ten directions of the universe. Buddhism has a very extensive view of the world, and says that worlds arise and perish, with some universes perishing here and others forming there. In every world, sentient beings have different karma and different environments.

videos.title: The difference between pain and suffering(GDD-0326)
videos.description: Pain is a physical phenomenon experienced with our nerves. Suffering is a mental phenomenon, a psychological thing. Pain is not tantamount to suffering, yet suffering can often cause pain. Our suffering comes from our craving and attachment, and from our unwilling or reluctant to give up or let go. If we are able to readily take up responsibilities, let go of any attachment, and face reality and deal with the situation at hand without running away from it, then we won't feel suffering in our minds.

videos.title: The significance of story of "The Big Duck and the Small Duck"(GDD-0331)
videos.description: Big ducks leave large wakes and little ducks leave small wakes. Whether it's big or small, each duck takes its own path. Everyone has different karma and blessings, so there's no need to compare ourselves with others and envy others. We should do as much as we can do and learn with peace of mind in our lives.

videos.title: How do college students select a mentor in Buddhism?(GDD-0333)
videos.description: Studying Buddhist doctrine and practicing are two different things. But it helps to have a clear idea of what Buddhism is about by truly understanding Buddhist doctrine before we start to practice; otherwise we could easily go astray in our practice because we aren't clear about our direction and the basic principles involved.

videos.title: How should women practice spiritually?(GDD-0334)
videos.description: Men and women are fundamentally equal; the Buddha says that all sentient beings have buddha-nature. Therefore, when it comes to spiritual practice, there aren't different methods for women and men. The methods are the same and the goal is also the same, as are the ideas and views, although differences do arise in some situations.

videos.title: Why should we "generate the mind"?(GDD-0335)
videos.description: In Buddhism, to "generate the mind" means to generate a "great mind" or "vast mind", meaning generating a bodhisattva mind to do good deeds for the benefit of all sentient beings. It also means to generate a mind of patience and perseverance, meaning that we should not stop until we attain Buddhahood or, at least, that we should continue to do good deeds, do what we should do, and work hard.

videos.title: Literary creation and spiritual practice(GDD-0336)
videos.description: A real practitioner doesn't write just for the sake of writing, but writes to pass on what he knows and has experienced of the Buddhadharma to other people. I express what I have to say using speech and writing that most people can understand, so as to allow people to know what I'm thinking, what I've experienced, and what I've discovered. My doctorate degree helps me contribute cultural, academic and educational circles, and attract or introduce people to Buddhism.

videos.title: What should monastics do when a problem arises at home?  (GDD-337, Master Sheng Yen)
Introspection and correction (GDD-338, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We should examine our every thought with a sense of shame, and have to keep going so as to discover the mistakes. If we keep discovering mistakes and correcting them, then we may gradually improve ourselves. Chan practice requires us to use the methods of practice to examine our mind, which is the most important. Don't be afraid of making mistakes; be afraid only of not recognizing mistakes. Don't be afraid of having bad thoughts; be afraid only of being unaware of having bad thoughts.

videos.title: Introspection and correction (GDD-338, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We should examine our every thought with a sense of shame, and have to keep going so as to discover the mistakes. If we keep discovering mistakes and correcting them, then we may gradually improve ourselves. Chan practice requires us to use the methods of practice to examine our mind, which is the most important. Don't be afraid of making mistakes; be afraid only of not recognizing mistakes. Don't be afraid of having bad thoughts; be afraid only of being unaware of having bad thoughts.

videos.title: Pure mind is pure land(GDD-339, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A quiet mind isn't necessarily a pure mind, and a tranquil land isn't necessarily a pure land. Purity means when there is no vexation in the mind, and that when one has a wise mind not subject to any outside influence. We need to practice to avoid having a greedy mind, a hateful mind, a mind that is deluded, prideful, jealous, or doubting. When these negative mentalities are thoroughly cleaned up, one is pure in mind. Once your mind is pure, then the world you see is also pure—a pure land on earth.

videos.title: Buddhists' patriotism(GDD-340, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Shakyamuni Buddha's teachings, his views, and his methods actually aim to help people actively participate in the world, save the world and transform the world. Life involves birth, aging, sickness and death, which are all things Shakyamuni Buddha and Buddhists care a great deal about. The Buddha taught the Dharma in hope that we would use it to help ourselves, to adjust our attitude and perspective, and then help purify our society. Buddhists are never passive and negative.

videos.title: How to get along with our co-workers(GDD-341, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From the perspective of the Buddhadharma, no matter what environment or situation we're in, relationships between people should be open and harmonious. Harmony at the office depends on the system at work, and also on staff members' attitude in getting along with each other. We should avoid making comparison with others, never mind what others do or what they think of us, and simply devote ourselves to our work wholeheartedly.

videos.title: How do managers maintain a good relationship with their subordinates?(GDD-342, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A good mid-level manager is the one who does the planning for the boss. He devises strategies, does research, implements plans, and then divides and delegates the work carefully. After that he must coordinate and harmonize the lateral relations of the departments, and provide a working system for the company's hierarchy. He solves all problems and is caring toward everyone, all the employees.

videos.title: What makes a great master?(GDD-348, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In Shakyamuni Buddha's time, the title "great master" actually referred to the Buddha himself. During the course of history, calling someone a great master is a way for later generations to show their reverence for former masters, or it's a way for disciples to address their highest mentor or leader, their spiritual leader. People are called a great master for a reason: They are broad-minded, visionary, charismatic, and inspire respect. They perform great meritorious deeds and possess great virtue and wisdom.

videos.title: Why onions, garlic and leeks are seen as "non-vegetarian" foods(GDD-349, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism teaches that it's best to refrain from eating the five pungent spices. There are two reasons for this: when you're chanting sutras or when you're receiving guests, it is impolite and disrespectful if your breath smells bad. The other reason is that they arouse anger when eaten raw; when eaten raw before they're cooked, they make you irritable and ill-tempered. When eaten cooked, they arouse your passions; when you eat them cooked, they arouse your sexual desire and stimulate your sex drive.

videos.title: What kind of attitude should a business leader have(GDD-392, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The relationship between labor and management is interdependent, in which they interact with, help, need, and make demands of each other. Business owners, management and executives contribute a lot by investing capital, offering their wisdom and their time, and taking on risks, while employees put in their contributions through their hard work, cooperation, and support. This reflects the Buddhist teaching that every phenomenon, every achievement or success is the working together of many causes and conditions.

videos.title: How to cultivate the ability to be self-restrained and at peace(GDD-0312, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Idle people are unable to be at peace because their mind and body wander about, unable to settle down. We need to devote our body and mind to work, which can help put our body and mind at peace. We can only grow after we have worked hard; only after we have grown can we bring peace to ourselves and others.

videos.title: The true meaning of happiness (GDD-0313, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Whether one can live in peace and happiness has mainly to do with one's state of mind. Happiness is to be content and always joyful; happiness is to live fully in the present moment, to be mindful of our conduct and actions, and to face our own conscience truthfully; happiness is to count our karmic blessings and cultivate merit at all times.

videos.title: How to adjust our disposition (GDD-0314, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We can adjust our mind as a way to help our physical health. We need to realize that birth, aging, sickness, and death are a natural part of our life, that to have some illness can motivate us to practice and achieve the Way, and that by falling sick we are actually paying off our karmic debts and therefore can feel carefree afterwards.

videos.title: Life's responsibilities (GDD-0315, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From the Buddhist perspective, there are only two kinds of responsibility in life. The first is to fulfill our vows, and the second is to pay back our karmic debts. We should learn the Buddhas and bodhisattvas in making great vows to save suffering sentient beings. In paying back our karmic debts, we should actively contribute to our society for the benefit of the public, and treat any situation we encounter, whether good or bad, with equanimity.

videos.title: Becoming a monastic and returning to lay life (GDD-0317, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There is nothing wrong with returning to lay life once becoming a Buddhist monk. If after making a sincere effort one finds that one's habits and mindset are not suited to monasticism, one can still be a good lay practitioner.

videos.title: Male chauvinism (GDD-0318, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From the Buddhist perspective, men and women are equal because we can see in the sutras that Shakyamuni Buddha's disciples included both men and women. Men can achieve the fruit of arhatship and so can women. It's problematic for people to hold a double standard, being male chauvinistic themselves while expecting their own daughter to be treated with respect. People should treat women equally as they would like their daughter to be treated.

videos.title: What kind of books Buddhists should read (GDD-0319, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although Buddhists are detached from worldly pursuits, that doesn't mean they don't care about the world. In order to care about people and the world, we need to understand and learn more about the people, affairs and things of the world. So Buddhists also need to read secular books; the Buddhadharma is actually not separate from the world. By combining Buddhism and secular learning, we can actually help ourselves and others better solve the problems in the world.

videos.title: Agricultural pollution (GDD-0320, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Using pesticides not only takes the life of those insects, but also kills people indirectly by contaminating the vegetables and fruit, as well as the soil. We can use natural or organic fertilizers, adopt indoor or greenhouse cultivation, and, if people believe in Buddhism, recite the Buddha's name for those insects, wishing them to relocate or be reborn in the Western World of Ultimate Bliss.

videos.title: Bringing modern Buddhist music to greater heights(GDD-0301, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist music can free our mind of desires and impurities and make us calm and composed. It can positively affect our lives with harmonious melodies, and help purify people's minds and society.

videos.title: Appropriate ways of giving(GDD-0302, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Through the action of giving we foster our compassion and generosity, which will help us reduce our attachment and clinging to the self, and reduce the greed, craving, and desire of the self. Though the merit of giving may be subjective, we should do investigation and contribute to credible people and organizations, or to those who are truly sincere and deserve our support.

videos.title: True filial piety(GDD-0303, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From a Buddhist point of view, filial piety really means that we support our parents, take care of their daily lives, their health and medical care, and even their religious and spiritual needs. Moreover, we should always be grateful for our parents' loving concern, although we don't necessarily need to stick to our parents' ways, as times and society may have changed.

videos.title: How to break down the barriers of our mind(GDD-0304, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The barriers of our mind come from our five mental afflictions: greed, aversion, ignorance, arrogance and doubt. If we can transform the five mental afflictions into the mind of cultivation by being sincere and maintaining a warm and caring attitude, respecting people and treating them with dignity, concern, understanding and compassion rather than seeing others as enemies, then we wouldn't need our mental defenses.

videos.title: How to cultivate patience(GDD-0305, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To develop our patience, whether it's dealing with our job or with our relationships, first we must feel that the job is one we should do, we enjoy, and one we must complete. Secondly, we must realize that since we have no way to escape from someone or something we are supposed to deal with, we cannot but try to have patience.

videos.title: The Buddha saves those with affinities(GDD-0306, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddha works to deliver all sentient beings in the hope that they may be delivered. But some people have heavy karmic hindrances, karmic retributions, and afflictive hindrances that keep them from believing in the Buddha or understanding the Buddhadharma in the right way. Nevertheless, the Buddhas and bodhisattvas will all actively teach the Dharma and deliver sentient beings by forever creating affinities and causing them to ripen.

videos.title: How to cultivate people with foresight(GDD-0307, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Our ingrained habits and our ways of thinking due to our self-centeredness have caused most of us to lack wisdom and compassion. By practicing the six perfections of the bodhisattva path—giving, keeping precepts, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom—we can transform ourselves to have more wisdom and compassion, and become a person with intelligence, foresight, and love.

videos.title: How to cure the mind of those who've overindulged in ease and pleasure(GDD-0308, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We should be alert and vigilant even in times of peace and prosperity, always be prepared for impending disaster. So we must cultivate diligence and the ability to endure hardship, then whatever kind of environment or situation arises, we'll be able to get through it safe and sound.

videos.title: How to cultivate perseverance(GDD-0309, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Spiritual cultivation requires us to develop aspirations as a long-term, lasting goal. By setting an unchanging, ultimate goal we are then able to walk along our path, and move one step at a time, without losing our hope and giving up when encountering defeat or setbacks.

videos.title: How to keep our mental balance and relieve pressure in stressful times(GDD-0310, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we feel pressure or stress, it means we have certain fears or we're not feeling confident; we doubt our own capability so we feel we can't shoulder the burden and wish we didn't have to deal with it. We should try to use the slightest effort to deal with our problems by first understanding them very well, and manage to accomplish our task. When we're doing a task, do not feel overwhelmed. Just put forth our best effort; there's no need to worry about not doing it well.

videos.title: "Are Buddhism's buddha-nature and Confucianism's idea of  inherent goodness .....?(GDD-0324)
Is it possible to combine religions?(GDD-321, Master Sheng Yen) )
How to break through dichotomous thinking(GDD-322, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: While dichotomous thinking is necessary for human culture and civilization, there must be communication and harmony between oppositions and contradictions in order to reach unity. After achieving unity, we must transcend it. Only then can we reach wisdom and absolute compassion, thereby attaining liberation and freedom.

videos.title: Cultivating outstanding Buddhist talent(GDD-323, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The most talented and gifted sages in Buddhism are "naturals." They aren't a product of their environment or of education, but are a natural phenomenon. However, people with slightly lesser or average gifts, either monastics or lay practitioners, can still become Buddhist talent through formal Buddhist education, or through regular practice and study of Buddhist concepts and methods, being a driving force in the transformation of the world today.

videos.title: "The mind changes with the environment"(GDD-0291, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If our minds are affected by our environment, then we'll change in accordance with it, feeling unstable and insecure. If we can keep our mind unaffected by our environment, then we won't change with it no matter how our environment changes, and therefore remain composed and calm.

videos.title: Are bodhisattvas and Buddhas humans or deities?(GDD-0279, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Buddhas and bodhisattvas have the qualities of deities, such as the power to manifest spiritual responses, but Buddhas and bodhisattvas are sages who have only wisdom and compassion and are not attached to the self, and who have already achieved liberation, free from the afflictions of self-centeredness. 

"

videos.title: Buddhist education for children(GDD-0284, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: It is essential for people to acquire their moral training and sense of ethics through inculcation from a very early age. Parents should make their child learn about and understand a religious faith that helps develop their gratitude, thankfulness, compassion, and wisdom, so that they grow up to be honest and upright people, kind and genuinely willing to help others.

videos.title: Does burning ghost money work?(GDD-0280, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Burning ghost money is not a part of Buddhist culture, nor is it a Buddhist belief. This is a part of Chinese culture that has more of a comforting effect rather than any substantial use for the dead. Therefore, Buddhism advocates reciting the Buddha's name, preaching the Dharma or reciting the sutras for the deceased, to enable them to become detached, let go of the suffering, and be reborn in the Buddha's Pure Land.

videos.title: How can we absorb the favorable elements of the West  culture?(GDD-0286, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The good point about Western culture is that it stresses straightforwardness and immediate results; it is good at material and technological cultures. While spiritual culture, or the culture of the inner life, is strength of Asia. We should be able to achieve a blend of the two; the two must be made to complement each other so they can work in harmony without contradiction.

videos.title: How to get teenagers to change their ways?(GDD-0283, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Our society has created an environment to encourage young people to look for stimulation and excitement instead of seeking true satisfaction and contentment. Parents should take responsibility for advising and educating their children from a young age about how to play in a way that is meaningful and is good for the mind and body. Business people must have morality and shouldn't pander to the public with advertising lines that will cause damage to young people's minds.

videos.title: How to overcome deluded thoughts(GDD-0282, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: It would be impossible for most people not to have wandering thoughts. It is fine as long as we recognize and be aware of our wandering thoughts. With spiritual practice, such as repentance prostration, reciting sutras or the Buddha's name or mantras, and sitting meditation, we can train ourselves to calm and purify our minds, and thereby naturally reducing our distracting or wandering thoughts.

videos.title: How we can beyet happy, and tired but joyful(GDD-0290, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We have to be busy in that we need to use our limited lives and precious time to build up our wisdom and merit, by giving of ourselves to serve, help, and take care of others. In Buddhism, we're busy for ourselves, so even if we've gotten nothing in this life, we'll still have gained merit and the benefit of wisdom. Therefore, we'll feel tired but very happy for having the opportunity to be busy.

videos.title: Pursuing a perfect character(GDD-0289, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Pursuit of perfection is impractical, for our wisdom has its limitations and we are bound to have many blind spots, plus the fact that our self-understanding is incomplete. Perfection in its true sense means when our mind isn't perturbed by the environment because of our confidence and wisdom, while being sincere and genuine, admitting it when we are wrong and continuing our efforts to make progress and improve ourselves.

videos.title: The meaning of "giver of joy"(GDD-0287, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: At Dharma Drum Mountain, managers are referred to as the "giver of joy" in the hope that those in the managerial position can, based on the Buddhist idea that all sentient beings are equal and have the Buddha-nature, use their ability and intelligence to serve others and help others to grow, so that everyone feels peaceful and happy.

videos.title: What to do if you accidentally eat meat while practicing vegetarianism(GDD-0288, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A full vegetarian must have a firm will and confidence in themselves to stick to vegetarianism, while following Buddhism in a natural and easy manner without making things difficult for themselves or become imprisoned by their own inflexible views.

videos.title: Why do we often address others as "bodhisattva?"(GDD-0277, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"A bodhisattva is someone who hasn't achieved Buddhahood yet but wants to become a Buddha. Anybody who's walking on the path towards Buddhahood is called a bodhisattva. As a bodhisattva with initial aspiration to the Way we may still be afflicted by vexations and also experience suffering, but we can practice being wise and compassionate, then our mind will be tranquil and peaceful and we will have fewer vexations.

"

videos.title: What's DDM's goal in activities?(GDD-0293, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Dharma Drum Mountain seeks to address the problems of our day by promoting its vision of uplifting the character of humanity and building a pure land on earth based on the spiritual environmentalism campaign, which has received much of a response from its own followers, other Buddhist groups, and society.

videos.title: How can we achieve the right balance between contending and not contending
videos.description: To achieve the right balance between contending and not contending, as well as giving and receiving, Buddhists should make a proper judgment between whether it is for the sake of personal interest or for sentient beings and Buddhism as a whole.

videos.title: Outlook of the 21st century(GDD-0295, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As technology continues to develop and become more and more advanced, our material standard of living will become better and better, but the damage to our environment and the loss and waste of our natural resources will grow more serious, and the feeling of emptiness will grow stronger. In the future people will need religion; we will need the Buddhadharma to offer us a guidance to be at peace, and a way to think about and deal with interpersonal relationships.

videos.title: How to calm an agitated mind(GDD-0296, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If there's a problem anywhere on this planet, other places will also experience related problems. First of all, we have to face reality and acknowledge that the real world is unstable. Secondly, it's very important to train ourselves to have peace of mind; once our mind is tranquil and calm, no matter how chaotic the environment is or how it changes, our mind will still be able to stay calm and collected.

videos.title: How to encourage people to practice Buddhism (GDD-0297, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To help Buddhist practitioners persevere in their practice and not give up, monasteries can train more monastics to offer care and concern activities for their devotees. Buddhist followers, when first taking up Buddhism, should take their vows seriously enough, develop the bodhi-mind, and resolve to follow the bodhisattva path. Lay practitioners can take turns organizing group practice activities in their homes, encouraging and helping each other to continue treading the way to bodhi

videos.title: Easy methods for calming our body and mind(GDD-0298, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism incorporates a variety of practices to help us calm our body and mind, and it all depends on whether we do these practices on a regular basis. In our daily lives, we can spare a certain period of time for regular practice, or, when we don't need to use our brains, recite the Buddha's name, and use Buddhist views to calm our mind.

videos.title: How should we view the dreams we have of our dead relatives or friends?(GDD-0299, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we have dreams of our deceased loved ones, the best thing that we can do for them is to recite the Buddha's name or the sutras and transfer the merit to them. This is the best way to help.

videos.title: How should Buddhists take care of their appearance ?(GDD-0300, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: While excessive adornment is unnecessary, we should take care of our appearance in an appropriate manner, partly to ensure a hygienic environment and to show respect and courtesy to others, and partly to establish an image as a means for helping sentient beings.

videos.title: How to properly dispose of old and used things(GDD-0292, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: For economic and aesthetic reasons it may make sense to replace old things with new ones, but this does a lot of damage to our natural environment. Of the goods in our everyday life we need to tell the difference between basic necessities and luxury items. The government, as well as industry and commerce, should spend money on researching a set of methods that not only allows for the collection of used plastic products, but also enables them to be recycled and reused again and again.

videos.title: How to avoid falsehood(GDD-0251, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To speak falsehood is to speak words or speak in a way that harms or hurts people and affects people negatively. Although sometimes there is a need for funny, lighthearted remarks to cheer people up, it is always a best policy to be compassionate and sincere in what we say, in order to get somebody's respect, earn somebody's trust, or make people feel we're amiable and trustworthy.

videos.title: How to find a suitable job(GDD-0252, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There is no perfect job in the world. Some people are unsure about what job would suit them best mainly because they don't understand themselves or lack a clear direction in life. Young people should take their first job as an opportunity to train their patience and perseverance, which will eventually help them earn a steady job.

videos.title: How to deal with setbacks(GDD-0253, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Dreams and goals are not the same; young people often take their dreams for goals. While it is necessary to have hope, plans, and also dreams for the future, when our dreams are not realized, we must still have peace of mind and not feel troubled, for we have gained wisdom and experience.

videos.title: Parents with teenage children(GDD-0256, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Our times may have changed and the ideas about educating children may have changed with the times, but what remains true is that family atmosphere affects the personality of the children and their psychological health. At home, parents should be kind and good-natured, if their opinions differ they must communicate and act for the welfare of the child. If the parents are kind and loving, the child will feel secure. 

"

videos.title: What attitude should young people have towards the opposite sex?(GDD-0257, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Promiscuity is an irresponsible act towards others, oneself, other people's families, and society as a whole; it can cause troublesome issues that lead to family problems and also cause problems in educating the children. We must strive to teach our children basic values and beliefs, preferably in some kind of religious belief, so that they can grow up with the relevant moral discipline and restraint.

videos.title: How do Buddhist summer camps benefit young people?(GDD-0258, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We organize Buddhist summer camps to offer children help and guidance through environmental influences on two levels. First, through group activities and very relaxed courses, we teach them basic Buddhist ideas that one should care for and help others. Secondly, we design spiritual activities such as prostrating to the Buddha, seated meditation, and reciting the Buddha's name.

videos.title: Buddhist songs for children(GDD-0259, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Music can express emotions and feelings that language cannot. Buddhist children's songs are a good way to present the teachings and spirit of Buddhism in a simple and easy to understand way that is also interesting and enjoyable to children.

videos.title: Integration of various methods of Buddhist practice(GDD-0260, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Integration of various methods of Buddhist practice cannot be done and is not necessary, in that people's preferences and aptitudes are not the same. The ideal way is to know how to choose a Dharma gate that is most suitable. Whatever we are learning or want to learn, once we have started and feel that it is good, then keep on learning it.

videos.title: Teen crimes(GDD-0261, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The problem of teen crimes can be attributed mostly to the state of our society as a whole. If we can care more for children, both our own children and other people's children,  and if parents can spend more time with their children and show more understanding for them, they will more likely become good children.

videos.title: Will eating a vegetarian diet lead to malnutrition for children?(GDD-0262, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Nowadays, not everyone is vegetarian for religious reasons. Some are vegetarians for reasons of health, and some because they care for animals. Some people are vegetarians from childhood, but their bodies don't lack anything. When our body needs something, it will take the food we have eaten and change it into whatever our body needs. As long as one is not a picky eater, one shouldn't worry that vegetarianism means poor nutrition.

videos.title: Déjà vu(GDD-0263, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"There are several kinds of dreaming: the kind in which something appears in someone's dreams because it is frequently on their mind; the kind in which something we may never have thought of or seen appears in our dreams due to the activity of our consciousness; the kind to do with one's spiritual response with a deity or spirit; and the kind as a result of one's own power of spiritual practice.

"

videos.title: How to address Buddhist clerics(GDD-0264, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: "Master," "venerable master" and "Dharma master" are all polite forms of address for Buddhist monks. It is improper to use overly respectful titles like "great master," an honorific title for the Buddha, for ordinary monastics.

videos.title: Is it right to travel far from your parents when they're still alive?(GDD-0265, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In our commercial and industrial society we may not be able to take care of our parents in the same way as people did in ancient, agricultural society by living with our parents, we should still show concern for them and provide for their care in a thorough manner.

videos.title: Why we should eat a vegetarian breakfast on a regular basis(GDD-0266, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To abstain from eating meat on certain meals or certain days as a practice is a good way to practice living a simple life with fewer desires and cultivate our compassion, thereby improving our fate, our society, and environment.

videos.title: Why there are so many Buddhas, bodhisattvas and deities in Buddhism(GDD-0267, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There are many Buddhas in the past, present, and future; Buddhahood is achieved by sentient beings. A bodhisattva is one who is in the process of going from the stage of sentient being to Buddhahood. Bodhisattvas help Buddhas and work with Buddhas to deliver sentient beings. Deities protect the Three Jewels—the Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangha—so that the Buddhadharma may be propagated smoothly and numerous beings may be delivered. That is why in monasteries of Mahayana Buddhism there are many statues of Buddhas, bodhisattvas, and deities.

videos.title: Why do some people refer to influential Buddhist groups as shantou, or "factions"?(GDD-0268)
videos.description:
"Indian Buddhism was split into twenty schools after Shakyamuni Buddha's death due to the fact that different places with different customs, different conventions, and different needs required that the application and interpretation of the Dharma be carried out from different viewpoints. Similarly, within the Buddhist community nowadays, different big monasteries or organizations may be using different means or methods to do their own things, but they share the same basic ideals and principles as Buddhist groups.
"

videos.title: How funeral arrangements should be handled if there are different religious beliefs in a family(269)
videos.description: In holding funerals, family members should show respect for their parents' faith. If the other family members aren't clear about their own faith or that of the deceased, then we Buddhists may take the initiative and advise them to hold a Buddhist funeral. Yet if they insist on their individual preferences, then it's advisable to use different rites as preferred, while Buddhist family members should hold their own delivery or prayer service for the deceased.

videos.title: Do Buddhists attach importance to celebrating birthdays?(GDD-0270, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: If we live in this world with the best intentions, do good deeds, are righteous and generous with people, and help others as much as we can, then that is the best way to celebrate our own birthdays. The true meaning to celebrate parents' birthdays is to make their lives happier and make them feel at peace by taking care of them with respect and devotion, and by being a kind and good person.

videos.title: Why does everyone want to get married in a church and not at a Buddhist temple?(GDD-0271)
videos.description: People like to have weddings in churches because they are simple, impressive and solemn. This type of atmosphere gives the couple a feeling of dignity. So as Buddhist monastics interact with lay people every day, it is necessary to design and organize impressive, solemn, and simple humanized Buddhist marriage ceremonies, to let the couple feel that they have grown, their sense of responsibility has increased, and their character has grown.

videos.title: The surnames of monastics(GDD-0272, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist monks in China all use the surname Shi derived from Shakya—Shakyamuni Buddha's clan name—which shows that they are children of Shakyamuni Buddha. We should only ask monastics their Dharma name, not their surname.

videos.title: Why is the Land of Utmost Bliss in the west?(GDD-0274, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: According to the sutras, there are innumerable Buddhas in the ten directions of the universe. The reason why Shakyamuni Buddha introduced Amitabha Buddha's Pure Land to us is that with the power of Amitabha Buddha's vows people who have firm faith in the Pure Land can be reborn there, where there are no obstacles for one's practice of the Buddha path and therefore one can achieve Buddhahood quickly and then return to this Saha World or go to other worlds to liberate sentient beings.

videos.title: (GDD-0275, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism teaches people to develop a peaceful and positive mindset with wisdom, compassion, so as to stay unaffected by external unrest and chaos. While those who truly practice the Dharma and help others to practice are too small in number, we should still make a great effort to promote Buddhism, which is of wisdom and compassion and offers stability and a sense of security, and thereby making our society more peaceful and harmonious.

videos.title: Religious literature and Buddhist books(GDD-0226, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although all the religious literature out there promotes respect for morality and encourages people to do good, wholesome deeds, Buddhist books, including the Buddhist cannon, have much more to offer in that they are all-embracing, all-inclusive, and all-transcending.

videos.title: What should we do to curb cruel forms of entertainment?(GDD-0227, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Cruelty sports and fighting games should not be encouraged because they pollute our kindness and compassion, the best parts of our humanity, and have a bad effect on children's psychological maturation. Since we hope that everyone will be able to live together in peace and harmony, we should respect and love each other by starting from our inner peace and not having cruelty in our hearts.

videos.title: Protecting wildlife(GDD-0228, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As cause and effect relationships operate in nature, the more we destroy natural ecology, the greater the price we will have to pay. From a Buddhist point of view, sentient beings are all equal. Numerous sentient beings live with us in the same world; just as human beings want to survive, we should respect the right of all wildlife to live as long as it does not threaten our life.

videos.title: Vegetarianism(GDD-0229, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People practice vegetarianism for health concerns or religious reasons. Practicing vegetarianism enables people to have a gentler and friendlier temperament, a more peaceful aura, good health, and relatively pure blood.

videos.title: How to cultivate Buddhist talent(GDD-0230, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To serve society and humanity as a whole, the Buddhist circles should nurture talent that can not only organize and lead religious activities, but also give a lecture on Buddhism. More challenging is to cultivate talent to be Dharma teachers or Chan masters. Also required is to train Buddhist monastics in different ways in order that they can fulfill tasks in different fields, including social services and education.

videos.title: How Buddhism can serve as a compass for the times(GDD-0231, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist methods and forms must change according to the times and the environment, in order to maintain its principle of enabling people to obtain wisdom and thus to cut off their own afflictions, as well as to obtain compassion and thus to help others resolve their problems and free themselves from suffering.

videos.title: Buddhism for the young generation(GDD-0232, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism is gradually gaining acceptance among the younger generation because it fulfills those who are thoughtful and contemplative in their spiritual quests. Also, Buddhism has a wide range of philosophical theories and practice methods to offer people with different educational levels and cultural backgrounds.

videos.title: Should monastics stick to practicing asceticism ？(GDD-0233, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although the Buddha encourages the ascetic practices of Buddhist monks, ascetic monks must go beg for alms among people, interacting with people and preaching the Dharma. In order for Buddhism to widely and deeply interact with people and merge into society, Buddhist practitioners should often be present in every corner of society.

videos.title: What's the correct attitude for studying Buddhism?(GDD-0234, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Correct attitude for studying Buddhism involves using the right methods of practice and having a good grasp of the essentials. Enlightenment means to let go of self-centeredness, discrimination, craving, and desire; it means detachment and freedom of body and mind and letting go of the surrounding environment or world.

videos.title: The importance of focusing deeply on one method(GDD-0235, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism emphasizes that in spiritual practice one should focus deeply on one method, be engaged in it, and practice it as best one can. Only when we have achieved sufficient mastery of one method can we then move on to something else. Otherwise we will end up getting confused and achieving nothing.

videos.title: Cherishing blessings(GDD-0236, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We are closely related to the people of ancient times, to the people in the world today, and to the people of the future; all sentient beings share a common fate. By wasting natural resources we are not only exhausting our blessings but also destroying the natural environment for our future generations; by cherishing our blessings we are actually saving them for the future.

videos.title: Avoid all that is evil, do all that is good(GDD-0237, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: While Buddhism encourages people to abstain from evil and do good deeds, its main aim is to teach people to purify their own minds. If our mind is impure, we are liable to use impure speech and perform impure physical acts at anytime. We should purify our mind by constantly remaining aware of, repenting of, and cleaning the impure thoughts in our mind.

videos.title: How can we practice the Way with perseverance?(GDD-0238, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Just as the reality that anyone who wants to achieve something significant must have patience and perseverance, we must exercise patience and work hard non-stop in our practice of the Buddha path. Though we may not be able to see immediate results, we are actually growing and making progress every day.

videos.title: The importance of shame and repentance(GDD-0239, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Shame and repentance go together and complement each other. With a sense of shame, we are able to admit our faulty behaviors. Repentance means taking responsibility for our faults. By having the sense of shame and repenting, we show our willingness to shoulder responsibility and are determined not to repeat the same mistake, and thereby eradicating our karmic hindrances.

videos.title: How to make our progress along the path of cultivation(GDD-0240, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we encounter adversity in our spiritual practice, we shouldn't always suppose it is a demon, but should take it as a kind of training, something we inevitably have to go through when we are making progress. Most of the time, the demonic state reflects the demons of our own mind, such as when we have imaginary fears due to suspicion or when we want to get something for nothing.

videos.title: How to set up a Buddhist altar at home(GDD-0241, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From the Buddhist perspective, the question of having an altar at home or not is not a problem. If there is enough room in the house and the conditions allow then it's very good to have a altar or shrine. Most importantly is to have an image of the Buddha in our mind, keep the Buddha in our mind and act in line with the Buddha's teachings.

videos.title: Taking refuge(GDD-0242, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Taking refuge means to identify with, accept and depend upon the Three Jewels—the Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangha. By taking refuge in the Three Jewels we are affirming and declaring ourselves a Buddhist, and making a vow to follow Buddhism, using the Buddhist concepts and methods to guide us and help us to progress along the bodhisattva path.

videos.title: How can young people help themselves and make their contribution?(GDD-0243, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Young people may feel worried or panic-stricken when first entering the job market, which is like entering a new world. Entering this new stage of life, new graduates should mentally prepare themselves and not set their ideals too high. The priority consideration is to find a job, one we can live on and gain our foothold in and make a contribution in, with which we can gradually work towards the future.

videos.title: How should we help young people to embrace good values?(GDD-0244, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we seek personal gain and interest, we must think beyond ourselves and consider the benefits of others. In Buddhism we should encourage young people to understand the purpose and value of human existence, and to use wisdom and hard work to make contributions to society and take making a contribution as their goal and value of life.

videos.title: How do we instill proper religious views in young people?(GDD-0245, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To help children and young people truly know Buddhism, we must begin with the parents. At home parents can encourage children to worship the Buddha, recite Amitabha Buddha's name or the Bodhisattva's name (Avalokitesvara or Ksitigarbha), and tell them that the purpose is to seek wisdom and compassion. Monasteries can help in this respect by providing children's class.

videos.title: How we can learn to achieve the carefree ease of "non-striving"(GDD-0247, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although competing and striving is an ingrained habit of humans, what makes us humans truly human is the fact that we have wisdom, rationality, and feelings, and can always use education to transform our habits and character. It's very important to affirm our own value ourselves, no matter how much we can contribute, no matter how much we understand and whatever we have achieved. Being able to admit and face defeat or failure is also self-affirmation.

videos.title: How we may avoid becoming the slaves of our craving(GDD-0248, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The desire to satisfy our wants or excessive, superfluous demands is craving. After satisfying our basic needs to make a living, we should have a greater desire by having hope for everybody, for the everlasting good of a greater environment.

videos.title: How to become a contented person(GDD-0249, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: True contentedness means that all those material things, worldly possessions, desires and cravings are no longer important to us. We should train ourselves to be content by having few desires, and live a more fulfilled life by using our wisdom and our physical strength to help other people and by making efforts to contribute to society.

videos.title: How we can become unselfish(GDD-0250, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Smart selfishness is the kind that benefits oneself but also benefits others. The most reliable way to be "selfish" is to benefit oneself by benefiting others. In terms of bodhisattva practice, the primary goal is to benefit others; yet in the process as we benefit others, we also benefit themselves.

videos.title: Only well-measured practice is the middle way(GDD-0201, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In spiritual practice, we shouldn't ask for too many results at a time, and we mustn't work too hard or be too sluggish. For personal practice, we must deeply practice just one Dharma method, instead of trying to be adept at many things in one go. In fact, once we have successfully practiced one method, we will be able to penetrate all others.

videos.title: How to carefully select a site for Dharma practice(GDD-0202, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we first try to practice Buddhism, we have to overcome our mental obstacles by making a firm resolve. Then we need to spare time for practice by cutting back on not very important socializing, and by stopping idling away our time. Finally, choose a suitable Dharma practice center that teaches and practices the correct Buddhadharma.

videos.title: What constitutes a world religion(GDD-0203, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A world religion is a religion that is not only accepted by a large number of people, but can continue to be passed on through the ages of history; it is not just widespread, but can stand the test of time. A true world religion must remain everlastingly fresh and new, and be able to make adjustments in their ideas, forms or methods when time requires it.

videos.title: The difference between Mahayana and Hinayana Buddhism(GDD-0204, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In Shakyamuni Buddha's time, Buddhism had not split into Mahayana and Hinayana, though Mahayana ideas were already circulating. The distinction between Mahayana and Hinayana and their later developments reflect the different ways of interpreting the Buddha's ideas and the precepts. While Hinayana Buddhism is a conservative form of Buddhism that adheres to Pali scriptures and the Buddha's original teachings, Mahayana Buddhism emphasizes the Bodhisattva spirit in delivering senting beings and transforming the world.

videos.title: Where exactly are the pure lands?(GDD-0205, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although the idea of rebirth in Amitabha Buddha's Pure Land is much encouraged in Shakyamuni Buddha's teachings, the fundamental philosophy of pure land all comes down to the cultivation of a pure mind, a state of mind that is free of greed, hatred, and ignorance.

videos.title: Why academics value Buddhism?(GDD-0206, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In Buddhism, theory and practice are supposed to join together, instead of turning Buddhism into an academic discipline without involving cultivation and faith. By simultaneously studying, practicing, and cultivating, we are more able to truly understand Buddhism, and truly discover the essence of Buddhism or what Buddhism's advantages are.

videos.title: Giving up grasping(GDD-0207, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The mind of grasping is a mind that always looks outward and pursues things in the external world. Buddhism offers us methods to train ourselves to lessen such a mind, help us to concentrate our mind so that it becomes quiet and peaceful. By grasping less at external things, our mind won't be so distracted and confused and therefore we can store up our mental and physical energy for meaningful work.

videos.title: How we can lead a life of abundance(GDD-0208, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: After satisfying our basic needs for living, we should seek spiritual satisfaction. Religious satisfaction is a form of spiritual satisfaction that is relatively easy to achieve; as long as we have faith and actually practice accordingly we will feel that we are secure and our life is blessed with abundance. The most reliable satisfaction to obtain is when we give of ourselves to benefit others.

videos.title: Karmic power and the unconscious(GDD-0209, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In terms of psychology, the unconscious is not something that we can control or are aware of, while karmic power, a Buddhist concept similar to the unconscious, is a kind of power produced by our actions in countless past lives, which we can change our karma by understanding its source and not letting it grow.

videos.title: Emptiness and psychodynamics(GDD-0210, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The consciousness-only theory in Buddhism is a study of psychological analysis, which analyzes the mind in great detail. Ego, in Buddhism, is a tendency to cling to an illusion and is constantly changing, and so it is a false or delusory self. Buddhism advocates no-self, a true self that is free of any kind of attachment and realizes emptiness, meaning neither existence nor non-existence.

videos.title: Having few desires and being content (GDD-0211, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism teaches that life is suffering, including the suffering of not getting what one wants. The antidote is to have few desires beyond one's own needs and be content with what one absolutely needs for daily use.

videos.title: Mundane dharmas - worldly phenomena (GDD-0212, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism teaches that mundane and supramundane dharmas are one and the same. The Platform Sutra states, "Buddhadharma is of this world, and is to be experienced without leaving it. To leave this world to seek enlightenment is like searching a rabbit for its horns." The world gives us a point toward which to apply our efforts, to practice living our lives without feeling distressed or afflicted. This is called transcending the world.

videos.title: The Buddhist concept of karmic causality (GDD-0213, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism looks at the process of life in the context of the past, present, and future lives. For good and bad karma that was sown in the past, we will receive the karmic results in this present life or in future lives. By accepting this law of karmic causality, we can face reality bravely and willingly, and, additionally, maintain infinite hope for the future.

videos.title: The true meaning of the Buddhadharma (GDD-0214, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhadharma is not separated from mundane dharmas and all dharmas of the mundane world are the Buddhadharma. As long as we see through things and perceive them as empty, and are therefore not attached to them at all, then we can be free of the affliction and attain liberation from the sea of suffering.

videos.title: The true meaning of one's urge to climb higher (GDD-0215, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The urge to climb higher reflects a human instinct to survive and develop. We should combine this instinct with our spiritual dimension and go beyond, emulating the spirit of the bodhisattva and seeking growth by contributing ourselves.

videos.title: How we can avoid letting our ego get inflated (GDD-0216, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: An inflated ego is illusory and impractical as personal successes are not achieved single-handedly, but are the result of a multitude of factors. We should constrain ourselves by thinking that even if we achieve something extraordinary that contributes to the whole nation or the whole world, it is actually brought about by the blessings arising from the merit of all sentient beings.

videos.title: The difference between traditional and new religions (GDD-0217, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The formation of new religions is a very natural development in response to the needs of our time, the needs of modern people in a new environment. Although some new religions or religious sects may tend to think and act erroneously, they help spur traditional Buddhism to reform and modernize, while its basic principles remain unchanged.

videos.title: The importance of religious education (GDD-0218, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Religious education, in terms of nurturing qualified religious teachers, is important in that it ensures a religion's development and its dissemination in a pure and orthodox form, and it also helps a religion to offer its services to society, contributing to the welfare of society.

videos.title: Compassionate aid, culture and spiritual practice (GDD-0219, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The three areas of compassionate aid, cultural education, and spiritual practice are all necessary for Buddhism as a whole. Compassionate aid represents the practice of giving; cultural education nurtures talent to spread and share the message; and spiritual practice refines and elevates our spirit.

videos.title: Outer paths (GDD-0220, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Instead of referring to heresy, "outer path" means seeking spiritual or material assistance from a source outside oneself. Buddhism teaches about realizing the mind and seeing the nature from within because the fundamental Buddha nature lies in the mind. However, outer paths can always serve as a way through which one learns to let go of one's original clinging mind.

videos.title: The importance of being able to identify true religious books (GDD-0221, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Though some occult sciences or folk religions do share a common basis with higher forms of religion, they lack the features, contents, and functions to be a religion. A Buddhist should solely rely on the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and should not follow unorthodox cults or outer-path ways, which cannot give up clinging to the self and embrace the concepts of impermanence and no-self.

videos.title: Buddhist perspective on rights and equality (GDD-0222, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Regarding equality, the Buddha taught that all sentient beings possess the intrinsic wisdom of the Buddha, and that, in teaching his monastic disciples, when one was willing to leave the household life to practice the path one could become an arhat, whether one was a man or a woman. On the issue of shared rights, the Buddha taught that every person has the same human dignity and everybody is equal, although they may be receiving different education and are assigned different tasks.

videos.title: How Buddhists can both be engaged in the world and transcend it (GDD-0223, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: One can be engaged in the world while transcending it regardless of one's physical location. It all lies in whether one can serve society and help solve problems of the world while living a life that accords with the standards of the Dharma, without creating disorder and being possessive of worldly things and affairs.

videos.title: Mystical experience (GDD-0224, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Mystical experiences may happen as a production of one's personal spiritual cultivation or come from an external force.
