Mystical experiences can help develop one's self-confidence and enhance one's faith in one's religion and teacher, on the premise that such powers or experiences are not violating the law of karmic causality.

videos.title: Learning to let go in life(GDD-0176, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Human beings always hope for increase. Real addition means that, while one may be gaining more fame, status, power, and wealth, one should also grow in merit, wisdom, and compassion. Otherwise, it is like taking more and more money out of a bank account, with the account balance getting smaller and smaller.

videos.title: The true meaning of universal love(GDD-0177, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism encourages the kind of love for all humanity, for all sentient beings, or, in Buddhist terms, unconditioned compassion. As the Diamond Sutra teaches, ""Without dwelling in anything whatsoever, allow this mind to arise,"" one should help others without thought of helping others and expecting anything in return.

videos.title: The true meaning of a practical life(GDD-0178, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To live a practical life is to cherish our life in the here and now, treasuring the time and environment we have and using them wisely, such as reciting the Buddha's name, doing good deeds, spreading the Buddhadharma, taking part in volunteer work, engaging in social service, and showing concern for people in general. While it is important to work when it's time to work, we should also rest when it's time to rest and relax when it's time to relax.

videos.title: Realizing the value of  life(GDD-0179, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The value of life depends on how we use our lives. If what we want are positive values, we must use our bodily, verbal, and mental actions to achieve sufficient growth in our morals, character, and humanity.

videos.title: How to break through the stifling distress that engulfs our lives(GDD-0180, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Shakyamuni Buddha taught us that life is suffering. Buddhism is to resolve the suffering of our world by offering people with Buddhist concepts and methods to deal with and transform the suffering.

videos.title: Following your conscience(GDD-0181, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Moral intuition or conscience often clashes with human desire. Because we are human beings and not animals, we have to safeguard our conscience and not to abandon it and nurture our desires. It takes practice to maintain a conscience and use our conscience to judge.

videos.title: Cultivating moral courage(GDD-0182, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The reckless courage of the ordinary people is just bravery that lacks wisdom, the courage of those who do not know themselves, while the moral courage taught in Buddhism is the kind that shoulders all the burdens that no one else can bear, with patience, perseverance, and a profound mind.

videos.title: An untainted mind(GDD-0183, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From a Buddhist standpoint, we bring the contamination with us at birth due to our beginningless ignorance, so our mind may impulsively give rise to emotions and desires in any circumstance. We can just tell ourselves to calm down and relax our mind, making it less susceptible to external environment.

videos.title: How to become more broadminded(GDD-0184, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To develop a broad mind, we can learn to regard time and space as everlasting and endless. With this breadth of mind, we will be able to let go of our ego, embrace and be more tolerant of all people and all situations, thereby attaining the sense of ease and freedom.

videos.title: A peaceful mind(GDD-0185, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A peaceful mind, or an "ordinary mind" in terms of Chan Buddhism, is the state of mind unaffected by external situations and therefore free of fluctuation or inner conflicts, while remaining clearly aware of whatever there is in our surroundings.

videos.title: Taking control of our mind(GDD-0186, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When we don't have a firm standpoint and a clear direction, we have no control of our own mind. By practicing spiritually, cultivating insight and concentration, we will know our direction and standpoint better and therefore become more aware and gain mastery of our own mind.

videos.title: How to realize non-self(GDD-0187, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To realize non-self, we must first let go of a foolish and selfish self that seeks temporary benefit and advantage for ourselves but causes others to suffer losses, and then practice  doing meritorious deeds without calculating whether we will gain any merit, and regard it as something we should do.

videos.title: Contemplating the impurities of the body(GDD-0188, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The practice of mindfulness of the body as impure is to help us eliminate our clinging to the self. Though our body is impure and unclean, it is a useful tool with which we can practice the way of bodhisattva, cultivating merit and wisdom. We still have to protect it and keep it healthy so it can serve its proper purposes.

videos.title: Mindfulness of sensation as suffering(GDD-0189, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The practice of contemplating our sensation, or feelings, as suffering is to make us aware that in this world suffering is the rule, while joy is a temporary exception. By having fewer desires and being content, we can minimize our cravings for the pursuit of all kinds of desires, and eventually attain liberation, which is the eternal joy.

videos.title: Mindfulness of the impermanence of the mind(GDD-0190, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The mind of the average person is afflicted by greed, aversion, and ignorance and therefore is deluded and impermanent, while the Buddha mind, or the pure mind, is marked by selfless wisdom and compassion and therefore is an unchanging mind. By changing our afflicted mind into a mind of wisdom, we are actually turning impermanence into infinite hope and creating a brighter future.

videos.title: Mindfulness of dharmas as without self(GDD-0191, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To contemplate all phenomena as without a self is to contemplate that our physiological and psychological phenomena and all the material phenomena in our environment are constantly changing. By letting go of our ego or selfish self we will realize the true self, turning the small self into the infinite self, the greater self, which is eternal.

videos.title: The importance of observing the precepts(GDD-0192, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist precepts serve as the standard of action for a person and a fundamental moral code for the exemplary Buddhist. They were designed to protect our bodily health, to preserve the harmony of our households, and to ensure the tranquility of society.

videos.title: The importance of cultivating firm-mindedness(GDD-0193, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In spiritual practice, it is very important to choose one Dharma method and stick to it, believing it to be the best. This gives the practitioner a strong footing and confidence and therefore can be truly beneficial.

videos.title: How to develop our wisdom(GDD-0194, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Knowledge is not necessarily wisdom. Wisdom means objectivity and freedom from self-centeredness. We gain wisdom by reading the sutras and listening to the Buddhadharma.

videos.title: The relationship between Buddhism and politics(GDD-0195, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Shakyamuni Buddha travelled among different countries in ancient India to teach the Dharma, hoping to help those countries by influencing their political systems with the ten virtues. Today, Buddhists should know no national borders and not be divided along party lines in applying the Dharma to help humanity and society.

videos.title: Buddhists' stance on participating in politics(GDD-0196, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Nowadays Buddhists should show concern for political affairs while applying Buddhist concepts and the principles of compassion and wisdom. Compassion allows us to be tolerant of people who hold different views. With wisdom we can develop and utilize all the human, social, and political resources in our community, thereby benefitting society.

videos.title: Can monastics involve in politics?(GDD-0197, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist monks can and should serve as elected representatives, to express their own views and share their beliefs with the entire nation so that they will be duly considered, accepted and implemented, thereby benefitting our country and our society.

videos.title: What are we really so busy for?(GDD-0198, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We have to work hard to insure our own future prospects by achieving merit and virtue, as a way to take responsibility for the past and the future. In addition, we have to work hard to help and benefit all the myriad sentient beings in the universe by using our wisdom and compassion.

videos.title: What attitude we should have when facing the onslaught of disease(GDD-0199, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The "four sufferings" of birth, aging, sickness, and death are inevitable. While finding ways to adjust both our body and mind to improve our health, we should be aware and mentally prepared for disease and death. When our hour has come, we should set our mind at rest and go happily and joyfully to the Pure Land of Amitabha.

videos.title: Starting Dharma practice at a young age(GDD-0200, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Any undertaking has to be started in one's youth so as to lay a solid foundation. We should not wait until we are old to study Buddhism, but should start to practice the moment we hear about the Dharma. Nowadays it's easier than ever to go about learning and practicing the Buddhadharma, so we want to do that while we can by making the most of our spare time and holidays to get into contact with Buddhism.

videos.title: Is "Buddhism of the human world" against Buddhist tradition? (GDD-151, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Buddhism is meant to solve major human problems of birth, aging, sickness, and death. It is to be practiced in daily life so that we can live without fear and with a sense of security and stability, and that people can live peacefully with each other and care for each other.


"

videos.title: Buddhist music (GDD-152, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Music is a basic and universal tool for communicating emotions and, in terms of its positive aspect, can alleviate people's emotional tension. Similarly, Buddhist chanting or music, being pure, peaceful, joyous and harmonious, helps purify people's emotions.

videos.title: How we can be contented with a simple life to seek inner joy (GDD-153, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Though it is very hard for us to return to simplicity living in modern society, if we can keep a piece of simple and pure nature in our mind by cutting down our wants and having fewer desires, we can still contribute to the protection and conservation of our natural environment.
."

videos.title: How to live a convenient life in a sustainable manner? (Environmental protection) (GDD-154)
videos.description:
"To convenience ourselves but end up inconveniencing others or causing long-term aftereffects is actually to sow bad karmic seeds, harming ourselves and others in the future. Since the garbage problem has become very serious now, if we can create less of garbage and less waste we will be doing a meritorious deed by cutting down on pollution for the benefit of society. 

"

videos.title: How can Ch'an practice be applied in education (GDD-155, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Ch'an practice or meditation as a way to relax and train our body and mind is worth promoting in that it enables us to become gentler and milder in temperament, stronger and more stable in their personality. 
"

videos.title: Living in the present (GDD-156, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"With more and more information and knowledge to occupy our minds nowadays, it's all the more important to make best use of our time. Living in the present, appreciateing the present, and enjoying the present is actually the most economical way to use the time.
"

videos.title: How should women plan their life? (GDD-157, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"The times, society, and family structures may have changed, men and women cannot exchange their natural roles. In terms of work in society and intellectual ability, women and men should be equal, but in terms of taking care of children and home, women have more patience, resilience, endurance and they are more stable and better equipped.


"

videos.title: How can women face up to karma and eliminate obstacles? (GDD-158, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Karmic obstruction means our evil karma that has accumulated in past lives and our occupation that keeps us from taking up the teachings of the Buddhadharma. We should be broad-mined or use psychological concepts to make adjustments and not lose hope.


"

videos.title: How to become a graceful, modern beauty (GDD-159, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Exterior beauty without internal substance is only superficial and false beauty. True face with honesty, sincerity, and compassion in mind is the beauty within, and therefore the genuine beauty. Beauty and ugliness are determined in the mind, not by one's outward appearance.

"

videos.title: How to pursue a bright, beautiful, and fulfilling marriage (GDD-160, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Husband and wife are two distinct people from different backgrounds and so may have different ways of thinking about children, home, finances, careers, and how to deal with things. Husband and wife should respect each other, learn from each other, forgive and be understanding towards each other, and care for each other.
 "

videos.title: How can one emerge from the game of pursuit of wealth(GDD-161, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Pursuing wealth for individual self-interest will bring harm to oneself and others. Instead, by seeking wealth for all society or all human beings without harming others, we are cultivating blessings and accumulating merit. 

"

videos.title: A look at "life plan" from the Buddhist perspective(GDD-162, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Life planning should cover endless lives and go beyond the material aspect. We can plan our life by setting a direction for the growth of our spiritual cultivation and realizing where our talents lie, our qualities and abilities, and what our resources are.
"

videos.title: The correct way to view and care for our body to make use of it for spiritual practice(GDD-163)
videos.description:
"Though Buddhism teaches us not to be attached to our physical body, it is a tool for the practice of the Way, a medium through which we cultivate wisdom. We should use it properly, and care for it by protecting our physical health through doing exercises, sitting meditation, or simply relaxing our body and mind at any time or place.
"

videos.title: How can we elude the temptations and fetters of material indulgence(GDD-164, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"The higher the level of spiritual involvement in one's life, the lower one's degree of dependence on material goods. However, to do without material things completely is not something Buddhism advocates. Our use of material should be appropriate to who we are, suitable for the situation we are in, and suitable for the time.
 
"

videos.title: How to attain freedom and ease in emotions(GDD-0165, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There are three levels of emotion: passing moods, feelings, and noble sentiments. Buddhism encourages the elimination of passing moods, and the harmonization, purification, and exaltation of rationality and emotion, thereby developing compassion and wisdom.

videos.title: Interpersonal skills(GDD-0166, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The suffering of meeting the hated and the suffering of parting with the beloved reflect the affliction we have in our interpersonal relationships. Buddhism helps us deal with these problems by teaching us to let go of our self-centeredness through repentance and transference of merit.

videos.title: The art of work(GDD-0167, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As a responsibility to contribute to society in which we help each other to live and exist, we should employ "ordinary mind" to do what we should, what we can, and what we are given to do, while seeking to improve ourselves by constantly learning from more capable or talented people.

videos.title: How to transcend the things that happen to us in life (GDD-0168, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When our mind changes with the environment, then it is subject to afflictions. We should be the master of our own mind by not being affected by the situations or circumstances we are in, while seeking to improve the environment from an impartial perspective and with a broad mind.

videos.title: How to build self-confidence(GDD-0169, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Fame, status, wealth, power and influence do not help us to build confidence. To build true confidence, one must not be affected by wealth or poverty, high or low status, and life or death, and have a right understanding of ourselves.

videos.title: Why can't success, wealth, power, and status bring us happiness?(GDD-0170, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: According to Confucius, those who can establish merit, virtue, or words are successful people. In terms of Buddhism, those who can achieve peace of mind are also successful people, and attaining Buddhahood is the greatest success.

videos.title: How to find our true self(GDD-0171, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Most people have misconception of the self and therefore become the slaves of the external environment. To find our true self is to learn to be our own master and govern our mind, while trying our best to do what we can, learn what we should learn, and continually correct ourselves.

videos.title: How to own up to our mistakes (GDD-0172, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To encourage people to own up to their own mistakes, we must accept responsibility for our mistakes and also accept other people's admission of their mistakes. By bravely owning up when we make a mistake, we will be more able to avoid repeating the same mistake, which is the true meaning of repentance.

videos.title: How to transcend the basic human desires for food and sex(GDD-0173, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To truly transcend our self, we must constantly make progress by letting go of our views, affirm, encourage, and recognize others by letting go of our self-centeredness, as well as give of ourselves without thinking of getting anything back.

videos.title: How to cope when one loses his social status(GDD-0174, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Social status actually means the roles one plays in society and should be regarded from the angle of equality, and not from the point of view of its differences. As long as one plays one' roles appropriately and fulfills their respective duties, then one already has a social status and will be approved by society.

videos.title: The pursuit of freedom and dignity (GDD-0175, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Instead of trying to obtain freedom and dignity from outside ourselves, we should earn them by first giving others their freedom and acting like we deserve our dignity, instead of trying to extend our own individuality and fighting for dignity.

videos.title: How to choose  a suitable "Dharma-gate," or method of practice, for oneself(GDD-126)
videos.description:
"The most suitable Dharma-gate is the one we come into contact with and are using right now, which we should believe to be the best. One can make small adjustments on the spiritual path, but one shouldn't frequently change one's spiritual path, for the most effective and reliable practice should be a deep commitment to one single Dharma-gate. 

  "

videos.title: The ritual of taking refuge in the Three Jewels(GDD-127, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Though reading sutras or practicing the Dharma by oneself can be beneficial, it is not as good as  having taken refuge in the three jewels in that it marks one's aspiration to learn the Buddhadharma in its true sense from a source of transmission, and a collective spirit to enhance one's spiritual practice.

"

videos.title: Individual vs. group cultivation(GDD-128, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhist term "seven classes of disciples" indicates that Buddhism has always encouraged group cultivation, in which practitioners can encourage and correct each other and thus help each other grow better, faster, as well benefit from wise teachers and fellow practitioners spiritually.

videos.title: The difference between creating and dispelling karmic ties(GDD-129, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To form good karmic ties with all sentient beings is to aid them through the Buddhadharma, in which we use the Dharma to help others help themselves or use material objects to release other people's suffering unconditionally.

videos.title: The difference between a Buddha's and a Bodhisattva's deliverance(GDD-130, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A bodhisattva is an enlightened sentient being, who benefits himself and others in leaving behind afflictions, gaining wisdom, and ultimately attaining Buddhahood. While a buddha is perfect in both blessings and wisdom, one who has realized no-self and delivers sentient beings without thinking there are any to deliver.

videos.title: Freeing captive animals—its meaning and methods(GDD-131, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: It is best for animals to live in natural environments, so animal protection or preservation is a better way for the purpose of protecting lives, instead of releasing captive animals into an environment in which they cannot survive.

videos.title: How to face predicaments and overcome obstacles in our lives(GDD-132, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From the Buddhist perspective, life is suffering and the process from birth till death is all surrounded by difficulties. We should face this reality of life with mental preparation and a positive way of thinking, taking it as a necessary training to aid our development.

videos.title: How to lead a rational emotional life(GDD-133, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A rational emotional life is one with emotions and rationality in harmony. If we are stuck with an emotional problem, we should use the Buddhadharma to channel our mind and have a new way of thinking so as to overcome the problem.

videos.title: The meaning of work(GDD-134, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Having a job means having the means to sustain our daily living and a way to contribute to society in which people work to produce the living environment and conditions we enjoy. We should take going to work as performing a service to society and forming good karmic affinities with others, which will in turn increase our own blessings.

videos.title: How to achieve eternal spiritual liberation(GDD-135, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism teaches about impermanence, meaning that there is nothing truly eternal and unchanging. The ultimate meaning of eternal is to face reality and live our lives in a down-to-earth way, remain clear and free of any vexation or affliction, and develop faith to sustain our spirituality.

videos.title: The meaning of demonic tests(GDD-136, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Except for the demon of death, the other three types of demon reflect our own mental afflictions or unrighteous thoughts. So the best way to avoid demonic obstacles is to try our best to cultivate the path, maintain right views, and use correct methods of practice.

videos.title: Should one have faith in the sutras?(GDD-137, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist sutras are records of the Buddha's teachings in different places and with different people, and therefore have different effects. Although the sutras are not necessarily all the words of the Buddha, they all represent the basic Buddhist principles and so are useful and beneficial.

videos.title: Are the Buddhist sutras really difficult to read and understand?(GDD-138, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist special terms are what make Buddhist sutras seem difficult to understand. Any person can understand the sutras if they really want to understand them. As long as we are willing to spend time to learn and understand, we will get to know what they mean.

videos.title: Is Buddhism a pessimistic, world-weary religion?(GDD-139, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The reason why Buddhism teaches that everything in this world is suffering is to encourage people to transcend the world and attain liberation by devoting themselves to the world, practicing the Dharma, following the path to enlightenment, and cultivating bodhisattva practices.

videos.title: The true meaning of kalpa(GDD-140, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A kalpa is a vast unit of time to measure the coming and going of a world system. Though our world will come to its kalpa of destruction and eventually the kalpa of emptiness, we need not worry but should practice diligently in order to be reborn in the Western World of Ultimate Bliss.

videos.title: Is praying really useful?(GDD-141, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism shares many functions of other great religions, but it is also a philosophy and a form of practical ethics we should practice ourselves in order to achieve liberation and attain Buddhahood, the ultimate goal of practicing Buddhism. Prayer serves as an aid to this purpose and whether it is useful or not all depends on our sincerity and faith.

videos.title: Should we take the advice of  Buddhist masters with a grain of salt?(GDD-142, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism centers on the Three Jewels: Buddha, Dharma, Sangha. Buddhism has three criteria: rely on the Dharma, not those who teach it; rely on the spirit, not the letter; rely on the ultimate meaning, not any provisional truth; rely on wisdom, not merely intellectual understanding. These four are called the "four reliances.

videos.title: What role does Buddhism play in the effort of purifying people's minds?(GDD-143, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Purifying people's minds is the basis for purifying the environment and society. Buddhism helps purify human minds by offering concepts and methods of practice to improve people's family lives, enhance individual character, and influence society in a positive way.

videos.title: The true meaning of emptiness(GDD-144, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In Buddhism, ""emptiness"" means that all phenomena, either material or psychological, are not eternal and unchanging. Therefore we should remain undisturbed by them in our minds and don't fall victim to all kinds of negative, contaminated mental reactions.

videos.title: What distinguishes Buddhism from other religions?(GDD-145, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism speaks of causes and conditions instead of a Creator God, or the idea that God created the universe. It acknowledges the existence of deities, ghosts, and all kinds of spirits, considers them as various types of sentient beings, and sees them equally.

videos.title: Is the law of karmic cause and effect applicable in the present time?(GDD-146, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Karmic force means the effect of our bodily, mental, and verbal actions performed in the past. The law of karmic cause and effect spanning the three periods, namely the past, the present, and the future, actually points us toward hope, tells us not to despair, and helps us experience peace of mind.

videos.title: Using correct religious concepts to help purify society(GDD-147, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist principles of moral thought and action can be incorporated in school education in terms of civic or social education, in order to help improve social climate and the way of the world by purifying people's minds.

videos.title: Can the Buddhadharma and medical theory complement each other?(GDD-148, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddhadharma helps us face and accept illness with peace of mind and hope through the transformation of our psychological feeling. Without suffering in our mind, our physical illnesses will ease and even be cured.

videos.title: How does the Buddhadharma explain impermanence?(GDD-149, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Impermanence is the reality of phenomena in the process of time, where good and bad alternate. It teaches us to be aware and alert with a sense of crisis and preparedness, while living our lives with content.

videos.title: Buddhist householder and a non-Buddhist householder(GDD-0150, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Lay practitioners can certainly practice Buddhism in a family setting by learning the bodhisattva's way, developing wisdom by not being vexed by problems in life and cultivating compassion by showing care and love to their family members.

videos.title: How do we choose our Chan practice teachers?(GDD-101, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Most people do need a Chan Practice teacher. They should find a teacher with correct understanding of Buddhism, sound practice, with a clear mind and good skills in guiding others.

videos.title: The meaning of Drop the butcher's knife and immediately become a Buddha (GDD-102, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Everyone has an innate buddha-nature and has the potential to become a buddha. As long as we stop doing evil and start to practice the six paramitas (six perfections), we are heading toward the Buddhahood.

videos.title: The purpose of sutra recitation and mantra chanting(GDD-103, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There are two functions of reciting the sutras and mantras. It helps us to self-reflect whether our acts are in accord with the sutras. It is also a meditation practice.

videos.title: Must Ch'an practice always involve sitting meditation?(GDD-104, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Ch'an practice is to train our mind to be calm, quiet, and pure so that we can be liberated from afflictive emotions. Practicing concentration starts from contemplation and a right mindfulness, and it doesn't have to involve sitting down in meditation.

videos.title: Is pilgrimage is a form of practice?(GDD-105, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: As a way of practice, pilgrimage is a sacred journey of worship to pay respect rather than sightsee. It helps develop our faith and encourage us to live out the spirit of the Buddha or Bodhisattva.

videos.title: The merits of giving (GDD-106, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Giving with expectations of future rewards is a merit with outflows and can only lead to blessings for human and heavenly beings. While giving without seeking anything in return is a Buddhist virtue that will help one transcend samsara and attain great liberation.

videos.title: Contention (GDD-107, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Fighting comes from greed and desire. Selfish desires are insatiable and will only bring affliction. Instead we should turn them into purified desires, as a vow to benefit both ourselves and others.

videos.title: Competition (GDD-108, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Competitiveness has its own positive function in that it brings out our right efforts and urges us to work harder and strive for better. But at the meantime we should also avoid either arrogance or the sense of inferiority and simply give our best effort.

videos.title: How to deal with envy and jealousy (GDD-109, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A fundamental affliction in terms of Buddhism, jealousy has to do with anger or hatred in that people tend to feel that if they don't get what they want, then nobody else should get it either. The remedy to jealousy is to practice rejoicing in others' meritorious deeds, and the best way to avoid being envied is to be modest.

videos.title: Anger and hatred (GDD-110, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Anger and hatred make us lose our wisdom and calmness. Instead we should try to improve our own situation and change our mindset with spiritual practice, and to be kind and compassionate toward ourselves and all sentient beings.

videos.title: Can visiting Buddhist monasteries and eminent monks be considered spiritual practice?(GDD-111)
videos.description: Visiting Buddhist monasteries and eminent monks to learn different methods of practice is good, reliable, and useful only under the condition that it is done through a wise teacher's advice and guidance.

videos.title: How to enhance the quality of life(GDD-112, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Talking about the quality of living without taking actions to enrich our spiritual life will be empty. To improve the quality of living, we must have a cultural, spiritual, and religious life. But only religious belief, practice, and experience with faith can provide a truly fulfilling life.
 

"

videos.title: Success and failure(GDD-113, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"There is no such thing as true success in this world; there is only the process. Success and failure are just an illusion; it all depends on the causes and conditions. Instead of pursuing success we should simply have a direction for which we can put forth our efforts without expecting and being attached to the result.
"

videos.title: How does Buddhadharma account for disability?(GDD-114, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Events of this life are karmic results from our actions of past lives. For the disabled who have accepted the Buddhist concept, we can tell them to practice and repent so that their karmic hindrances will diminish. Otherwise we should encourage them to regard themselves as bodhisattvas manifesting in this world as a model to influence others in a positive way. 


"

videos.title: How do we overcome an external limitation, and restore our internal faith?(GDD-115)
videos.description:
"Some people may be handicapped, but their mental capacities are exactly the same as everyone else's. Through psychological guidance and religious faith, one can transform one's perceptions and be a healthy person by maintaining a healthy mind and outlook.
"

videos.title: Resolving attachment, hatred, passion and resentment(GDD-116, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Mental and emotional afflictions come from our attachment to our feelings and thinking. We should resolve such afflictions by understanding karmic causality as well as the working of causes and conditions. 
"

videos.title: How to transcend birth, aging, illness and death(GDD-117, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism teaches that birth, aging, sickness, and death are all suffering in that they are changing, false image. Even when there is joy it is transient and not forever. To transcend samsara we should prepare our savings of merit to be born in Amitabha Buddha's Pure Land of Ultimate Bliss, our final settling place.

videos.title: How to achieve the state of one-pointed concentration(GDD-118, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"All Buddhist sects in China advocate recitation of Buddha's name for it is the simplest method for spiritual practice, which is proven to be effective to the greatest number of people and has been most commonly used. Buddha-name recitation brings numerous benefits: spiritual response, protection from Dharma-protecting deities, elimination of evil thoughts, peace of mind and body, benefits in the present life, rebirth to Amitabha's Pure Land.
"

videos.title: Practicing Buddhism(GDD-119, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Whether we will make progress in our practice of Buddhism  depends on our willpower and willingness. To keep practicing diligently we can constantly relive our initial aspiration for bodhi or enlightenment and keep pushing forward. Every step forward in the process equals an accomplishment, and we are reaping the benefits while we are practicing.
"

videos.title: How to enhance and purify love(GDD-120, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism advocates the ultimate form of love, which is causeless compassion, or unconditional compassion. To practice unconditional compassion is to practice giving or show concern to others on an equal basis without expecting any payback or reward.

videos.title: The merits of reciting sutras(GDD-121, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Reciting sutras benefits oneself and one's family and represents spreading the teachings of the Buddhadharma. It can also benefit other sentient beings who are hearing the recitation. Its ultimate purpose is that we observe the teachings of the sutra and act accordingly.

videos.title: The meaning of sutras(GDD-122, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"In general, the essential teachings of the sutras are about the analysis of the mind and the resolution of affliction. The whole Buddhist canon contains a massive collection of sutras, but their basic principles are ""suffering, emptiness, impermanence and selflessness,"" and their main idea is to help us attain liberation from the sea of samsara.

"

videos.title: The effects of chanting mantras(GDD-123, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The power of mantra comes from the merit attained by a certain ghost, deity, Bodhisattva, or Buddha, as well as from the mental power or power of concentration of the person reciting it. The efficacy of mantras lies in faith.

videos.title: The difference between Buddha and God(GDD-124, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"In Buddhism, ""sin"" is the bad karma one brings from one's past lives since beginningless time; it reflects the idea of causality, or cause and effect. To eliminate our karma and change our fate, we are supposed to follow the Buddha's teachings and practice accordingly, and that is the way to achieve salvation or redemption.
 "

videos.title: Is enlightenment equivalent to Buddhahood?(GDD-125, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Orthodox Buddhism teaches about enlightenment but also teaches us not to become obsessed with pursuing enlightenment. Enlightenment in its true sense means hearing the Dharma, experiencing the Buddhadharma for ourselves, and then acting accordingly to change ourselves, instead of some mystic experiences, though they can reinforce our faith for the path.

"

videos.title: Are the five Confucian human relationships at odds with the concept of equality?(GDD-76 )
videos.description: Ethical codes are a system of order to define the role or position from which individuals should fulfill their respective responsibilities. They are there to protect us by conferring on us a number of rights, allowing our society to operate in an orderly fashion, which reflects the spirit of equality.

videos.title: Cooperation and submission(GDD-77 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The true meaning of cooperation is that through combined efforts people will be able to achieve their commonly needed and pursued work. Cooperation implies the need for division of labor and requires communication, coordination, and mutual understanding.

videos.title: Which is more important, the individual or the group?(GDD-78 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism advocates communality and helping one another based on harmony and equality by considering everyone's needs. Through group practice in this spirit individuals are able to develop faster and follow the more correct path.

videos.title: How should we view special privileges? (GDD-79 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Responsibilities and powers can't be separated, in that our rights are in fact our duties. In terms of Buddhism, life itself is a power we should put to good use in seeking wisdom and cultivating blessings so as to benefit ourselves and others.

videos.title: How do we maintain good judgment?(GDD-80 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To have sober judgment, we should keep ourselves from getting swept up and confused in new things or ideas by observing things dispassionately and making rational choice, or otherwise by following people with wisdom or intelligence.

videos.title: How do the Buddhas view sentient beings?(GDD-81 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddha sees all sentient beings as equal and as future buddhas, although they still have afflictions. The Buddha is an educator who helps us eliminate our afflictions with his impartial compassion and selfless wisdom, without thinking about how many beings he has delivered.

videos.title: Belief, understanding, practice and verification(GDD-82 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism places equal emphasis on both understanding and practice, and encourages people to immediately put to practice what they know. Practice and understanding should correspond to each other, although we can still practice Buddhism and therefore benefit from it even if we don't understand.

videos.title: Appearances and reality(GDD-83 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"In our current society, it is necessary to use publicity to call on people to participate in doing good deeds and hope others to follow suit. Ch'an Buddhism is down-to-earth and sensible; it encourages people to put in effort to practice so as to benefit physically and spiritually instead of putting emphasis on mystical experiences.
  
"

videos.title: The true meaning of Ch'an(GDD-84 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"The true meaning of Ch'an is wisdom and compassion, and the meaning of meditative absorption is not to be affected by our environment and not to be subject to any temptation. Ch'an Buddhism teaches that concentration and wisdom are one, with which we are able to deal with people and events objectively without giving rise to mental affliction.
"

videos.title: Simple and easy ways of practicing Ch'an for people who lead busy lives(GDD-85 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Ch'an practice is in everyday activities; our daily lives can be a time and place of spiritual practice. It all comes down to whether the mind is stable, whether our minds and bodies are unified, and whether we can be unperturbed inside.

"

videos.title: Do Ch'an masters also have to observe the precepts?(GDD-86 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A Ch'an master should also observe the precepts, otherwise he cannot have the power to move and transform others. A fully enlightened person must be one who can observe the precepts purely before transcending them all and without being bound by them.

videos.title: Mundane Ch'an vs. modern Ch'an(GDD-87 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Ch'an Buddhism originated with Shakyamuni Buddha and its essential spirit has never varied. It places great emphasis on daily life and the experience of direct awakening. By practicing Ch'an, even when one cannot achieve enlightenment, one is certainly planting the roots of good karma and will be able to have fewer afflictions and develop more wisdom.

"

videos.title: Twin practice of both Ch'an and Pure Land methods(GDD-88 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Pure Land Buddhism advocates reciting the Buddha's name or mindfulness of the Buddha, based on the teaching that the mind itself is buddha. Ch'an Buddhism teaches that as the mind is purified, so is the land purified. Reciting Buddha's name and the approach of Ch'an Buddhism are essentially identical. Nonetheless, Ch'an practice methods are the foundation for a stabilized mind and can better ensure one's possibility of birth in the Western Pure Land.

"

videos.title: Enlightenment vs. seeing the true nature of one's mind(GDD-89 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Enlightenment means the development of wisdom, the perfection of character, and the eradication of the afflictions, and it all lies in whether we are willing to let go ouf our ego or self. To achieve this we must frist realize conceptually that all things are without substance, and then use Buddhist methods to transform our minds.

videos.title: The difference between gradual enlightenment and sudden enlightenment(GDD-90 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Gradual enlightenment and sudden enlightenment serve the same purpose. As long as one becomes enlightened, it is good. It depends on one's karmic capacity whether one will attain gradual or sudden enlightenment. After attaining enlightenment one still has to practice so as to achieve the state of perfect buddhahood. 
"

videos.title: Deriving wisdom from concentration(GDD-91 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"In terms of meditation, concentration means a progress of practice from a scattered, chaotic mind to a focused mind, and then to a unified mind, at which point one will have more objectivity. In terms of Ch'an, selfless wisdom is achieved when one lets go of one's self-centeredness and hence becomes undisturbed by the environment.
 
"

videos.title: Spiritual capacity(GDD-92 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The root of goodness and that of affliction, or ignorance, exist side by side. As ignorance diminishes the good roots grow. By developing our wisdom and compassion, we are actually increasing our spiritual capacity and developing our good roots, which is the Buddha-nature, and therefore transform ourselves from an ordinary person.

videos.title: Seven-day Ch'an retreat - why fixed on  a 7-day span, and not more or less?(GDD-93 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The practice of seven-day Ch'an retreat comes from the idea of setting a time period to live a pure life and practice meditation. The timeframe of seven days is related to the movement of the universe and marks a cycle. Nowadays, seven-day Ch'an retreats are open to lay practitioners to participate in the practice.

videos.title: The relationship between Ch'an Buddhism and Chinese culture(GDD-94 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Chinese culture and Chinese Buddhism influenced each other and are inseparable. Ancient China, influenced by Confucianism and Taoism, was a rather humanistic and naturalistic society, so Buddhism in China has become an earthly religion, a unique quality of Ch'an Buddhism. 
"

videos.title: How Westerners differ from Asians in practicing Ch'an and applying Ch'an to their lives(GDD-95 )
videos.description: Ch'an got to the West after World War II mainly attributed to two systems of Japanese Zen, advocated by Kyozan Joshu Sasaki and Daisetsu Teitaro Suzuki respectively. Although Westerners approach Ch'an somewhat differently than Asians do, they both appreciate its physical and mental benefits for their lives.

videos.title: Buddhist tradition of transmission(GDD-96 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Transmission, which is a "meeting of minds" in terms of the insight into reality, marks the source of one's Dharma-body or Dharma lineage, and serves to prove or verify one's state of enlightenment.

videos.title: Demonic state vs. enlightened state(GDD-97 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Demonic states may come from our bodily reactions or psychological afflictions when we are engaged in meditation practice. Most people enter demonic states because when they practice their mind is not very pure. So the best way to do meditation is to have no attachment or craving, letting go of trying to get anywhere at all.

videos.title: Solitary retreat - its qualification requirements and benefits(GDD-98 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Solitary retreat is an opportunity for individual practice, to focus solely on studying the Buddhist canon, doing prostration to the Buddha, reciting Buddha's name, or sitting in meditation, among other methods of practice. One can benefit a lot from it if one has a good command of the concepts and methods of practice.

videos.title: Advantageous effects of meditation(GDD-99 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Meditation can help us balance our body and our mind, bring out our potential wisdom, and develop our potential physical and mental power. While Chan practice enables us to eliminate our attachment to our self-centeredness, and therefore attain liberation and freedom.

videos.title: Mutual affinity in Ch'an Buddhism - Meeting of the minds(GDD-100, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Intuitive meeting of minds is pointing directly to the human mind regarding the insight to reality. This requires one to have experienced some degree of enlightenment, which is beyond the expression of words.

videos.title: What does it mean to wear Buddha beads?(GDD-51 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Wearing Buddha beads reminds one to pay attention to one's daily actions. Reciting the Buddha's name signifies eliminating one's vexation. One can recite as many times as one wishes but the important thing is to focus while one is reciting.

videos.title: School education(GDD-52 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The fundamental reason for education issues lies in the human mind. The pursuit of personal freedom should not compromise ethical relations between teachers and students. Integrity and self-awareness are the key remedy to educational problems.

videos.title: Drug abuse(GDD-53 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People who use drugs lack a sense of security and belonging. Buddhism can help them establish a new view of life and sense of confidence by changing their outlooks and giving them encouragement.

videos.title: Should we let prophecies affect our lives?(GDD-54 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: From a Buddhist perspective, everything arises from the interaction of causes and conditions. Instead of believing in prophecies, we should believe in cause and effect, and that we can change our fate by changing our way of thinking.

videos.title: How to establish one's own senses of security and stability(GDD-55 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The Buddha taught that life is impermanent and the world is fragile and fraught with danger. By being mentally prepared, having a positive thinking, and cultivating merit with faith, we'll have a better guarantee of security.

videos.title: The relationship between our thoughts and behaviors(GDD-56 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: We should carefully examine our bodily, verbal, and mental actions, which will result in a karmic force that affects our fate. The mind is our master, and can change our fate and the world for better or for worse.

videos.title: The relationship between human and the Buddha(GDD-57 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: All sentient beings have the Buddha-nature and can attain Buddhahood. But Buddhist teachings are targeted at human beings, who are required to fulfill their ethical responsibilities and be compassionate toward others.

videos.title: The difference between human and the Buddha(GDD-58 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A Buddha is one who has achieved no-self and delivers sentient beings with wisdom and compassion, without thought of deliverance itself. An ordinary person circles around a selfish self and cares about gain and loss. We should transform ourselves by learning the bodhisattva way.

videos.title: Bodhisattva of infant-like practice and the Bodhisattva precepts(GDD-59 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: A bodhisattva of infant-like practice is one who has just generated the bodhi-mind to become a Buddha. Those who practice Mahayana Buddhism should learn the bodhisattva spirit and are encouraged to receive the Bodhisattva Precepts.

videos.title: How do we achieve no-self from ego?(GDD-60 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Although Buddhism teaches about no-self, the Buddha's teachings begin with the self and require us to affirm and develop ourselves by being our own master, and thus grow in merit and virtue and develop toward the road to Buddhahood.

videos.title: Self-affirmation (Part I)(GDD-61 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Self-affirmation is to take up responsibility for our actions in the past, present, and future. It lies in whether we can control ourselves or be our own master, by first knowing our own faults and strengths.

videos.title: Self-affirmation (Part II - methods)(GDD-62 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhist practice methods enable us to discover our own faults and take responsibility for our own actions, which is the true meaning of repentance. We should also repent for not having done what we should be doing in terms of Buddhist practice.

videos.title: Why should we repent? How should we repent?(GDD-63 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: To repent, either to our own conscience, to the person we have done a disservice, or in public, is to express responsibilities for ourselves. By repenting on a daily basis we can gradually purify our body and mind, and therefore eliminate our karmic obstacles.

videos.title: Buddhist repentance rituals(GDD-64 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The contents of different repentance rituals are compiled based on different Buddhist sutras. Repentance rituals can serve as a way of practice, help one cure one's karmic illness and achieve peace of mind when facing karmic obstacles or receiving karmic retribution.

videos.title: Buddhist etiquettes(GDD-65 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: True etiquette lies in internal sincerity, respect, and thankfulness. We should show etiquette in our mental, verbal, and bodily actions. By regarding all sentient beings as bodhisattvas and treating them equally, we will have politeness in mind on all occasions.

videos.title: Why do we promote joint weddings,  joint birthday  (GDD-66, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Dharma Drum Mountain promotes joint weddings, joint birthday celebrations, and joint funerals as a way to remind people of the true meaning of these occasions by introducing Buddhist concepts and methods, and thereby encouraging respect, frugality, the sense of responsibility, and harmony in society.

videos.title: Democratic spirit in Buddhism(GDD-67 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Democratic spirit in Buddhism is reflected in the six points of reverent harmony or unity in a monastery, where monastics are required to achieve the same views through communication and consensus voting.

videos.title: What is the relationship between the Buddhist precepts and the law?(GDD-68 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Democracy and law complements each other. The rule of laws, which are legislated in accordance with the views of the people, ensures a society's peace and security. Buddhist precepts were set down based on the social customs and conventions and in accordance with the people's needs in the Buddha's time, to safeguard practitioners' dharmic consciousness.

videos.title: How to draw the line between what's reasonable and what's unreasonable?(GDD-69 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Whether things are reasonable or unreasonable depends on the reasoning of the majority, logical thinking, common sense, and judgment based on experience. In a group setting, we must find a consensus everybody is comfortable and happy with.

videos.title: Personal views vs. conventional principles(GDD-70 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Personal views reflect people's judgments in their own place and time, which have their reasons and should be understood. But if one is very insistent on one's own opinions, it might compromise the harmony of all society. The best way is to continue offering our opinions to help while having the magnanimity to see them rejected.

videos.title: Subjectivity and objectivity(GDD-71 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: There is no conflict between subjectivity and objectivity because they are relative. Objectivity is achieved by bringing together everyone's subjective opinions, weighing up their importance, and making a best choice while respecting everyone's subjective consciousness.

videos.title: Being active vs. being passive(GDD-72 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Active is when a person takes the initiative, with mental preparedness. Passive is when we have to face and deal with a situation. But active and passive basically coordinate with each other and reflect the Buddhist idea of causes and conditions.

videos.title: Adaptation and change(GDD-73 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: When joining a new society, environment, or group, we must try to adapt to it first. Once we have adapted and realize that there are areas in need of change, we can seek gradual improvements by offering our personal opinions while listening to all objections and differences of opinion.

videos.title: Spiritual practice(GDD-74 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Spiritual practice is about mending our own bodily, verbal, and mental action. In addition to reciting sutras, prostrating to the Buddha, sitting in meditation, among other methods of practice, we can also practice while at work by putting our heart into our work.

videos.title: Mundane dharmas and supramundane dharmas(GDD-75 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Mundane dharmas are that which is dualistic and relative and involves a self and others, while supramundane dharmas are that which transcends time and space. To transcend the mundane means to be liberated from the relative and dualistic mind, instead of leaving the mundane existence.

videos.title: Organ donation(GDD-26, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Organs are parts of the body made up of the four elements and are therefore a false appearance one shouldn't attach to. Donating one's organs is an act of letting go of one's ego. It is a form of giving and has great merit.

videos.title: Birth (Part I)(GDD-27, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: People without children can share their time by doing volunteer works or taking care of other people's children. People should raise their adopted children as their own child. Parents with handicapped child should see it as an opportunity to walk the bodhisattva path. Parents shouldn't put pressure on their children by imposing their own expectations on them.

videos.title: Birth (Part II: child-rearing)(GDD-28, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Children should be allowed to develop naturally and their education must be directed at their own characters and personal interests. Parental care and love should not be compromised by material compensation.

videos.title: Aging (Part I)(GDD-29, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Aging is not a problem as long as the elderly know how to take care of themselves, keep going with their willpower and aspirations, and continue to be of use by contributing their experience and wisdom while learning to let go.

videos.title: Aging (Part II)(GDD-30, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
Genuine youth is in the heart, not in the skin. Focus on the present and keep looking forward, and do away with the problem of being old by awakening the aspiration for enlightenment, dedicating oneself to sentient beings, and learning the bodhisattva spirit.
.

videos.title: Illness(GDD-31, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Illness is normal and will help us develop a greater understanding of the process of life. We should view illness with detached observation and equanimity, as an experience to pay off our karmic debt.

videos.title: Death (Part I)(GDD-32, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Death is a natural part of life and people have to be mentally prepared for it. Instead of feeling sorry we should recite Amitabha Buddha's name for the dead. Letting go helps us overcome our fear for death and maintain our mental health.

videos.title: Death (Part I)(GDD-33, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Death is a natural part of life and people have to be mentally prepared for it. Instead of feeling sorry we should recite Amitabha Buddha's name for the dead. Letting go helps us overcome our fear for death and maintain our mental health.

videos.title: Death (Part III - Bardo: intermediate life entity)(GDD-34, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The best way to deliver the departed soul is to chant the Buddha's name or recite Buddhist sutras, enabling their minds to become opened and free of attachments, and hopefully sending them to the Western Pure Land.

videos.title: Consulting the dead & delivering the deceased from suffering(GDD-35, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Prayer services and transfer of merit through providing charity and doing good deeds can benefit our departed loved ones. Buddhism advocates cremation, for it is the cleanest method and keeps the dead from clinging to their own bodies.

videos.title: Greed(GDD-36, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Greed is when we want something we don't need; it is the root of all our mental afflictions. Apply wisdom to distinguish between need and want. Seeking well-being for society and for all sentient beings is not greed.

videos.title: Fame and fortune(GDD-37, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Ordinary people pursue fame and fortune out of greed. Buddhism tells us that these things are all empty. Success does not come from outside but lies within; it depends on whether you have a giving heart or are acting to serve society.

videos.title: Anger(GDD-38, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Anger comes when our greed cannot be satisfied or when things don't go according to our wishes. It cannot resolve a problem and can lead to mental instability and physical illness. Instead, handle the problem with compassion and wisdom.

videos.title: How to eliminate ignorance and enhance wisdom(GDD-39, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Ignorance means our mental affliction and a lack of understanding of cause and effect, as well as causes and conditions; it means our inverted views. Ignorance is false and transitory; all living beings have transcendental wisdom, which is always there and has never changed.

videos.title: Arrogance and doubt(GDD-40, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Arrogance can happen when we think we are superior, or inferior, to others. To eliminate our arrogance we should not compare with anybody but should instead walk our own path and make our own efforts.

videos.title: Emotions(GDD-41, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Feelings often develop into emotions, which are irrational and can compromise our physical and mental health. We should dissolve our emotions by using reason, adjusting our concepts, or reciting the Buddha or bodhisattva's name.

videos.title: The right ways of looking at love(GDD-42 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: True love means giving, mutual support, mutual understanding, and mutual respect. A marital union is a two-way situation and requires the right causes and conditions.

videos.title: Emotional adaptations during adolescence(GDD-43 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Young people in adolescence undergo huge physical and emotional changes. They need more understanding from their parents and teachers. By being friends with them, we can help them through sharing their feelings, and thus providing them with comfort and support.

videos.title: Idol worship during adolescence(GDD-44 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: "Idol worship during adolescence is normal, but the adult world has to change its business perspective in creating unorthodox people as role models and instead provide guidance to allow teenagers to admire great people and those who contribute to society.

videos.title: Buddhism's view on money (false speech) (GDD-45 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Greed and earning money are two separate things. Greed is selfish, while making money for the collective group, the family, society, and all the sentient beings, is not. Businessmen should make reasonable profit while paying back society.

videos.title: Buddhism's view on money (making charitable donations) (GDD-46 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Giving benefits both others and oneself; it creates karmic merit, which becomes a blessing for oneself. Giving is not limited to money; one can also give of their knowledge, time, or physical strength to help others.
 "

videos.title: Buddhism and environmental protection(GDD-47 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Environmental protection reflects the Buddhist idea of purity, which encourages us to live a clean and simple way of life, as well as respect natural ecology and relish the blessings of Earth.

videos.title: Protecting the spiritual environment (GDD-48 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Environmentalism is more than a concern of the physical environment and our living environment, it should also include our spiritual, psychological, and conceptual level. Protecting the spiritual environment lies in getting rid of selfishness.
  "

videos.title: Protecting the social environment(GDD-49 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Interpersonal relationships in life must start with etiquette and manners, which make human dignity and civilization possible. Respect and frugality are essential in practicing social environmentalism.

videos.title: What's the ultimate goal of Buddhism?(GDD-50 Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism helps people eliminate their suffering and live a happier life. Buddhist teachings are to be practiced in life. Chanting sutras and reciting the Buddha's name can train the mind, develop faith and concentration.

videos.title: Buddhadharma in the Modern Era (GDD-1, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Ch'an practice lies in our daily life. Spiritual practice is to constantly pay attention to our action, speech, and thought, and correct ourselves, and therefore attain spiritual liberation and freedom of mind.

videos.title: The Functions of Meditation  (GDD-2, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Ch'an is not in sitting; it is about wisdom and letting go. But sitting meditation can help us keep a serene, stable body and mind, which in turn facilitates our Ch'an practice.

videos.title: Chan Practice in Daily Life (Benefits of Chan Meditation) (GDD-3, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Meditation helps improve our work efficiency and emotions. Meditation requires relaxation in the body and mind, and guidance from an experienced teacher. One mustn't expect instant results in practicing meditation.

videos.title: How to cope with and alleviate stress(GDD-4, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Stress is self imposed, and often results from not letting go. We will feel less stress by turning it into a self-expectation or aspiration, concentrating on the task at hand without being worried, and thinking of work as interesting life.

videos.title: Must disputes and confrontations be settled through violence?(GDD-5, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In face of disputes and confrontations, instead of acting on our emotions and resorting to violence, we should use reason, patience, and compassion to dissolve the conflict and get along peacefully with others.

videos.title: Diversity and karma(GDD-6, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Diversity reflects the working of causes and conditions, and natural principles, which are harmony and coordination. Diversity is normal, so we are required to consider and respect others by dissolving our ego.

videos.title: Supernatural power and its impact on society(GDD-7, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Psychic ability and supernatural power do exist, which can be generated through spiritual practice. However, they cannot help one escape the law of cause and effect.

videos.title: How does Buddhism view the practice of fortune telling?(GDD-8, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Fortune telling and fengshui may have their validity and usefulness, but people can actually change their fate through psychological transformation and good deeds. What matters is the mind.

videos.title: Reincarnation(GDD-9, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism believes in the concept of reincarnation, in which people are compelled, and must take responsibility for their own actions, whether of the body or of the mind.

videos.title: Karma—the notion of cause and effect(GDD-10, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Karma of the three periods of time refers to the causes and effects involved in the past, present, and future. In applying this concept in our daily life, we should always be aware of the consequences of our actions.

videos.title: Buddhism and family life(GDD-11, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Family problems come from a lack of sympathy and respect, and a lack of understanding of each other's strengths and shortcomings. In engaging in spiritual practice at home, lay practitioners are required to first meet their responsibilities as a human being.

videos.title: How do householders practice spiritually? (GDD-12, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Householders can practice in daily life by cultivating discipline, concentration, and wisdom, that is, by following the five disciplines, maintaining a tranquil mind, and not clinging to the ego, which will help eliminate their vexations.

videos.title: Effective communication between married couples (GDD-13, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Good family communication requires the couple to use the attitude of appreciation to listen to what each other wants to express, say more good words, more words of comfort and consolation, and say fewer words of complaint.

videos.title: How should married couples manage their money? (GDD-14, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In dealing with family financial matters, the husband and wife should consider whether the use of money is proper and whether the family income and expenditures should be balanced, and create a harmonious household by maintaining the family together.

videos.title: Responsibility of household chores (GDD-15, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In family life men and women are equal, in the sense that the husband and wife should share household work and cooperate, fulfilling their role as mother and father, taking up family responsibilities together.

videos.title: Extramarital affair (GDD-16, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Extra-marital affairs bring psychological harm, a sense of insecurity, and fear, affecting one's health and causing suffering. In facing the situation, no couple should take divorce lightly. The situation should be dealt with rationally.

videos.title: Marital violence (GDD-17, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Marital violence is related to the Buddhist concept of anger and hatred. Domestic violence can be avoided through introspection and self-examination, the attitudes of respect and caring, and  rational consideration and forgiveness.

videos.title: Relationship with the in-laws (GDD-18, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: In-law problems are also a generation gap, which often result in family discord. The fundamental solution is to respect others by surrendering one's own ego and seeing another person from their position.

videos.title: The meaning of eating a vegetarian diet (Part I) (GDD-19, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism encourages people to eat a vegetarian diet not only for health and hygiene reasons, but mainly out of compassion and the belief that all sentient beings are equal.

videos.title: The meaning of eating a vegetarian diet (Part II) (GDD-20, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description:
"Meat imitation products are to tempt meat-eaters to try vegetarian food. Dairy products and unfertilized eggs are fine for vegetarians.
"

videos.title: Taking of life of household insect pests(GDD-21, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Buddhism opposes killing in any form. In order to keep our surroundings clean, the best is a hygienic environment and using our intelligence to prevent pests, instead of killing living creatures afterwards.

videos.title: Abortion(GDD-22, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Human life actually begins from the moment of conception. A fetus has the right to life and is one's own flesh and blood sharing a karmic connection or relation.

videos.title: Euthanasia - an act of compassion or of cruelty?(GDD-23, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Aging, illness, and death are natural phenomena. It's ideal that a person can just die naturally without human intervention. Religious faith can help one relax, and hence diminish one's suffering, both physical and spiritual.

videos.title: Setting animals free to save their lives(GDD-25, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: Setting animals free is to reflect the Buddhist idea of compassion and respect for life. But it mustn't end up encouraging hunters to go catch certain animals or disturbing the balance of natural ecology.

videos.title: Suicide(GDD-24, Master Sheng Yen)
videos.description: The human form is difficult to obtain and human life is precious. We obtain this body as a result of our karma and so should accept it and use it to repay our karmic debts or fulfill our vows as a duty.
